title: Canadians waiting longer for surgeries and other procedures compared to 2019: report
summary:
```html

Summary

Patients in Canada are experiencing longer wait times for priority procedures like hip and knee replacements and cancer surgeries post-COVID-19, despite an increase in the number of surgeries performed. The Canadian Institute for Health Information reports a decline in the percentage of patients treated within recommended time frames since 2019. Disparities exist among provinces, with Ontario generally having shorter waits. Median wait times for certain cancer surgeries have also increased slightly. Strategies such as same-day discharges and hiring more physician assistants are suggested to improve efficiency.

Facts

  • Hip replacement surgery within 26 weeks
    • 66% (-9%, -9 percentage points from 2019)
    • Number of procedures: +18%
  • Knee replacement surgery within 26 weeks
    • 59% (-11%, -11 percentage points from 2019)
  • Lowest provincial rates for knee replacement within 26 weeks
    • Prince Edward Island: 21%
    • Newfoundland and Labrador: 37%
    • New Brunswick: 38%
    • Quebec: 38%
  • Highest provincial rate for knee replacement within 26 weeks
    • Ontario: 76%
  • Hip fracture repair within 48 hours
    • 82% (-4%, -4 percentage points from 2019)
  • Radiation therapy within recommended time frame
    • 94% (-3%, -3 percentage points from 2019)
  • Lowest provincial rate for radiation therapy within recommended time frame
    • Newfoundland and Labrador: 57%
  • Median wait times increase for cancer surgeries
    • +2 to +4 days compared to 2019
  • Day surgeries in British Columbia
    • 2021-2022: 17%
    • 2018: 1%
```
quotes: "The data shows that 66 per cent of hip replacement patients had surgery within the recommended time frame of 26 weeks compared to 75 per cent in 2019, even though the number of procedures rose by 18 per cent."

title: Dollarama reports 24% profit boost in fourth quarter, hikes dividend
summary:
Summary

Dollarama Inc. reported a 24% increase in Q4 profit, with net earnings rising to $323.8 million. The company saw a comparable store sales growth of 8.7% for the quarter and 12% for the full year. Total sales grew by 11.3% to $1.6 billion in Q4 and by 16.1% to nearly $5.9 billion for the full year. Dollarama also increased its quarterly dividend by 29.9%, opened 65 new stores, and expects to open 60 to 70 more this year. Gross profit margin improved to 46.3%, and full-year net earnings reached $1 billion.

Facts

  • Q4 profit increase
    • 24% (24-per-cent)
  • Quarterly dividend increase
    • 29.9% (to 9.2 cents per common share)
  • Comparable store sales growth (Q4)
    • 8.7% (compared to the same period the prior year)
  • Total sales growth (Q4)
    • 11.3% (to $1.6-billion)
  • Gross profit margin
    • 46.3% (compared to 44.6% in the prior year)
  • Full-year sales increase
    • 16.1% (to nearly $5.9-billion)
  • New stores opened
    • 65 (total to 1,551 locations)
  • Comparable sales growth (full year)
    • 12%
  • Full-year net earnings
    • $1-billion (or $3.57 per share)
quotes: "Dollarama Inc.DOL-T +7.39%increase reported a 24-per-cent increase in profit in the fourth quarter, as Canadians feeling the sting of inflation continue to visit discount retailers to purchase everyday needs such as food, cleaning products, and personal care items." - "The Montreal-based company also boosted its quarterly dividend by 29.9 per cent, to 9.2 cents per common share." - "While people are buying less items during each trip to Dollarama, they are shopping there more frequently, partly as they look for lower prices on products the company refers to as “consumables.”" - "That has been an ongoing trend over the past two years as prices have risen and people have looked for ways to cut back"

title: Majority of recent CO2 emissions linked to just 57 producers, report says
summary:
```html

Summary

Between 2016 and 2022, 57 entities accounted for 80% of global CO2 emissions from fossil fuels and cement, as per the Carbon Majors report by InfluenceMap. Top emitters include Saudi Aramco, Gazprom, and Coal India. Despite the Paris Agreement, fossil fuel production has increased, leading to record high CO2 emissions. The report aims to enhance transparency and accountability for climate change impacts, and has been used in legal cases and research.

Facts

    • 80% (57 entities)
  • Top CO2-emitting companies (2016-2022)
    • Saudi Aramco
    • Gazprom
    • Coal India
  • Paris Agreement (2015)
    • Fossil fuel production increased post-agreement
  • Global energy-related CO2 emissions
    • Record high in the last year
  • Use of Carbon Majors database
    • Legal cases
    • Academic research
    • Campaign groups
    • Investors
```
quotes: "The world’s top three CO2-emitting companies in the period were state-owned oil firm Saudi Aramco, Russia’s state-owned energy giant Gazprom and state-owned producer Coal India, the report said." - "Since then, while many governments and companies have set tougher emissions targets and rapidly expanded renewable energy, they have also produced and burned more fossil fuels, causing emissions to rise."

title: Canadian deal-making still stuck in a rut, despite the hot markets
summary:
```html

Summary

Canadian M&A activity in Q1 2024 declined by 23% year-over-year to US$28.1 billion, falling 55% below the 10-year average. Stock sales rebounded to $5 billion from last year's $1.9 billion, yet remained below the $10.1 billion decade average. Debt deals rose by 35%, exceeding the 10-year average by 28%. No IPOs occurred, continuing 2023's downturn. Optimism is seen in equity and debt markets, with expectations of increased M&A activity as recession fears wane and private equity pressure to invest grows.

Facts

  • M&A activity
    • -23% (US$28.1-billion from Q1 2023)
    • -55% (below 10-year Q1 average of US$62.1-billion)
  • Stock sales
    • +163% (to nearly $5-billion from $1.9-billion in Q1 2023)
    • -50% (below 10-year average of $10.1-billion)
  • Debt deals
    • +35% (to $21.4-billion from start of 2023)
    • +28% (above 10-year Q1 average)
  • IPO market
    • 0 (no IPOs in Q1 2024)
```
quotes: "Deal-making all but dried up in Canada during the first three months of 2024, despite hot stock markets and a rebound in mergers and acquisitions globally." - "[M&A involving Canadian businesses marked]a 23-per-cent decline from the same period in 2023 and nearly 55 per cent below the 10-year first-quarter average of US$62.1-billion." - "There was a glimmer of optimism in the debt market, however, as Canadian businesses raised $21.4-billion through deals during the first quarter – a 35-per-cent increase from the start of 2023, and more than 28 per cent above the 10-year first-quarter average." - "That follows 2023, which was the worst year since at least 1994 for the Canadian IPO market."

title: Canada lost 8.6 million hectares of forest in 2023, more than 90% due to wildfires
summary:
```html

Summary

Canada experienced a record forest loss of 8.6 million hectares in 2023, with over 90% due to wildfires. This figure is 3-5 times higher than any previous year and represents more than 2% of Canada's total forest cover. The World Resources Institute highlighted this as the most concerning fire story globally. Despite the significant loss, Canada's overall forest area is expected to remain stable. The federal government reported an even higher area burned at 15 million hectares. Globally, tropical forests decreased by 3.7 million hectares, with deforestation rates dropping in Brazil and Colombia but rising in other countries.

Facts

  • Canada's forest loss in 2023
    • 8.6 million hectares
  • Percentage due to wildfires
    • Over 90%
  • Comparison to previous years
    • 3-5 times greater
  • Total forest cover of Canada
    • 367 million hectares (end of 2022)
  • Percentage of total forest cover burned
    • More than 2%
  • Average area burned annually over the past 50 years
    • 2.3 million hectares
  • Previous record for area burned (1989)
    • 7.6 million hectares
  • Canadian federal government's reported area burned in 2023
    • 15 million hectares
  • Global tropical forest loss in 2023
    • 3.7 million hectares
  • Deforestation rates in Brazil and Colombia
    • Decreased significantly
  • Deforestation rates in Laos, Bolivia, DRC, and Nicaragua
    • Accelerating losses
  • 2030 target for halting forest loss
    • Far off track
```
quotes: "The satellite-derived data, produced by researchers at the University of Maryland, showed that the swaths of forest burned in Canada in 2023 represented one of the largest anomalies witnessed since they began collecting the data globally in 2001. They dubbed it the world’s “most concerning fire story” of the year." - "The surface area burned across Canada last year “is three, four and five times greater than any individual preceding year,” said Matthew Hansen, a remote sensing scientist who leads a lab at the university that studies changes on the Earth’s surface" - "Canada’s overall forest loss last year, though widely described as record-breaking, had only a negligible impact on the country’s vast overall forest cover."

title: Cultural LTC admissions drying up in Ontario due to new priority rules
summary:
```html

Summary

In Toronto, cultural long-term care homes like Villa Colombo and Ivan Franko Home face challenges due to Bill 7, enacted in 2022. This law prioritizes hospital patients needing long-term care, leading to non-Italian residents being admitted to Italian-speaking homes, causing cultural isolation and confusion. At Ivan Franko Home, non-Ukrainian occupancy has risen to 25% from 8-10% pre-pandemic, necessitating additional cultural accommodations. Hospitals can charge patients $400 per day for refusing transfers. Discussions are ongoing to address these unintended consequences.

Facts

Bill 7 - Enacted in 2022 - Prioritizes hospital patients for long-term care home placement Non-Italian residents in Villa Colombo - Increase of 3 residents per month Non-Ukrainian residents in Ivan Franko Home - Increase to 25% occupancy - Pre-pandemic occupancy was 8-10% Hospital transfer refusal fee - $400 per day Transfer distance for patients - Up to 70 kilometres in general - Up to 150 kilometres in northern Ontario ```
quotes: "A law known as Bill 7 enacted in 2022 has garnered much criticism for allowing people to be placed in a long-term care home not of their choosing, but AdvantAge Ontario CEO Lisa Levin said the law has had other consequences as well." - "Levin, of AdvantAge Ontario, said it seems like the impact on cultural home admissions was an unintended consequence of Bill 7 and she has had “encouraging” conversations with Minister Stan Cho about how to address it."

title: 2024 Housing Market Outlook
summary:
```html

Summary

Weak economic growth is expected in 2024, with a rebound in 2025-2026 as interest rates decrease. Housing starts will decline in 2024, with a slight improvement over the next two years, but not reaching 2021-2023 levels. MLS® prices are forecasted to rise beyond previous peaks, indicating continued affordability issues. MLS® sales are expected to increase due to strong population growth, surpassing the 10-year average but staying below 2020-2021 records. Rental demand will outstrip supply, leading to higher rents and lower vacancy rates. Regional disparities will see the Prairie provinces thriving, while Ontario and B.C. face challenges.

Facts

  • Economic growth
    • 2024: Weak growth
    • 2025-2026: Momentum regain
  • Housing starts
    • 2024: Decrease
    • 2025-2026: Slight improvement
    • 2021-2023 levels: Not reached
  • MLS® prices
    • Forecast: Increase beyond previous peaks
  • MLS® sales
    • Forecast: Increase
    • 10-year average: Surpass
    • 2020-2021 records: Remain below
  • Rental housing demand
    • Forecast: Increase
    • Rents: Rise
    • Vacancy rates: Fall
  • Unemployment rate
    • 2024: Rise by >1 percentage point (to 6.5%)
  • Inflation
    • Mid-2024: Fall to mid-2%
    • 2025-2026: Stabilize in low 2% range
  • Interest rates
    • Mid-2024: Decrease
  • Consumer confidence
    • 2025-2026: Increase
  • Regional outlook
    • Prairie provinces: Positive performance
    • Ontario and B.C.: Challenges leading to decline
    • Quebec: Robust growth but below post-pandemic levels
    • Atlantic region: Realignment with weaker growth
  • Alternative scenarios
    • Pessimistic scenario: Recession in 2024, modest recovery in 2025-2026
    • High-growth scenario: Stronger growth in 2025-2026
```
quotes: "Expecting weak economic growth in 2024." - "Expecting lower housing starts in 2024. " - "Despite more rental completions, growing demand for rental homes will not be met because the cost of homeownership will lead households to stay in rental housing." - "Rents will rise and vacancy rates will fall." - "Higher mortgage rates made things more difficult for potential homebuyers, leading to less homeownership demand and weaker house price growth." - "We anticipate weak growth in gross domestic product in 2024 with economic momentum gradually increasing throughout 2025 – 2026." - "Consumers were a significant driver of post-pandemic economic recovery, but their spending capacity in 2024 will be constrained by high price levels and interest rates." - "Rising production costs and decreased demand will put pressure on Canadian businesses." - "Interest rate increases led rapidly to declining starts of smaller structures, particularly single-detached starts." - "We anticipate housing starts will decline in 2024, continuing the decline from the record high levels of 2021." - "Ontario and British Columbia are expected to drive the decline in national housing starts for 2024" - "Despite some recovery in homeownership demand, many households will struggle to afford homes in 2024 – 2026, leading to increased demand for rentals"

title: Ford delaying start of EV production at Oakville, Ont., plant until 2027
summary:
Summary

Ford Motor Co. announced a 1.90% increase and a delay in launching electric vehicles at its Oakville, Ontario plant until 2027, two years later than planned. The $1.8-billion EV retooling will still commence in May. The delay is to allow market development for larger EVs and to utilize emerging battery technology. The majority of the plant's 2,700 workers will face extended layoffs, with assembly workers most affected. Unifor, the workers' union, has secured wage and benefit supports for layoffs, and will negotiate for an extension due to the delay.

Facts

- Ford Motor Co. stock increase - +1.90% (no amount specified) - Launch delay for electric vehicles - +2 years (until 2027) - EV retooling budget - $1.8 billion - Layoffs for Oakville plant workers - Majority of 2,700 workers - Unifor members' layoff benefits - 70% of weekly earnings - Current Oakville plant production - Edge SUV (to be discontinued) - Unnamed future vehicles - Three family EVs with three rows of seats - Ford's EV market position in the U.S. - No. 2 EV brand for the past two years
quotes: "Detroit-based automaker said on Thursday it needs the additional time to allow the consumer market for larger EVs to develop, and to “enable Ford to take advantage of emerging battery technology.”" - "The move will mean extended layoffs for the majority of the factory’s 2,700 workers, said Ford spokesman Said Deep."

title: Canadian international merchandise trade, February 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

Canada's merchandise exports and imports saw a significant rise in February, with exports increasing by 5.8% and imports by 4.6%. This led to a trade surplus expansion from $608 million in January to $1.4 billion in February. Exports were driven by a record $2.0 billion (68.8%) increase in unwrought gold, contributing to over half of the export growth. Imports reached a peak since June 2023, with a notable 9.7% rise in electronic and electrical equipment and parts. Trade with the United States resulted in a surplus increase to $9.1 billion, while the deficit with other countries narrowed to $7.7 billion.

    • $1.4 billion

quotes: "Canada"s merchandise trade surplus with the world widened from $608 million in January to $1.4 billion in February" - "Exports increased 5.8%, while imports rose 4.6%" - "Exports of unwrought gold, silver, and platinum group metals and their alloys—a category largely composed of unwrought gold—contributed the most to the growth, posting a $2.0 billion or 68.8% increase" - "Exports of farm, fishing and intermediate food products rose 9.7% in February, the strongest percentage increase observed since July 2023" - "After falling 15.9% in January 2024, wheat exports (+27.0%) rebounded in February" - "Imports of electronic and electrical equipment and parts increased 9.7% to a record $7.6 billion in February" - "Imports of computers and computer peripherals (+41.4%), which had been trending downward since the spring of 2022, were mostly responsible for the growth in February 2024" - "Imports of energy products rose 10.2% in February" - "Exports to countries other than the United States jumped 14.2% in February, driven mostly by a strong increase in unwrought gold exports to Switzerland and the United Kingdom" - "Canada"s trade surplus with the United States widened slightly from $8.8 billion in January to $9.1 billion in February" - "In February, monthly service exports were up 1.9% to $17.4 billion" - "When international trade in goods and services are combined, exports increased 5.0% to $84.0 billion in February, while imports gained 3.7% to $83.6 billion" - "Canada"s total trade balance with the world went from a $595 million deficit in January to a surplus of $367 million in February"

title: Federal budget will include $15-billion top-up to apartment construction loan program
summary:
Summary

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced an additional $15 billion for an apartment construction loan program, aiming to create at least 30,000 new units. This funding is part of a series of housing initiatives, including a $6 billion infrastructure program. Trudeau emphasized working directly with municipalities if provinces are not cooperative. Ontario's Premier Doug Ford expressed willingness to collaborate but rejected forcing policies on municipalities. Alberta and Quebec criticized the federal approach, citing jurisdictional concerns and other priorities. Saskatchewan questioned the relevance of multiplexes for their province.

Facts

  • Federal funding for apartment construction
    • + $15 billion
    • Minimum 30,000 new units
  • Ontario's response
    • $6 billion infrastructure program acknowledged
    • Emphasis on municipal decision-making
    • $1.8-billion provincial infrastructure budget
      • $1-billion for municipal roads and sewers
      • $625-million for water-systems fund
  • Alberta's response
    • Concerns about federal funding adequacy
    • Claims of bypassing provincial jurisdiction
  • Quebec's response
    • Rejection of federal housing plan
    • Call for federal action on immigration
  • Saskatchewan's response
    • Doubt over multiplexes' relevance
    • Concerns about impact on other infrastructure projects
  • Canada Builds program conditions
    • Provincial and territorial partnerships
    • Complementary provincial investments
    • Development on various types of land
    • Development approval timeline: max 18 months
quotes: "Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, announcing billions of dollars in federal funding Wednesday to bolster apartment construction, says he will bypass provinces that don’t want to work with his government on the issue." - "“If a province decides it doesn’t want to be ambitious on housing, that’s their decision. We’ll work with the municipalities within that province that are ambitious.”" - "“I’m going to leave that up to each municipality to decide. They know best,” said Mr. Ford, referring to decisions on housing policy" - "“I don’t believe in forcing municipalities. I believe in working with municipalities,” said the former Toronto city councilor." - "In a statement sent out late Tuesday, the Alberta government said it had “deep concerns” about the federal housing announcement." - "“This is another example of the federal government’s long history of ignoring the province’s jurisdiction and playing politics with important issues like housing,” said the joint statement from Jason Nixon, Minister of Seniors, Community, and Social Services, and Minister of Municipal Affairs Ric McIver." - "Also Tuesday, the Quebec government rejected the federal plan, with the province’s ministers of Canadian relations and housing saying the Trudeau government should tackle the housing problem by addressing issues of federal responsibility such as immigration."

title: How lowering the number of non-permanent residents will impact Canada’s economy
summary:
```html

Summary

Canada's federal government plans to reduce non-permanent resident arrivals, aiming to lower their population share to 5% from 6.5%. This policy may slow GDP growth by 0.5% by 2025 but won't significantly affect per-capita GDP, unemployment, inflation, or interest rates. An older population and lower labour force participation are expected, potentially easing housing demand but not solving long-term supply issues. The number of non-permanent residents needs to decline by 20% (500,000 people) over three years. Immigration helps mitigate population aging, with 70% of new permanent residents under 35, compared to 40% of Canadians.

Facts

  • Share of temporary resident population
    • -1.5% (from 6.5% to 5%)
  • Non-permanent resident population reduction
    • -20% (500,000 fewer people)
  • GDP growth reduction by 2025
    • -0.5%
  • Labour force participation rate (2021)
    • Non-permanent residents: 74.2%
    • Broader Canadian population: 65.6%
  • Age distribution of new permanent residents
    • Under 35: 70%
  • Age distribution of Canadian population
    • Under 35: 40%
  • New home starts vs. population increase (last year)
    • New home starts: 242,000
    • Population increase: 1.2 million (approx. 360k new households)
```
quotes: "The federal government announced plans to aggressively cut back on the arrivals of non-permanent residents in Canada" - "The total productive capacity of the economy will grow more slowly with slower population growth" - "Slower population growth could make the economy grow about 0.5% less than previously expected by the end of 2025" - "Canadian productivity (output per hour worked) growth could be higher than otherwise would have been the case" - "Immigration helps slow population aging because new arrivals are substantially younger than the broader population" - "The total labour force participation rate among non-permanent residents is higher than for the broader population" - "Slower population growth might slow house price and rent growth in future years but isn’t likely to solve Canada’s affordability problem" - "Capping immigration might take some of the steam out of home price appreciation in 2025 and beyond, but isn’t enough on its own to push home prices lower."

title: Some provinces reject $6-billion housing program announced by Trudeau ahead of federal budget
summary:
```html

Summary

The Canadian federal government announced a new housing fund worth up to $6-billion, with conditions that include eliminating single-family zoning and allowing fourplexes. Provinces have until January 1, 2025, to agree, but Ontario and Quebec have rejected the terms, viewing them as federal overreach. The fund aims to support infrastructure for new housing, but faces resistance from provinces concerned about jurisdiction and the adequacy of funds to address housing needs.

Facts

  • Total fund value
    • $6-billion
  • Allocation to provinces
    • $5-billion
  • Allocation to municipalities
    • $1-billion
  • Provincial agreement deadline
    • January 1, 2025
  • Territorial agreement deadline
    • April 1, 2025
  • Ontario's additional budget for housing-related infrastructure
    • $1.8-billion
```
quotes: "The potential standoff over housing money looms as the Prime Minister is also fighting with the majority of premiers over their objections to the consumer carbon tax." - "But Housing Minister Sean Fraser said the government is prepared to go around any provinces that don’t agree to the fund’s conditions, which also include freezing development charges and adopting changes to the national building code." - ""We could never accept that the federal government interfere in our areas of jurisdiction while urgent issues under its responsibility are not taken care of,” said the statement issued by ministers Jean François Roberge and France-Élaine Duranceau."

title: Either the carbon tax goes or 'the prime minister’s going,' Doug Ford tells reporters
summary:
```html

Summary

Canadian political leaders are clashing over the federal carbon pricing policy. Ontario Premier Doug Ford insists the carbon tax must be eliminated, while Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre calls for an emergency meeting to discuss the policy amid a $15-per-tonne increase. This increase adds 3.3 cents per litre of gasoline, costing an extra $1.65 for a 50-litre tank. Trudeau defends the policy, highlighting rebates that offset costs, particularly for low-income households. He remains open to alternative proposals that meet federal emissions reduction standards.

Facts

Carbon price increase - 3.3 cents per litre - $1.65 for a 50-litre tank Rebates - Quarterly payments - Favor low-income households Next federal vote - No later than October 2025 ```
quotes: "Ontario Premier Doug Ford minced no words in saying that the carbon price has to go — or Trudeau will." - "Poilievre vows to scrap the policy if he becomes prime minister after the next election." - "In the lead-up to the April 1 increase, Trudeau dismissed calls from seven premiers to cancel it, including from the lone Liberal provincial premier, Newfoundland and Labrador’s Andrew Furey."

title: Consumers Keep their Wallets Open in January-FebruaryTD Credit and Debit Card Spending Report

Total spending in January and February 2024 showed a year-on-year growth of nearly 6%. Services spending rebounded by 2.1% month-on-month in February, led by recreation and entertainment, despite weak travel spending. Goods spending declined, with a notable drop in grocery store spending. Regions including the Atlantic provinces, Ontario, Manitoba, and Quebec exceeded the national spending average, while Alberta fell below and British Columbia trailed. Overall, consumer spending is expected to contribute positively to GDP with a projected annualized growth of 3.0% for Q1 2024.

title: Canadian Internal Trade Hub
summary:
```html

Summary

Internal trade is crucial to the Canadian economy, with $528 billion worth of goods and services, or 18.8% of GDP, traded interprovincially in 2022. One-third of Canadian businesses engaged in internal trade in 2023. The Canadian Internal Trade Data and Information Hub (CITH) was launched to centralize data on internal trade, enhancing decision-making for businesses and policymakers. Over one in five Canadian businesses sold to other provinces or territories, while one-quarter purchased from them. Labour mobility is also significant, with certain occupations exhibiting high interprovincial movement rates.

Facts

  • Internal trade value
    • 18.8% ($528 billion)
  • Business participation in internal trade
    • 33.3% (one-third)
  • Businesses selling interprovincially
    • Over 20%
  • Businesses purchasing interprovincially
    • 25%
  • Larger companies conducting internal trade
    • 44.9% (100 or more employees)
  • Smaller companies conducting internal trade
    • 17.1% (one to four employees)
  • Labour mobility in occupations
    • Managers in public protection services: 10.0%
    • Front-line public protection services: 4.3%
    • Transportation officers and controllers: 3.9%
    • University professors and post-secondary assistants: 3.8%
```
quotes: "Approximately $528 billion of goods and services moved across provincial and territorial borders in 2022—equal to 18.8% of Canada"s gross domestic product." - "One-third of Canadian businesses participated in internal trade by buying or selling goods across provincial and territorial borders in 2023." - "Over one in five businesses sold to customers in another province or territory during the preceding year, and one-quarter purchased goods or services from suppliers outside their province or territory during that time." - "Nearly two-thirds of businesses had no form of interprovincial activity." - "While 44.9% of businesses with 100 or more employees sold goods or services to a customer in another province or territory, 17.1% of businesses with one to four employees did so." - "Transportation costs were identified as the most common obstacle." - "Managers in public protections services (10.0%), front-line public protection services (4.3%), transportation officers and controllers (3.9%) and university professors and post-secondary assistants (3.8%) were the occupations that had the highest mobility rate between provinces and territories." - "Mine service workers and operators in oil and gas were the fifth-most mobile employees in Canada out of 134 occupational categories."

title: Toughest time ever to afford a home as soaring interest costs keep raising the bar
summary:
Summary

Canadian homeownership costs soared in Q4 2023, with a median household needing to spend 63.5% of income on an average home, up from 61.8% in Q3. Mortgage payments rose 3.3% to $3,990 despite a 0.5% price drop. Affordability worsened across all markets, with Vancouver, Victoria, and Toronto hit hardest. The Bank of Canada's rate hikes since March 2022 reduced median household purchasing power by 22% to under $500,000. Prospects for affordability improvement hinge on anticipated mid-year rate cuts, but significant challenges persist, and a full recovery is expected to be slow.

Facts

Ownership costs as a percentage of median income

- Increased to 63.5% (up 1.7 percentage points) Monthly mortgage payment -

Rose by 3.3% ($125 increase) Composite home price - Decreased by 0.5% Median household maximum budget - Decreased by 22% (down to just under $500,000) Home prices - Fell by 1.8% Affordability measure in Victoria - Increased by 4.0 percentage points to 80.2% Affordability measure in Vancouver - Reached 106.4% Affordability measure in Calgary - Worsened to 48.3% Affordability measure in Edmonton - Increased to 36.8% Affordability measure in Saskatoon - Rose by 1.6 percentage points to 37.8% Affordability measure in Regina - Stood at 30.4% Affordability measure in Winnipeg - Rose to 32.8% Affordability measure in Toronto - Reached 84.8% Affordability measure in Ottawa - Reached 49.9% Affordability measure in Montreal - Was at 53.3% Affordability measure in Quebec City - Stood at 35.7% Affordability measure in Saint John - Rose by 1.3 percentage points to 31.4% Affordability measure in Halifax - Jumped to 45.3% Affordability measure in St. John's - Was at 28.7%
quotes: "A household earning a median income needed to spend a staggering 63.5% of it to cover the costs of owning an average home at market price." - "We estimate they’ve shrunk the maximum budget for a household with a median income by 22% since the first quarter of 2022 to just under $500,000." - "It’s never been as expensive to own a home anywhere, anytime in Canada as it was in Vancouver in the fourth quarter." - "RBC’s aggregate affordability measure reached its worst level ever in the fourth quarter (84.8%)." - "RBC’s aggregate measure reached 49.9% in the fourth quarter—a record high for the area." - "RBC’s aggregate affordability measure was at a record high of 53.3% in the fourth quarter, a level limiting the pool of potential buyers." - "RBC’s aggregate measure jumped to 45.3% in the fourth quarter—far exceeding the long-run average of 31.9%."

title: Business Outlook Survey—First Quarter of 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

Business sentiment and sales growth expectations have stabilized, with demand remaining weak but showing signs of optimism. Business conditions, sales outlooks, and employment intentions have ceased declining. Sales growth is anticipated due to population growth, market expansion, and expected interest rate declines. Investment plans are being moderated due to high costs and weak demand, with a focus on maintaining capacity. Job vacancies are easier to fill, and while wage growth is high, it is expected to slow. Pricing behavior is normalizing, but output price growth remains high due to slow wage growth moderation and cost pass-through.

Facts

  • Business sentiment
    • Stabilized
  • Sales growth expectations
    • Stopped falling
  • Demand
    • Subdued
  • Price pressures
    • Easing
  • Labour market
    • Easing
  • Price increases planning
    • Fewer firms
  • Investment plans
    • Moderating
  • Capacity maintenance
    • More businesses focusing
  • Job vacancies
    • Easier to fill
  • Wage growth
    • High
    • Expected to slow
  • Output price growth
    • Remains high
```
quotes: "In thie environment, fewer firms feel the need to expand" - "But the slow moderation in wage growth and the gradual pass-through of high costs are keeping output price growth elevated." - "Cost pressures also remain a top concern, with nearly half of all firms still reporting larger-than-normal increases in their costs." - "And more businesses than in previous quarters reported taxes and industry-specific or localized regulations as a pressing concern." - "More than 60% of firms said the cost of living is influencing their wage-setting decisions, but less than one-third of these firms said it is putting more pressure on wage growth than it was last year."Only 27% of firms in the Business Outlook Survey expect inflation to persist above 2% beyond three years, down from 37% last quarter."

title: Indigenous peoples economic account, 2012 to 2021
summary:
```html

Summary

Indigenous Gross Domestic Income (GDI) in Canada reached $56.1 billion in 2021, growing by 10.0% from 2020 and representing 2.4% of the total Canadian GDI. Over the past decade, Indigenous GDI surged by 57.6%, surpassing the total economy's growth of 37.6%. Jobs held by Indigenous people increased to approximately 848,000 in 2021, up 8.0% from the previous year. All provinces and territories saw growth in Indigenous GDI, with Prince Edward Island, British Columbia, and the Northwest Territories leading. The public administration, construction, and educational services sectors were significant contributors to this growth.

Facts

  • Indigenous GDI in 2021
    • 10.0% ($56.1 billion)
  • Indigenous GDI growth over the past decade
    • 57.6%
  • Total economy's growth over the past decade
    • 37.6%
  • Jobs held by Indigenous people in 2021
    • 8.0% (848,000 jobs)
  • Jobs decrease from 2019 to 2020
    • -8.2%
  • Prince Edward Island Indigenous GDI growth in 2021
    • 12.7%
  • British Columbia Indigenous GDI growth in 2021
    • 12.6%
  • Northwest Territories Indigenous GDI growth in 2021
    • 12.4%

    • 6.1%
  • Manitoba Indigenous GDI growth in 2021
    • 7.6%
  • New Brunswick Indigenous GDI growth in 2021
    • 7.8%

    • One-quarter ($13.3 billion)

    • 8.7% (203,295 jobs)
  • Manitoba's proportion of Indigenous GDI relative to overall GDI in 2021
    • 7.8%
  • Alberta Indigenous GDI growth in 2021
    • 10.6% ($9.8 billion)

    • 52.8% ($475.5 million)

    • 9.4% ($1.2 billion)
```
quotes: "Over the past decade, Indigenous GDI increased by 57.6%, outpacing growth in the total economy (+37.6%)" - "Prince Edward Island saw the largest growth in Indigenous GDI (+12.7%)" - "Indigenous GDI in Newfoundland and Labrador increased 9.9% to reach $1.5 billion" - "Indigenous GDI in Ontario represented nearly one-quarter of the total GDI earned by all Indigenous people in Canada" - "Manitoba was the province with the largest proportion of Indigenous GDI relative to their overall GDI at 7.8%" - "Nunavut saw Indigenous GDI increase by 9.4% in 2021 to reach $1.2 billion, representing 25.9% of the territory"s total GDI, the highest proportion of all provinces and territories"

title: Registered retirement savings plan contributions, 2022
summary:
```html

Summary

In 2022, RRSP contributions decreased by 3.4% to $54.2 billion, with the proportion of tax filers contributing falling by 0.7 percentage points to 21.7%. This decline follows increases in 2020 and 2021. The median RRSP contribution rose slightly to $3,910. Yukon saw an increase in contributions, while the Northwest Territories and Nunavut experienced the largest declines. All age groups reported fewer contributors, with the largest decreases in the 55-64 and 45-54 brackets. Income level influenced contribution rates, with the highest income brackets increasing their median contributions to the maximum claimable amount.

Facts

  • Total RRSP contributions
    • -3.4% ($54.2 billion)
  • Proportion of tax filers contributing to RRSPs
    • -0.7 percentage points (21.7%)
  • Median RRSP contribution
    • +0.5% ($3,910)
  • RRSP contributions by region
    • Yukon: +3.6%
    • Northwest Territories: -17.2%
    • Nunavut: -11.6%
  • Median RRSP contribution by region
    • Nunavut: $4,560
  • RRSP contributions by age group
    • 25 to 34 years: -1.0 percentage points
    • 35 to 44 years: -1.0 percentage points
    • 45 to 54 years: -4.5%
    • 55 to 64 years: -6.1%
    • 0 to 24 years: +3.0%
    • 25 to 34 years: +0.7%
  • Median RRSP contribution by age group
    • 55 years and older: $5,000
  • RRSP contributions by income
    • Below $20,000: 1.7%
    • $200,000 to $499,999: 66.2%
    • $500,000 to $999,999: Median contribution equal to $29,210
    • $1,000,000 and over: Median contribution equal to $29,210
```
quotes: "The proportion of tax filers making an RRSP contribution (-0.7 percentage points to 21.7%) also decreased in 2022, resuming a 12-year (2008 to 2019) downward trend" - "Yukon (+3.6%) had the only increase among provinces and territories in total RRSP contributions in 2022" - "Tax filers aged 55 to 64 years (-6.1%) had the largest decrease in total RRSP contributions" - "The proportion of RRSP contributors varies depending on the income bracket of the tax filer"

title: Energy statistics, January 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

Canadian energy production saw declines in January, with primary energy production down 1.2% to 2.0 million terajoules and secondary energy production down 0.6% to 0.5 million terajoules. Crude oil and equivalent products rose 1.4% to 24.4 million cubic metres, driven by a 2.5% increase in oil sands extraction. Crude bitumen production fell 2.2%, while oil extraction (except oil sands) decreased 3.6%. Finished petroleum product production dropped 1.2%, with consumption up 2.8%. Marketable natural gas production edged down 0.7%, with deliveries to Canadian consumers up 7.6%. Electricity generation increased 0.7%, led by a 16.8% rise in generation from combustible fuels.

title: Study: "Sandwiched" between multiple unpaid caregiving responsibilities
summary:
```html

Summary

In Canada, 42% of people aged 15 and older provided unpaid care in 2022, with 13% caring for both children and adults, making them "sandwich caregivers." Women were slightly more likely to be sandwich caregivers than men, with the highest prevalence among those aged 35 to 44. These caregivers often faced negative impacts on their health and well-being, with 86% reporting at least one negative impact. Financial hardship was reported by 35% of sandwich caregivers, and 66% of those not retired said their responsibilities affected their employment.

Facts

  • Percentage of Canadians aged 15+ providing unpaid care
    • 42% (13.4 million)
  • Percentage of unpaid caregivers providing care to both children and adults
    • 13% (1.8 million)
  • Percentage of women as sandwich caregivers
    • 7%
  • Percentage of men as sandwich caregivers
    • 5%
  • Age group with highest prevalence of sandwich caregivers
    • 35 to 44 years (29%)
  • Percentage of sandwich caregivers reporting negative impacts on health and well-being
    • 86%
  • Percentage reporting financial hardship due to caregiving
    • 35%
  • Percentage of non-retired sandwich caregivers affected in employment
    • 66%
```

title: Canada’s unemployment rate will continue to tick higher despite job gains
summary:
Summary

Employment data anticipates a job growth of +25,000, but unemployment is projected to rise to 5.9% from 5.8%, due to a larger labour supply and longer job search times for new entrants like graduates. Job openings have decreased by 25% compared to last year, and business insolvencies have spiked early in 2024, signaling potential economic risks. Wage growth has slowed to 5% year-over-year in February, with average hourly earnings 2 percentage points lower. The Bank of Canada is monitoring these trends, with expectations of reduced wage growth and inflation, potentially leading to a rate cut in June.


Facts

 

  •  Job growth
    • +25,000 (from February)
  • Forecasted unemployment rate
    • +0.1% (to 5.9% from 5.8%)
  • Job openings
    • -25% (below year-ago levels)
  • Business insolvencies
    • Spike (in early 2024)
  • Wage growth
    • 5% (year-over-year in February)
  • Average hourly earnings
    • 2 percentage points (below wage growth measures)
  • Bank of Canada's potential actions
    • Rate cut (expected in June)

title: Gross domestic product by industry, January 2024
summary:
Summary

Real GDP grew by 0.6% in January 2024, with services-producing industries up by 0.7% and goods-producing industries by 0.2%. The public sector saw a 1.9% increase, led by educational services at 6.0%, recovering from strikes. Manufacturing rose by 0.9%, recouping previous losses. Utilities increased by 3.2% due to cold weather, while rail transportation fell by 4.9%. The mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction sector contracted by 1.9%. Real estate and rental and leasing grew by 0.4%, and information and cultural services by 1.0%. An advance estimate indicates a 0.4% rise in GDP for February 2024.

title: Non-profit institutions and volunteering: Economic contribution, first quarter to fourth quarter 2023
summary:
```html

Summary

Real GDP of non-profit institutions marginally increased by 0.1% in Q4, following a 0.8% rise in Q3. Non-profits serving households and businesses saw growths of 1.1% and 0.9% respectively, while those serving governments declined by 0.2%. Annually, real GDP of non-profits rose 2.7% in 2023. Job numbers in non-profits increased by 0.8% in Q4, with health care jobs up by 1.4% and social services by 2.6%. Nominal GDP of non-profits grew by 0.8% in Q4, contributing to an 8.3% share of the economy-wide nominal GDP.

Facts

  • Real GDP of non-profit institutions Q4 change
    • 0.1% (increase)
  • Real GDP of non-profits serving households Q4 change
    • 1.1% (increase)
  • Real GDP of non-profits serving businesses Q4 change
    • 0.9% (increase)
  • Real GDP of non-profits serving governments Q4 change
    • -0.2% (decline)
  • Annual real GDP growth of non-profit institutions in 2023
    • 2.7% (increase)
  • Jobs in non-profit institutions Q4 change
    • 0.8% (increase)
  • Jobs in health care Q4 change
    • 1.4% (increase)
  • Annual jobs growth in health care in 2023
    • 5.9% (increase)
  • Jobs in social services Q4 change
    • 2.6% (increase)
  • Nominal GDP of non-profit institutions Q4 change
    • 0.8% (increase)
  • Nominal GDP of non-profits excluding government Q4 change
    • 1.4% (increase)
  • Share of non-profit institutions in economy-wide nominal GDP Q4
    • 8.3%
  • Annual nominal GDP growth of non-profits in 2023
    • 6.6% (increase)
  • Nominal GDP growth in health care in 2023
    • 7.3% (increase)
```
quotes: "Real gross domestic product (GDP) of non-profit institutions edged up 0.1% in the fourth quarter" - "Increases in real GDP of non-profits serving households and businesses was largely offset by a decline in real GDP of non-profits serving governments" - "Real GDP of non-profits serving households grew 1.1% in the fourth quarter, as reliance on non-profit services by families and individuals increased" - "In the fourth quarter, real GDP of non-profit institutions serving businesses rose 0.9%, the fourth consecutive quarterly increase" - "Real GDP of non-profit institutions, excluding those serving governments, grew 1.0% in the fourth quarter, increasing for the fourth consecutive quarter" - "In 2023, the real GDP of non-profit institutions rose 2.7%" - "Jobs in non-profit institutions rose 0.8% in the fourth quarter, the fifth consecutive quarterly increase" - "The number of jobs in health care rose 1.4% in the fourth quarter" - "Jobs in social services rose by 2.6% in the fourth quarter of 2023" - "The nominal GDP of non-profit institutions rose by 0.8% in the fourth quarter, largely driven by higher post-secondary tuition fees and rising health care costs" - "Overall, non-profit institutions represented 8.3% of the economy-wide nominal GDP in the fourth quarter" - "On an annual basis, nominal GDP of non-profits rose 6.6% in 2023, compared with a 2.7% increase in real GDP, owing to significantly higher prices"

title: Farm operating revenues and expenses, 2022
summary:
```html

Summary

In 2022, Canadian farms saw average operating revenues increase by 10.1% to $707,635, while expenses rose by 13.6% to $576,003, leading to a 2.9% decrease in net operating income to $131,632. Oilseed and grain farms had the highest profit margin at 28.3%, despite a decline due to rising expenses. Potato farms followed with a 22.9% margin. Livestock revenues grew by 10.0%, with hog farms having the highest revenues at $3.4 million. Over half of Canada's farm revenues were generated by the Prairie provinces, with oilseed and grain farms contributing $33.9 billion.

Facts

  • Average operating revenues
    • 10.1% ($707,635)
  • Average operating expenses
    • 13.6% ($576,003)
  • Average net operating income
    • -2.9% ($131,632)
  • Oilseed and grain farms profit margin
    • 28.3 cents per dollar
  • Potato farms profit margin
    • 22.9 cents per dollar
  • Livestock sector operating revenues
    • 10.0% ($47.9 billion)
  • Hog farms operating revenues
    • $3.4 million
  • Prairie provinces total farm revenues
    • 56.2% ($60.9 billion)
  • Saskatchewan oilseed and grain revenue proportion
    • 79.7%
  • Saskatchewan operating profit margin
    • 26.2 cents per dollar
  • Beef cattle farms revenues in the Prairies
    • $16.1 billion
```
quotes: "oilseed and grain farms had the highest average operating profit margin in 2022, at 28.3 cents per dollar of revenue" - "Potato farms reported an average net operating income of $623,167 in 2022" - "The livestock sector reported $47.9 billion in total operating revenues in 2022" - "Hog farms had the highest average operating revenues across all farm types in Canada, at $3.4 million" - "Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba had a combined total operating farm revenues of $60.9 billion in 2022" - "Saskatchewan farms had the highest operating profit margin of all provinces, at 26.2 cents per dollar of revenue"

title: Temporary foreign workers in primary agriculture in Canada: Transition from temporary residency to permanent residency and industry retention after transition
summary:
Summary

Temporary foreign workers (TFWs) in Canadian primary agriculture have low transition rates to permanent residency (PR), with only 10% obtaining PR after five years and 16.8% after ten years. Transition rates are lower for lower-skilled occupations and those under the Seasonal Agricultural Worker Program (SAWP). Retention in agriculture post-PR is also low, with only around one-fifth remaining after five years. Over 60% move to other industries, and retention rates vary by skill level, program stream, and agricultural subsector. The study suggests that PR status for TFWs may not address the labor shortage in agriculture.

Facts

Transition to PR after 5 years - 10% (slightly more than 10%) Transition to PR after 10 years - 16.8% Transition rates by skill level (2005-2009 cohort, after 10 years) - Higher skill: 60.9% - Lower skill: 11.5% Transition rates by program (2005-2009 cohort, after 10 years) - SAWP: 5.9% - Other agricultural streams: Higher than SAWP - Other TFWPs and IMP: Higher than other agricultural streams Retention in agriculture after 1 year of PR - 50% or less Retention in agriculture after 5 years of PR - Around 20% Movement to other industries after 5 years of PR - More than 60% No T4 Statement of Remuneration Paid after PR - Significant portion Retention by skill level (2006-2010 cohort, after 5 years of PR) - Lower skill: 16.0% - Higher skill: 26.5% Retention by program (2006-2010 cohort, after 5 years of PR) - SAWP: 19.3% (PR admission year), 80.0% moved to another industry (after 5 years) - Other agricultural TFWPs: 33.0% (after 5 years) Retention by subsector (2006-2010 cohort, after PR admission year) - Crop production: 49.7% - Animal production: 81.5%

title: Economic outcomes of government-assisted refugees in designated destinations: The effect of city size
summary:
Summary

The study analyzed economic outcomes of government-assisted refugees (GARs) in Canada, comparing those who stayed in their designated cities to those who moved. GARs in smaller cities had higher employment and earnings than those in larger cities like Toronto. Movers to smaller cities also reported better outcomes. Differences in employment incidence (89%) and earnings (47%) between Toronto stayers and others were largely explained by the city's employment rate and GARs' source region. The study suggests that economic integration is more successful in smaller communities for those who stay.

Facts

  • Employment incidence of GAR stayers in Toronto after 5 years: 49%
    • -14.6 percentage points (compared to medium-sized CMAs)
    • -23.0 percentage points (compared to small urban communities)
  • Employment incidence of GAR movers to gateway cities after 5 years: ~50%
    • +15 percentage points (compared to those moving to smaller communities)
  • Annual earnings of GAR stayers in Toronto after 5 years: $19,500
    • -$6,500 (compared to medium-sized CMAs)
    • -$7,500 (compared to small urban communities)
  • Annual earnings of GAR movers to gateway cities after 5 years: ~$21,000
    • -$5,200 (compared to those moving to medium-sized CMAs)
  • Percentage of GARs moving from their intended destination after 10 years: 42%
    • +23 percentage points (compared to family class immigrants)
  • Control variables explained employment incidence gap: 89%
    • Source region and city employment rate as key factors
  • Control variables explained annual earnings gap: 47%
    • Source region and city employment rate as significant contributors
quotes: "GARs who were assigned to smaller communities, compared with those assigned to large cities, were much more likely to move" - "those assigned to Toronto had the lowest employment incidence and annual earnings" - "those who chose to move to gateway cities had the lowest employment incidence and annual earnings" - "those who moved to a smaller city tended to report stronger labour market outcomes" - "the majority (89%) of these differences across city size could be explained by the city’s employment rate, as well as the source region of GARs" - "GARs from West Asia had the lowest employment incidence" - "GARs from South America had the highest employment incidence" - "employed GARs had lower annual earnings than PSRs and economic class and family class immigrants" - "GARs who moved down in city size tended to have better economic outcomes than other movers" - "differences in individual sociodemographic characteristics and city-level characteristics accounted for the majority (89%) of the observed differences in employment incidence" - "regional economic conditions should be an integral part of GAR resettlement decisions" - "strong economic outcomes can be achieved in smaller communities, which can in turn increase retention rates"

title: The Provincial Nominee Program: Provincial differences
summary:
Summary

In recent years, the Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) has become the primary route for economic immigrants entering Canada, with significant provincial variation. In 2019, 35% of economic immigrants were PNPs, which rose back to 35% in 2022 after a dip to 24% in 2021 due to the pandemic. The PNP's importance varied, being nearly the sole source in Manitoba and Saskatchewan, while less significant in Ontario. There was a substantial increase in provincial nominees with Canadian work or study experience, improving economic outcomes. Intended occupations varied, with more skilled and technical nominees in some provinces and more professionals in others

Facts

  • Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) entries
    • 1999: 500 immigrants
    • 2004: 6,000 immigrants
    • 2019: 68,000 immigrants
    • 2022: 88,300 immigrants
  • Percentage of economic immigrants through PNP
    • 2019: 35%
    • 2021: 24% (due to COVID-19)
    • 2022: 35%
  • Pre-landing Canadian work experience
    • 2000: 6% of provincial nominees
    • 2019: 61% of provincial nominees
    • 2020: 67% of provincial nominees
    • 2021: 72% of provincial nominees
  • Pre-landing Canadian study experience
    • 2000: 4% of provincial nominees
    • 2019: 38% of provincial nominees
    • 2020: 40% of provincial nominees
    • 2021: 44% of provincial nominees
  • Intended occupations of provincial nominees (2019)
    • Skilled and technical: Dominant in Nova Scotia, Saskatchewan, Alberta
    • Professional and managerial: More prevalent in British Columbia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island
    • Lower-skilled: Majority in Manitoba
  • Age at landing (2019)
    • 20 to 29 years old: Increased from 24% in 2005 to 38%
    • 40 to 54 years old: Decreased from 38% in 2005 to 21%
  • Source regions of provincial nominees (2019)
    • Southern Asia: 34% to 42% depending on the province
  • Language spoken at landing
    • 2009-2010: 5% to 32% spoke neither English nor French
    • 2019: Almost all spoke English or French

title: Housing, wealth and debt: How are young Canadians adapting to current financial and housing pressures?
summary:
```html

Summary

Young Canadian households are increasingly avoiding the housing market due to high debt-to-income ratios and rising costs. The national household debt to disposable income ratio is at 185%, with young households under 35 reducing their mortgage burden. Despite a 2.5% increase in disposable income and a 9.2% rise in net saving for young households in 2023, their debt-to-income ratio decreased to 165.2%. Housing remains a key wealth source, comprising 89% of young families' wealth. Economic pressures and affordability issues threaten socio-economic mobility, with more first-time home buyers relying on family gifts for down payments.

Facts

  • Household debt to disposable income ratio
    • 185% (Canada's ratio)
    • 125% (G7 average)
  • Mortgage balances
    • - (Young households reduced mortgage debt)
    • $73 billion (Total mortgage liabilities growth year-over-year in Q3 2023)
  • Disposable income
    • 2.5% (Increase for young households in 2023)
  • Net saving
    • 9.2% (Increase for young households in 2023)
  • Debt-to-income ratio
    • 165.2% (Young households in Q3 2023)
    • -10 percentage points (Decrease from Q3 2022)
  • Debt service ratio
    • 2.4 percentage points (Increase to 9.7% for young households in 2023)
  • Housing wealth
    • 55% (Overall household wealth from real estate)
    • 89% (Young families' wealth from housing assets)
  • Down-payment gifts
    • 30% (Share of first-time buyers receiving gifts in 2021)
    • 20% (Share in 2015)
    • $52,000 to $82,000 (Average gift value increase from 2015 to 2021)
```
quotes: "Young Canadians recently reported that they are less satisfied and less hopeful about the future" - "In 2022, concerns over rising prices led about one third of youth to reconsider buying a home or moving to a new rental" - "Canada has the highest household debt to disposable income ratio in the G7, at 185% compared with an average of 125% for all G7 countries" - "Younger households are starting to turn away from the housing market, as their overall mortgage balances have declined in recent quarters" - "Households where the primary earner is under 35 years of age were the only age cohort to reduce their mortgage burden" - "The disposable income of young households rose by 2.5%, reflecting broad-based wage increases, while their average net saving rose 9.2%" - "The household debt-to-income ratio of young households fell to 165.2% in the third quarter of 2023, about 10 percentage points below its level during the same quarter in 2022" - "Young households spent 10 cents of every dollar earned towards servicing their debt, up from around 7 cents in 2022" - "Housing assets account for 89% of their total wealth, making them more exposed to fluctuations in the real estate market" - "The gap between perceptions of inflation and actual inflation is unusually wide, particularly for young Canadians" - "People living in a rented dwelling (41.3%) were more likely to be experiencing difficulties meeting their financial needs than homeowners with a mortgage (35.5%) or without a mortgage (20.4%)" - "Down-payment gifts have become increasingly important for first time home buyers" - "In 2021, the share of first-time buyers that received help from family members was just under 30%, up from 20% in 2015; during this period, the value of the average gift rose from $52,000 to $82,000"

title: Canada's population estimates: Strong population growth in 2023
summary:
```html

Summary

Canada's population reached 40,769,890 on January 1, 2024, a 3.2% increase from the previous year, mainly due to temporary immigration. Permanent immigration accounted for 471,771 people, while non-permanent residents (NPRs) increased by 804,901. Alberta experienced the largest net gain from interprovincial migration, with 55,107 people. Ontario saw the largest net loss to other provinces at 36,197 people. In the fourth quarter of 2023, the population grew by 0.6%, with 100,472 permanent immigrants and an increase of 150,347 NPRs.

Facts

  • Fertility Rate
    • 1.33 children per woman (2022)
  • Population Growth (2023)
    • +3.2% (+1,271,872 people)
  • Population Growth without Temporary Immigration (2023)
    • +1.2%
  • Permanent Immigrants (2023)
    • 471,771 people
  • Non-Permanent Residents (2023)
    • +804,901 people
  • Interprovincial Migration (2023)
    • 333,000 Canadians moved
  • Alberta's Net Gain from Interprovincial Migration (2023)
    • +55,107 people
  • Ontario's Net Loss to Other Provinces (2023)
    • -36,197 people
  • Population Growth in Fourth Quarter (2023)
    • +0.6% (+241,494 people)
  • Permanent Immigrants in Fourth Quarter (2023)
    • 100,472 people
  • Non-Permanent Residents Increase in Fourth Quarter (2023)
    • +150,347 people
```
quotes: "Canada"s population reached 40,769,890 inhabitants, which corresponds to an increase of 1,271,872 people compared with January 1, 2023" - "This was the highest annual population growth rate (+3.2%) in Canada since 1957 (+3.3%)" - "Most of Canada"s 3.2% population growth rate stemmed from temporary immigration in 2023" - "In 2023, 471,771 permanent immigrants made Canada their home" - "A further 804,901 non-permanent residents (NPRs) were added to Canada"s population in 2023" - "Alberta saw the largest net gain in interprovincial migration in 2023, adding 55,107 people" - "This was the largest gain in interprovincial migration nationally since comparable data became available in 1972" - "Ontario (-36,197) lost the greatest number of people to other provinces and territories in 2023" - "Canada"s population increased by 241,494 people (+0.6%)" - "This was the highest rate of growth in a fourth quarter since 1956 (+0.7%)"

title: National tourism indicators, fourth quarter 2023
summary:
Summary

Tourism spending in Canada increased by 2.3% in Q4 2023 and 13.5% annually. Tourism GDP grew by 2.5% in Q4 and 9.5% over the year. Passenger air transport and accommodation services led the growth in spending, while pre-trip expenses declined. Tourism's share of GDP remained at 1.58%. Jobs in tourism rose by 0.7% in Q4, with the sector's share of total jobs at 3.34%. International visitor spending grew by 3.3%, with accommodation and food services leading. Domestic tourism spending rose by 2.0% in Q4 and 7.7% annually, with air transport being the main contributor.

title: Economic and Social Reports, March 2024
summary:
Summary

Young Canadians are adapting to housing market pressures with mortgage balances for those under 35 decreasing, despite a general increase of $73 billion in Q3 2023. Their debt service ratios rose by 2.4 percentage points. Immigrant and temporary foreign workers (TFWs) filled lower-skilled jobs as Canadian-born workers moved to higher-skilled positions. TFWs in agriculture had over a 10% transition to permanent residency, with low retention in the sector. 10% of TFWs had weak labour force attachment in 2019. Government-assisted refugees in smaller cities had better employment outcomes than those in larger cities.

Facts

  • Mortgage Balances
    • +2.4 percentage points (debt service ratios for younger households)
    • -$73 billion (growth in mortgage balances in Q3 2023)
  • Employment Shift
    • 43% (increase in professional occupations by immigrant workers)
    • 37% (increase in technical occupations by immigrant workers)
    • 8% (growth in professional occupations by TFWs)
    • 11% (growth in technical occupations by TFWs)
    • -860,000 (decrease in lower-skilled positions by Canadian-born workers)
    • +213,000 (increase in lower-skilled positions by immigrant workers)
    • +139,000 (increase in lower-skilled positions by TFWs)
  • TFWs in Agriculture
    • +10% (transition to permanent residency rate)
    • +20% (retention in primary agriculture after PR transition)
    • +60% (moved to different industrial sectors after PR transition)
  • Labour Force Attachment (2019)
    • 10% (TFW Program participants with weak attachment)
    • 22% (International Mobility Program workers with weak attachment)
    • +50% (study permit holders with weak attachment)
  • Government-Assisted Refugees
    • 49% (employment rate in Toronto after 5 years)
    • 56% (employment rate in Montréal after 5 years)
    • 72% (employment rate in small urban communities after 5 years)
    • 63% (employment rate in medium-sized metropolitan areas after 5 years)

Summary

Canada's population reached 40,769,890 on January 1, 2024, marking a 3.2% increase from the previous year, the highest since 1957. This growth was primarily due to international migration, accounting for 97.6% of the increase. Permanent immigration added 471,771 people, while temporary immigration contributed 804,901 non-permanent residents (NPRs). Interprovincial migration saw 333,000 Canadians relocate, with Alberta gaining the most. The fourth quarter of 2023 experienced a 0.6% population growth, with 100,472 permanent immigrants and an increase of 150,347 NPRs.

title: Survey on Early Learning and Child Care Arrangements - Children with Long-term Conditions and Disabilities, 2023
summary:
Summary

In 2023, 62% of Canadian children aged 0 to 5 with long-term conditions or disabilities were in child care, with 69% using centre-based care. Comparatively, 56% of all children in this age group were in care, with 61% in centre-based care. Of the children with conditions or disabilities in care, 56% received support services or therapies, and 35% of these received services within their child care. Additionally, 61% needed extra support for activities, with the highest needs in social interactions (32%) and managing behaviour (30%). Most parents felt their child's needs were met in their care arrangements.

Facts

  • Children with long-term conditions or disabilities in child care
    • 62% (percentage in child care)
  • Centre-based child care usage
    • 69% (children with conditions/disabilities)
    • 61% (all children aged 0 to 5)
  • Relative care usage
    • 24% (children with conditions/disabilities)
    • 21% (all children aged 0 to 5)

    • 12% (children with conditions/disabilities)
    • 16% (all children aged 0 to 5)

title: The expansion and changing characteristics of the Provincial Nominee Program
summary:
```html

Summary

The Provincial Nominee Program (PNP) has become the predominant route for economic immigrants to Canada, with its share increasing from negligible in 2000 to 40% in 2023. The program has significantly influenced the distribution of immigrants across provinces, with a notable increase in the Prairie and Atlantic provinces. The PNP has also altered the demographics and occupations of immigrants, with a rise in those previously working as temporary foreign workers and in technical occupations. However, recent cohorts of provincial nominees have seen lower initial earnings compared to Federal Skilled Worker Program (FSWP) immigrants.

Facts

  • FSWP share of economic immigrants
    • -66% (from 79% in 2000 to 13% in 2023)
  • PNP share of economic immigrants
    • +40% (in 2023)
  • PNP share in Saskatchewan
    • 93% (in 2023)
  • PNP share in Manitoba
    • 85% (in 2023)
  • PNP share in Ontario
    • 21% (in 2023)
  • Immigrants intending to settle in Prairie and Atlantic provinces
    • +23% (from 10% in 2000 to 33% in 2023)
  • Immigrants intending to settle in Ontario
    • -23% (from 61% in 2000 to 38% in 2023)
  • Provincial nominees aged 20 to 54 previously temporary foreign workers
    • +55% (from 6% in 2000 to 61% in 2019)
  • Provincial nominees in Alberta previously temporary foreign workers
    • 85% (in 2019)
  • Provincial nominees in New Brunswick previously temporary foreign workers
    • 28% (in 2019)
  • Provincial nominees in Saskatchewan previously temporary foreign workers
    • 35% (in 2019)
  • Earnings difference between provincial nominees and FSWP immigrants (2005-to-2014 cohort)
    • +$6,900 (in 2020 dollars, initial two years after admission)
  • Earnings difference between provincial nominees and FSWP immigrants (2015-to-2019 cohort)
    • -$6,500 (initial two years after admission)
```
quotes: "The expansion of the Provincial Nominee Program has significantly transformed the selection process for economic immigrants in Canada since the early 2000s" - "The Provincial Nominee Program has played a key role in bringing economic immigrants to the Atlantic and Prairie provinces" - "The sociodemographic characteristics of provincial nominees have also changed considerably" - "The growth in the PNP, combined with the corresponding decline in the FSWP, has affected the distribution of intended occupations among economic immigrants" - "There was also significant provincial variation in the intended occupations of new provincial nominees in 2019" - "Provincial nominees used to earn more in the initial years after immigration than FSWP immigrants, but this pattern has changed for subsequent arrival cohorts"

title: Police resources in Canada, 2023
summary:
Summary

Canadian police officer numbers increased to 71,472 in 2023, but the rate per 100,000 population fell to 178, the lowest since 1970. Racialized group representation remained at 8% for officers and 13% for recruits. Indigenous representation was at 4% for officers and 5% for recruits. Women officers grew to 23% of the force. Civilian employees in police services rose by 1,316, and special constables by 185. Calls for service decreased by 2%, while police operating expenditures increased by 6% in current dollars but decreased by 0.5% in constant dollars.

Facts

  • Police officer numbers
    • +1.3% (+892)
  • Rate of police strength per 100,000 population
    • -2% (from 2022)
  • Racialized group representation in police
    • Officers: 8%
    • Recruits: 13%
  • Indigenous representation in police
    • Officers: 4%
    • Recruits: 5%
  • Women in police services
    • Total: 23%
    • +2.6% (+411)
  • Civilian employees in police services
    • +3.9% (+1,316)
  • Special constables
    • +185
  • Recruits
    • -55
  • Calls for service
    • -2%
  • Police operating expenditures
    • +6% (current dollars)
    • -0.5% (constant dollars)
quotes: "26.5% of Canada"s population was part of a racialized group... 8% of all police officers and 13% of all recruits in Canada in 2023 identified as part of a racialized group" - "women represented 23% of all police officers" - "women police officers mostly held constable positions, making up about one-quarter (24%) of all constables in Canada in 2023" - "Police services are increasingly composed of civilian employees" - "The number of calls for service to police services decreased by 2% in 2022/2023" - "the total operating expenditures for all police services in Canada were $19.7 billion in current dollars—an increase of 6% compared with 2021/2022"

title: Statistics on social inclusion for ethnocultural groups in Canada: New products and selected results on the evolution of education among racialized groups, 2006 to 2021
summary:
```html

Summary

Racialized groups in Canada have seen significant educational attainment improvements from 2006 to 2021. The proportion of racialized individuals aged 25 to 64 without any certificate, diploma, or degree decreased from 13.0% to 9.0%, while those with a bachelor's degree or higher increased from 34.9% to 47.5%. Southeast Asian women had the largest decrease in the proportion without qualifications (-9.2 percentage points). Racialized women surpassed men in bachelor's degree attainment in 2021 (48.4% vs. 46.5%). Recent immigrants (2011-2021) are more educated, with 55.8% holding at least a bachelor's degree.

Facts

  • No certificate, diploma, or degree (2006-2021)
    • -4.0 percentage points (13.0% to 9.0%)
    • Total population: -5.5 percentage points (15.4% to 9.9%)
    • Southeast Asian women: -9.2 percentage points (31.2% to 22.0%)
    • Southeast Asian men: -4.2 percentage points (25.4% to 21.2%)
  • Bachelor's degree or higher (2006-2021)
    • +12.6 percentage points (34.9% to 47.5%)
    • Total population: +9.9 percentage points (23.0% to 32.9%)
    • South Asian: +18.7 percentage points (36.5% to 55.2%)
    • Korean: +6.3 percentage points (54.2% to 60.5%)
    • Black: +12.5 percentage points (19.9% to 32.4%)
    • Southeast Asian: +10.6 percentage points (19.9% to 30.5%)
  • Racialized women vs. men (2006-2021)
    • Women: +15.8 percentage points (32.6% to 48.4%)
    • Men: +9.1 percentage points (37.4% to 46.5%)
  • Recent immigrants' education (2011-2021)
    • 53.2% under economic category
    • Recent immigrants: 58.0% under economic category
    • Before 2011: 50.8% under economic category
    • Recent racialized immigrants with bachelor's or higher: 55.8%
    • Racialized immigrants before 2011 with bachelor's or higher: 41.5%
    • Recent South Asian immigrants with bachelor's or higher: 68.6%
    • South Asian immigrants before 2011 with bachelor's or higher: 44.8%
```
quotes: "The 2021 Census of Population results showed that most racialized groups generally have higher levels of education than the total population in Canada." - "The proportion of racialized individuals aged 25 to 64 with no certificate, diploma or degree dropped from 13.0% in 2006 to 9.0% in 2021." - "The proportion of racialized people aged 25 to 64 with a bachelor"s degree or higher rose from 34.9% in 2006 to 47.5% in 2021, reaching a new high." - "For the first time, in 2021, the proportion of racialized women with a bachelor"s degree or higher outpaced the proportion of their male counterparts." - "In 2021, more than half (55.8%) of racialized individuals aged 25 to 64 who recently immigrated to Canada (during the period from 2011 to 2021) had a bachelor"s degree or higher."

title: Aircraft movement and civil aviation statistics, January 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

In January 2024, Canada's major and select small airports saw a 5.9% decrease in aircraft movements, with local movements dropping 15.7% and itinerant movements down 2.1%. Major Canadian airlines flew 6.8 million passengers, a 10.9% increase from the previous year, though the passenger load factor slightly decreased to 83.1%. International traffic outside the US rose by 14.7%, while transborder movements with the US increased by 3.3%. Ontario airports had the highest aircraft movements, with Toronto's airport experiencing a 7.4% increase in activity.

title: With move to limit temporary residents, Ottawa is ‘attacking the demand curve now’
summary:
Summary

The Canadian government plans to reduce temporary residents from 6.2% to 5% of the population over three years, a 20% decrease from 2.5 million. This policy aims to ease housing demand and inflation, with population growth expected to slow to 1% from over 3%. The Bank of Canada notes immigration's long-term neutral inflation impact, but acknowledges short-term housing market imbalances. Shelter prices rose 6.5% in the past year, with rents increasing 8.2%. Additionally, the Temporary Foreign Worker Program's low-wage stream cap for certain sectors will drop from 30% to 20%.

Facts

Temporary residents' share - 1.2% decrease (from 6.2% to 5%) - 20% reduction (from current 2.5 million) Population growth rate - 2%+ decrease (from over 3% to closer to 1%) Shelter price inflation - 6.5% increase (over the past year) Rent inflation - 8.2% increase (over the past year) Headline inflation - 2.8% (as of February) Temporary Foreign Worker Program cap - 10% decrease (from 30% to 20% for certain sectors)
quotes: "On Thursday, Ottawa announced that it will reduce the share of temporary residents to 5 per cent of the total population from 6.2 per cent over the next three years." - "The Canadian population grew by around 1.25 million or 3.2 per cent over the 12 months to Oct. 1, 2023." - "But Ottawa has conceded that recent growth is exacerbating some issues, such as access to housing and health care." - "And while Canada has struggled to build sufficient rental housing over decades, the recent rush of demand has pushed vacancy rates down to historic lows, according to Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp"

title: Male doctors accounted for 83 per cent of reduction in physician work hours from 1987-2021, study says
summary:
```html

Summary

Canadian male physicians, particularly married ones, have significantly reduced their working hours, contributing to 83% of the overall decline in physician work hours from 1987 to 2021. Despite more doctors per capita, Canada faces primary care access issues, with only 86% of adults having a regular care source in 2023, down from 93% in 2016. Average weekly hours for doctors dropped from 52.8 in 1987-1991 to 45.9 in 2017-2021, with male doctors reducing their hours by 5.7 hours of the 6.9-hour total decrease.

Facts

  • Reduction in physician work hours
    • 83% (by male physicians)
  • Average weekly work hours (1987-1991)
    • 52.8 hours
  • Average weekly work hours (2017-2021)
    • 45.9 hours
  • Overall decrease in work hours
    • 13% (6.9 hours)
  • Decrease by male physicians
    • 82.6% (5.7 hours of the 6.9-hour reduction)
  • Primary care access (2016)
    • 93%
  • Primary care access (2023)
    • 86%
  • Hourly gap between male and female doctors (circa 1995)
    • 10 hours
  • Hourly gap between male and female doctors (2019)
    • 4 hours
```
quotes: "Published Monday in the Canadian Medical Association Journal, the paper found that male physicians accounted for 83 per cent of the reduction in physician work hours that occurred between 1987 and 2021" - "Despite the country having more physicians per capita than ever before, patients are struggling to access care – especially primary care – more than in the past." - "Canada placed last in primary care access, behind the 9th place U.S."

title: Ontario’s public education system faces dire staffing challenges, survey finds
summary:
Summary

In Ontario, over a quarter of schools face daily teacher shortages, with 24% of elementary and 35% of high schools affected. Education support worker shortages are even higher, with 42% of elementary and 46% of secondary schools struggling daily. The survey by People for Education, based on responses from 1,030 principals, indicates that these shortages lead to safety concerns, with many students with special needs being asked to stay home. The Ontario government is seeking solutions, including increasing the number of days retired teachers can work without pension penalties.

Facts

  • Daily teacher shortages
    • 24% (elementary schools)
    • 35% (high schools)
  • Daily education support worker shortages
    • 42% (elementary schools)
    • 46% (secondary schools)
  • Survey response rate
    • Responses from 1,030 principals
  • Impact on students with special needs
    • More than half of secondary school principals
    • Nearly two-thirds of elementary principals
  • Retired teachers' workdays without pension penalty
    • Current: 50 days
    • Proposed: 95 days
quotes: "The staffing challenges in Ontario’s public education system have grown so dire that more than a quarter of schools experience daily teacher shortages and nearly half have daily shortages of education support workers, a new survey has found." - "School boards in many parts of the country have said they struggle to find substitute educators to help fill the voids left in classrooms when permanent staff are absent."

title: Railway carloadings, January 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

In January 2024, Canadian railways carried 29.3 million tonnes of cargo, a decrease of 8.5% from January 2023. This decline was primarily due to reduced shipments of coal and grains, although the volume was close to the five-year average for January. Coal shipments fell by 19.0%, while grains such as wheat and canola saw decreases of 26.2% and 46.7%, respectively. However, potash and fuel oils shipments increased by 7.9% and 12.7%. Intermodal traffic and freight from US connections also declined, by 3.3% and 13.8%, respectively.

Facts

  • Total cargo volume
    • -8.5% (-29.3 million tonnes)
  • Non-intermodal freight loadings
    • -8.3% (-23.5 million tonnes)
  • Coal shipments
    • -19.0% (-627 000 tonnes)
  • Wheat carloadings
    • -26.2% (-611 000 tonnes)
  • Canola loadings
    • -46.7% (-385 000 tonnes)
  • Other cereal grains loadings
    • -40.2% (-211 000 tonnes)
  • Potash loadings
    • +7.9% (+137 000 tonnes)
  • Fuel oils and crude petroleum loadings

Real GDP of the natural resources sector grew by 1.4% in Q4, driven by crude oil and metallic minerals extraction. Annually, the sector's real GDP fell by 1.7% in 2023. Export volumes increased by 3.1% in Q4, with crude oil exports up by 5.3%. However, natural resource prices dropped by 2.5% in Q4, leading to a 1.1% decline in nominal GDP for the sector. Jobs in the sector rose by 0.4% in Q4, with the forestry subsector growing by 1.4%. Downstream activities' nominal GDP saw a slight increase of 0.2% in Q4.
