title: The impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on the postsecondary graduating class of 2020
summary:
```html

Summary

Early in the pandemic, 30.6% of graduates lost jobs, and 23.6% faced cancelled employment prospects. Employment rates for 2020 graduates were similar to 2015 graduates three years post-graduation, at 90.3%. However, those affected by the pandemic were less likely to be in full-time work (79.7%) and had a higher unemployment rate (7.5%) compared to unaffected graduates (3.6%). Pandemic-impacted graduates also earned less, with income reductions up to 16.3% for master's graduates. They were more likely to feel overqualified and less likely to have jobs related to their studies. Fewer pursued further education, with 34.3% changing their plans.

Facts

  • Job loss or layoff in 2020
    • 30.6% (graduates affected)
  • Cancelled employment prospects in 2020
    • 23.6% (graduates affected)
  • Delay in job start date in 2020
    • 9.6% (graduates affected)
  • Cancelled job with confirmed start date in 2020
    • 8.8% (graduates affected)
  • Employment rate three years after graduation (2020 graduates)
    • 90.3% (employment rate)
  • Employment rate for 2015 graduates
    • 89.9% (employment rate)
  • Employment rate for Canadian core working age population with postsecondary certificate or diploma
    • 87.3% (2023 employment rate)
  • Full-time work rate for affected 2020 graduates
    • 79.7% (full-time employment rate)
  • Full-time work rate for unaffected 2020 graduates
    • 83.8% (full-time employment rate)
  • Unemployment rate for affected 2020 graduates
    • 7.5% (unemployment rate)
  • Unemployment rate for unaffected 2020 graduates
    • 3.6% (unemployment rate)
  • Unemployment rate for Canadian core working age population with postsecondary certificate or diploma
    • 4.0% (2023 unemployment rate)
  • Median annual employment income reduction for affected college graduates
    • 9.6% (income reduction)
  • Median annual employment income reduction for affected master's graduates
    • 16.3% (income reduction)
  • Feeling overqualified for job in 2023 (affected 2020 graduates)
    • 26.6% (graduates feeling overqualified)
  • Job closely related to program of study in 2023 (affected 2020 graduates)
    • 52.7% (job relatedness)
  • Further education pursued by 2020 graduates
    • 32.4% (pursued further education)
  • Further education pursued by 2015 graduates
    • 39.7% (pursued further education)
  • Changes to further education plans among 2020 graduates
    • 34.3% (changed plans)
  • Delayed further studies among 2020 graduates

title: Travel between Canada and other countries, January 2024

Summary

In January 2024, non-resident visits to Canada reached 75.9% of pre-pandemic levels, with US residents making 910,600 trips and overseas residents 278,700. Canadian residents returning from abroad hit 91.2% of January 2020 levels, totaling 4.0 million trips. Compared to December 2023, non-resident arrivals decreased by 6.1%, while returning Canadian residents increased by 0.6%. US automobile arrivals were 76.0% of January 2020 figures, while air arrivals reached 79.0%. Overseas air arrivals stood at 96.1% of total overseas visits. title: Screened passenger traffic at Canadian airports, February 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

In February 2024, Canada's eight largest airports saw a 4.2 million passenger throughput, an 11.2% increase from February 2023 but 0.4% lower than February 2020. International passengers were up 18.9% from 2023 and 11.2% from February 2020. Transborder traffic to the US rose by 15.2%, yet remained 4.5% below pre-pandemic levels. Domestic traffic increased by 3.1% from 2023 but was 5.6% less than in 2020. Vancouver and Calgary airports exceeded their pre-pandemic passenger volumes, while Montréal broke a 10-month streak of surpassing pre-pandemic levels.

title: Industrial carbon price more effective to reduce greenhouse gases than consumer policy, report says
summary:
```html

Summary

Canada's carbon pricing for heavy industrial emitters is deemed three times more effective than the consumer carbon price, according to the Canadian Climate Institute. Industrial pricing is projected to account for 20-48% of emission reductions from 2025 to 2030, while consumer pricing is expected to contribute 8-14%. To meet the 2030 goal of a 40% reduction from 2005 levels, Canada must address policy overlaps and increase stringency. Current policies are anticipated to prevent 226 megatonnes of annual emissions by 2030, but Canada may still fall 30-40 megatonnes short of its target.

Facts

  • Industrial carbon pricing effectiveness
    • 20-48% (between 2025 and 2030)
  • Consumer carbon pricing effectiveness
    • 8-14% (between 2025 and 2030)
  • Projected emissions reductions by 2030
    • 226 megatonnes (annually)
  • Gap to 2030 emissions target
    • 30-40 megatonnes (annually)
```
quotes: "Canada’s carbon pricing system for heavy industrial emitters is by far the country’s most impactful policy for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and roughly three times more effective than the more controversial carbon price paid by most consumers, according to new research being released on Thursday." - ""It’s just a fact that industrial carbon pricing is the most important contributor to carbon reduction across the country." - Climate Institute president Rick Smith" - "Among the best ways to close that gap, it suggests, is by further strengthening the industrial carbon pricing system already doing the most heavy lifting."

title: Canada’s AI infrastructure does not compute
summary:
Summary

Canada's AI computing infrastructure is lagging, with the Niagara system falling from 53rd to 212th in global rankings since 2018. The country's AI capacity is ranked fifth, but infrastructure fell from 15th to 23rd. The federal government's $125-million AI strategy in 2017 is insufficient for current demands, with calls for $1-billion to $10-billion in investment. The U.S. and other nations are heavily investing in computing power, while Canada's most powerful system, Narval, is now 134th globally. The Digital Research Alliance of Canada recommends doubling capacity, but funding and procurement are slow.

Facts

- Niagara's global computing system ranking - Dropped to 212th - Was 53rd at launch in 2018 - AI capacity global ranking for Canada - Ranked 5th - AI infrastructure global ranking for Canada - Fell to 23rd from 15th - Pan-Canadian Artificial Intelligence Strategy funding - Initial funding was $125 million in 2017 - Narval's global computing system ranking - Dropped to 134th - Was 83rd at launch in 2021 - Digital Research Alliance of Canada's recommendation - Capacity should be doubled - Federal government investment in AI compute - $40 million announced in 2021 - U.S. investment in computing power - Spending $52 billion on semiconductor manufacturing - Japan's investment in computing power - Allocated $13 billion for chips sector - Britain's investment in computing power - Announced about £1.7 billion ($2.9 billion) since March 2023 - Proposed Canadian investment in AI compute - Calls for at least $1 billion to start - Up to $10 billion over several years suggested
quotes: "“We still have one of the greatest talent concentrations in AI in the world. But we are in danger of losing it because now there’s so much money being invested in these large systems, mostly in the U.S., that the brain drain is probably coming back,” said Prof. Bengio, the scientific director at the Mila AI institute and professor at the Université de Montréal. " - "But when ranked on infrastructure, Canada fell from 15th to 23rd place compared with the previous study." - "Since March, 2023, Britain has announced about £1.7-billion ($2.9-billion) to expand compute access and build infrastructure. By comparison, Canada announced $40-million to boost AI compute in 2021." - "Canada trailed all of its G7 peers in terms of aggregate computing power, according to the report, and ranked second last when adjusted for gross domestic product." - "Others will scale down their research because of a lack of resources, partner with researchers in another country or try to get access through a commercial cloud provider such as Microsoft, Google or Amazon.com Inc." - "“Canadians are behind, and most of our demand came from the United States in our first full year,” - Dave King co-founder of Denvr Dataworks in Calgary" - "And for all of the hype and excitement, Canadian companies have been slow to adopt generative AI, which is still a nascent, unreliable and expensive technology that has to prove its worth." - "With generative AI specifically, the Conference Board of Canada estimated in February that the technology could add close to 2 per cent to Canada’s gross domestic product, assuming businesses adopt it."

title: Trends in online banking and shopping
summary:
```html

Summary

Internet usage in Canada increased from 91% in 2018 to 94% in 2022, with online banking adoption growing especially among older adults (aged 65+), from 62% to 70%. Socio-economic factors significantly influence digital banking access; 16% of the lowest-income families lacked Internet access. Education and employment status also correlated with digital engagement. Trust in financial institutions and AI technology positively affected online banking usage. Online shopping was common among Internet users at 79%, with credit cards being the preferred payment method at 89%.

Facts

  • Internet usage in Canada
    • 3% increase (91% to 94%)
  • Online banking by older adults (65+)
    • 8% increase (62% to 70%)
  • Internet access by income
    • Lowest-income families without Internet: 16%
    • Second-lowest income decile without Internet: 11%
    • Highest income ($130,000+) without Internet: <1%
  • Internet access by employment status
    • Unemployed without Internet: 10%
    • Employed without Internet: <1%
  • Internet access by education
    • Less than high school without Internet: 15%
    • High school diploma without Internet: 6%
    • Trades certificate or diploma without Internet: 5%
    • University-educated without Internet: 1%
  • Online banking by age
    • Internet users aged 65-74 banking online: 76%
    • Internet users aged 75+ banking online: 61%
    • Internet users aged 25-34 banking online: 90%
  • Online banking by socio-economic status
    • Not employed banking online: 70%
    • Employed banking online: 89%
    • Lowest income decile banking online increase: 10% (63% to 73%)
  • Online banking by education
    • Without high school diploma banking online: 54%
    • With high school diploma banking online: 79%
    • With university degree banking online: 90%
  • Online shopping
    • Internet users shopping online: 79%
  • Payment methods for online shopping
    • Credit card use: 89%
    • Virtual wallet use increase: 100% (8% to 17%)

title: New Housing Price Index, February 2024
summary:

Summary

In February 2024, Canadian new home prices slightly increased by 0.1% month-over-month, the first rise since August 2023. Six of the 27 surveyed CMAs saw price increases, led by Montréal and Edmonton, while prices dropped in Winnipeg. Year-over-year, new home prices declined by 0.4%, with Ottawa experiencing the largest decrease. Unsold new single-family home inventory rose by 20.3% compared to the previous year.

  • Victoria year-over-year price change

  • Saskatoon year-over-year price change

In January 2024, household credit liabilities increased by $8.8 billion (+0.3%), reaching $2,928.6 billion. Mortgage debt grew by $5.4 billion (+0.2%), with the slowest year-over-year increase since April 2001 at 3.4%. Non-mortgage loan debt rose by $3.5 billion (+0.5% monthly; +5.7% annualized), with credit card debt increasing by $1.1 billion (+1.1%). Private non-financial corporations saw a decline in total credit liabilities by $3.0 billion (-0.1%), with significant repayment of government loans due to the Canada Emergency Business Account deadline, resulting in a -$10.1 billion change in overall borrowing.

title: Employment Insurance, January 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

In January 2024, Canadian Employment Insurance beneficiaries remained stable, with a minor increase of 0.3% (1,600 individuals) from the previous month, totaling 468,000. Over the year, there was an 18.0% increase, partially recovering from the prior year's 40.6% decrease. Youth beneficiaries rose by 1.7%, with equal gains among young men and women. Older recipient numbers also increased over the year. Alberta and Saskatchewan saw more EI recipients, while Newfoundland and Labrador and Nova Scotia experienced declines. The national unemployment rate slightly decreased to 5.7%.

Facts

  • Total EI Beneficiaries
    • +0.3% (+1,600)
    • +18.0% (+71,000) year-over-year
    • -40.6% (-271,000) previous year-over-year
  • Unemployment Rate
    • -0.1 percentage points to 5.7%
  • Youth Beneficiaries (15-24 years)
    • +1.7% (+800)
    • Young Women: +2.9% (+400)
    • Young Men: +1.2% (+400)
    • +29.3% (+7,300) young men year-over-year
    • +17.1% (+1,900) young women year-over-year
  • Youth Unemployment Rate
    • +1.1 percentage points to 10.8%
  • Older Beneficiaries (55+ years)
    • Women: -1.0% (-500)
    • Men: little change
    • +13.3% (+9,400) older men year-over-year
    • +9.6% (+4,100) older women year-over-year
  • Core-aged Beneficiaries (25-54 years)
    • +21.2% (+32,000) men year-over-year
    • +17.1% (+16,000) women year-over-year
  • Core-aged Unemployment Rate
    • Men: +0.8 percentage points to 5.1%
    • Women: +0.9 percentage points to 5.0%
  • Provincial EI Beneficiaries
    • Alberta: +3.4% (+1,800)
    • Saskatchewan: +1.8% (+300)
    • Newfoundland and Labrador: -1.3% (-400)
    • Nova Scotia: -1.5% (-300)
```
quotes: "'In January 2024, there were 800 (+1.7%) more youth (aged 15 to 24 years) receiving regular EI benefits, the second increase in three months." - "The increase in January was split evenly between young women (+400; +2.9%) and young men (+400; +1.2%)." - "Compared with January 2023, the number of regular EI recipients increased by 7,300 (+29.3%) among young men and by 1,900 (+17.1%) among young women in January 2024." - "Over the 12 months ending in January, more older men (+9,400; +13.3%) and older women (+4,100; +9.6%) received regular EI benefits." - "In Alberta, the number of people receiving regular EI benefits in January rose by 1,800 (+3.4%), the fourth consecutive monthly increase." - "The Calgary (+600; +3.8%) and Edmonton (+600; +3.5%) census metropolitan areas both recorded increases in the number of regular EI recipients in the month.'"

title: Summary of Governing Council deliberations: Fixed announcement date of March 6, 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

The global economy has slowed, with the US showing surprising strength due to a robust labour market. Euro area growth is minimal, while China's investment activity, especially in property, has weakened. Inflation is easing in the US and euro area, with improved supply conditions and a downward trend in core inflation. Canadian GDP growth exceeded expectations in Q4 2023, driven by exports, but domestic demand fell. Canadian CPI inflation eased to 2.9% in January, with goods prices slowing but services remaining stable. Shelter costs continue to drive inflation, with high mortgage interest costs contributing significantly.

Facts

  • Global economic growth
    • - Slowed in most regions
  • US economic activity
    • - Slowed but remains strong
  • Euro area growth
    • - Barely positive
  • China's growth in Q4 2023
    • - Slowed
  • US and euro area inflation
    • - Continued to ease
  • Oil prices
    • - Edged up slightly
  • Canadian GDP growth in Q4 2023
    • - Higher than projected
  • Canadian domestic demand in Q4 2023
    • - Declined
  • Canadian employment growth
    • - Slower than population growth
  • Canadian wage growth
    • - Showing signs of easing
  • Canadian CPI inflation in January
    • - Eased to 2.9%
  • Canadian shelter price inflation in January
    • - High at 6.2%
  • Canadian core inflation measures
    • - CPI-trim at 3.4%
    • - CPI-median at 3.3%
  • Monetary policy rate
    • - Maintained at 5%
```
quotes: ""Growth had slowed in most regions." 'In the United States, economic activity also slowed but remained surprisingly strong." - "Growth in the euro area had been barely positive." - "In China, growth slowed as expected in the fourth quarter of 2023." - "Inflation had continued to ease in both the United States and the euro area." - "Equity markets were strong and credit spreads had narrowed since the January Report." - "Growth in gross domestic product (GDP) was somewhat higher than projected in the January Report, led by stronger exports." - "Labour markets continued to ease gradually, with employment growing more slowly than the population." - "Recent strength in resales could translate into a pickup in house prices and stoke shelter price inflation." - "The Bank’s preferred measures of core inflation were both lower, at 3.4% for CPI-trim and 3.3% for CPI-median, but still above 3%." - "Shelter price inflation, which includes mortgage interest costs, rent and components related to home ownership, remained high at 6.2% in January." - "If the housing sector rebounds in the spring, shelter price inflation could be pushed up, delaying the return of CPI inflation to the 2% target." - "If inflation proves more persistent than expected, monetary policy would likely need to remain restrictive for longer." - "Members agreed that the current stance of monetary policy was doing its work to slow economic growth and relieve price pressures, but that more time was needed to restore price stability." - "Governing Council therefore agreed to maintain the policy rate at 5%." - "Members agreed they need to see further and sustained easing in underlying inflation.'"

title: National Insights into Non-profit Organizations, Canadian Survey on Business Conditions, 2023
summary:
```html

Summary

In 2022, Canada's non-profit sector contributed $216.5 billion (8.2% of GDP). In 2023, 92.6% of non-profits had boards, with 47.3% positions held by women, and 9.8% by racialized groups. The general public was the primary service target (42.1%), with health and social services most reliant on provincial funding (43.6% and 42.5%, respectively). Individual donations were significant for registered charities (41.5%). Demand for non-profit services increased (46.1%), outpacing capacity growth (24.3%). The sector is volunteer-heavy (81.8%), with sports and recreation being the largest focus area (33.3%).

Facts

  • Economic Contribution
    • 8.2% ($216.5 billion)
  • Board Diversity - Women
    • 47.3%

    • Environment: 56.0%
    • Business/Professional Associations and Unions: 36.4%
    • Religion: 37.1%
  • Board Diversity - Racialized Groups
    • 9.8%
    • Religion: 15.7%
    • Business/Professional Associations and Unions: 13.1%
    • Environment: 2.9%
    • Development and Housing: 4.7%

    • Children and Youth: 14.2%
    • Religious/Spiritual Groups: 9.1%
    • Occupations/Union Groups: 4.7%
    • Low-Income Households: 3.4% (primary), 26.8% (served)
  • Funding Sources
    • Individual Donations: 21.7%
    • Membership Fees/Dues: 17.7%
    • Provincial/Territorial Transfers: 10.5%
  • Funding - Registered Charities vs. Other Non-Profits
    • Registered Charities - Individual Donations: 41.5%
    • Other Non-Profits - Individual Donations: 4.0%
    • Other Non-Profits - Membership Dues: 29.1%
    • Registered Charities - Membership Dues: 4.9%
  • Demand vs. Capacity

title: Health Reports, March 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

In 2019/2020, 43.4% of Canadian adults aged 65+ visited medical specialists, 23.2% got non-emergency tests, and 10.4% had non-emergency surgeries. Women were less likely than men to visit specialists and get tests. Those with a regular medical doctor were more likely to access specialized services. Older Canadians with poor health utilized more services; for instance, 61.5% of men with poor health visited specialists. About 15.6% reported difficulties accessing services, with women experiencing more difficulties than men.

    • Men: 1.9 times more likely
    • Women: 1.8 times more likely
  • Poor physical and mental health (men)
    • Visited specialists: 61.5%
    • Got tests: 34.6%
  • Poor physical and mental health (women)
    • Visited specialists: 55.7%
    • Got tests: 37.9%
  • Difficulty accessing services
    • 15.6% (half-million)

title: Urban public transit, January 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

In January 2024, urban transit trips in Canada increased by 11.9% year-over-year to 127.1 million, representing 79.0% of January 2019's pre-pandemic levels. This indicates a slight decline from December 2023's recovery rate of 79.9%. Ridership growth from December to January was 3.8%, impacted by labor disputes. Operating revenue was 14.5% higher than January 2023, reaching $303.7 million, yet still $46.1 million less than in January 2019.

Facts

Urban transit passenger trips
  • +11.9% (+13.5 million trips) from January 2023
  • 79.0% of January 2019's level
  • -33.8 million trips compared to pre-pandemic January 2019
Ridership recovery rate
  • 79.9% in December 2023
  • 80% average over the last half of 2023
Month-over-month ridership change
  • +3.8% from December 2023
Labor disputes impact
  • Bus transit services for B.C. Transit affected
  • 48-hour work stoppage in Metro Vancouver
Operating revenue
  • +14.5% from January 2023
  • $303.7 million in January 2024
  • -$46.1 million from pre-pandemic January 2019
```

title: Dating violence against teens aged 15 to 17 in Canada, 2009 to 2022
summary:
```html

Summary

Self-reported data from 2018 indicates that 45% of Canadian teens aged 15 to 17 experienced dating violence, with emotional abuse at 45% being the most common. Physical violence was reported by 10%, and sexual violence by 7%. Police-reported data from 2009 to 2022 shows a 33% increase in dating violence since 2015, with 239 victims per 100,000 in this age group. Teen girls experience higher rates of police-reported dating violence, especially sexual violence, with 500 victims per 100,000 compared to 57 for boys.

Facts

  • Teens aged 15 to 17 experiencing dating violence
    • 45% (more than 4 in 10)
  • Emotional abuse among teens
    • 45% (most common form of violence)
  • Physical violence among teens
    • 10%
  • Sexual violence among teens
    • 7%
  • Police-reported dating violence victims per 100,000 (2009 to 2022)
    • 239
  • Decline in teen dating violence (2009 to 2014)
    • -22%
  • Increase in teen dating violence since 2015
    • 33% (+33%)
  • Police-reported dating violence for girls per 100,000 (2022)
    • 500
  • Police-reported dating violence for boys per 100,000 (2022)
    • 57
  • Police-reported sexual violence victims per 100,000 (2022)
    • 60
  • Sexual violence in dating among teens aged 15 to 17 compared to 18 to 24
    • Higher than 18 to 24 (43)
  • Sexual violence in dating among teens aged 15 to 17 compared to 25 and older
    • Higher than 25 and older (9)
  • Police-reported sexual violence for teen girls per 100,000 (2022)
    • 116
  • Police-reported sexual violence for teen boys per 100,000 (2022)
    • 5
```
quotes: ""More than 4 in 10 teens aged 15 to 17 experienced dating violence since they turned 15" ' "Emotional abuse was the most common form of violence (45%)" ' "rates of teen dating violence for this age group have increased 33% since 2015" ' "the rate of police-reported dating violence was about nine times higher for teenage girls (500 victims per 100,000 population) than boys (57)" ' "Teens aged 15 to 17 who were victimized by a dating partner had higher police-reported rates (60 victims per 100,000 population) of sexual violence than for other violent offences in 2022""

Summary

Equifax Canada reports a 14.3% increase in business credit delinquencies between Q4 2023 and Q4 2022. Instalment loan delinquencies rose significantly, with early-stage delinquencies up 12.5% and late-stage delinquencies up 16.3%. Business credit card and line-of-credit delinquencies increased by 1.3%. Additionally, business insolvencies surged by 41.4% in 2023. title: Cleanup for pollution from Teck coal mines will top $6.4-billion, assessment claims
summary:
```html

Summary

A new report suggests the cost to address selenium contamination from Teck Resources' Elk Valley coal mines could reach $6.4 billion, far above the $1.9 billion security bond held by the B.C. government. The estimate accounts for building and operating water treatment plants for 60 years. Wildsight, the report's publisher, fears taxpayers may bear the excess cost. Teck disputes the figures, claiming full compliance with provincial requirements. The issue has escalated to the International Joint Commission due to transboundary water concerns. Teck's recent sale of its coal operations adds to the uncertainty of addressing the pollution.

Facts

  • Estimated cost to tackle selenium contamination
    • $6.4-billion
  • Current security bond by the B.C. government
    • $1.9-billion
  • Percentage decrease in Teck Resources Ltd. stock
    • -1.51% decrease
  • Amount Teck has spent on water quality improvements
    • $1.4-billion
  • Additional investment by Teck by end of the year
    • $250-million
  • Percentage of mining liabilities covered by securities in B.C.
    • 90% (current)
    • 40% (before NDP took office)
```
quotes: "The resulting estimates raise concerns that B.C. taxpayers could be stuck with a hefty cleanup bill, said Simon Wiebe, mining policy and impacts researcher at Wildsight, which released the report on Tuesday"

title: Searching for vulnerabilities
summary:
```html

Summary

Household credit growth is at its lowest since the 1980s, with real growth barely above zero and consumer credit in negative territory. Insolvencies have risen by over 20%, but are mostly debt restructuring proposals rather than bankruptcies. Delinquency rates are up, but early-stage delinquencies are declining. Half of all mortgages, over one trillion dollars' worth, are yet to reprice, with an estimated average interest payment shock of 15% per year from 2024 to 2026. Renters show signs of stress with rising delinquency rates, holding 60% of non-mortgage debt and 85% of serious delinquencies.

Facts

  • Real growth in total outstanding credit
    • 0% (barely above zero)
  • Consumer insolvencies
    • +20% (year-over-year increase)
  • Debt restructuring proposals
    • 80% (of insolvencies)
  • Growth rate in credit limits
    • -50% (from mid-2022 pace)
  • Utilization rate of credit
    • Falling (recent months)
  • Delinquency rates
    • Increased (30-60 day category)
    • Declining (share moving to 60-90 day category)
  • Mortgages repriced
    • 50% (of all mortgages)
    • $1 trillion (worth yet to be renewed)
  • Average interest payment shock
    • 15% (per year, 2024-26)
  • Delinquency rates among subprime borrowers
    • Increased (to 2019 levels)
  • Delinquency rates on lines and credit cards among homeowners
    • Above 2019 levels
  • Non-mortgage debt held by renters
    • 60% (of total non-mortgage debt outstanding)
    • 85% (of serious delinquencies)
  • Delinquency rates for renters
    • Rising (both 30-day and 90+ day rates surpass 2019 levels)
```
quotes: "...the year-over-year growth rate in credit limitsavailable to households is now rising by half the pace seen inmid-2022 and below the pre-pandemic rate. In real terms limitsare hardly growing. At the same time, households are less eagerto use that available credit, with the utilization rate falling inrecent months" - "As it stands now, we estimate that 50% of all mortgagesoutstanding have already repriced to reflect tighter monetaryconditions."

title: Nursing and residential care facilities, 2022
summary:
Summary

Private and public nursing and residential care facilities' operating revenues increased by 4.2% to $39.1 billion in 2022. Public facilities' revenue grew by 3.8% to $21.6 billion, with Quebec leading contributions. Operating expenses for public facilities rose by 4.9% to $22.3 billion, resulting in a $767.5 million deficit. Private facilities saw a 4.7% revenue increase to $17.5 billion, with Ontario contributing the most. Their operating expenses increased by 5.8% to $16.1 billion, and profit margins dropped to 7.8%.

Facts

title: Households and the Environment Survey: Energy use, 2021
summary:
```html

Summary

In 2021, Canadian households consumed 1.3 million terajoules of energy, with an average of 85.4 gigajoules per household, a decrease from 90.5 gigajoules in 2019. Natural gas usage decreased by 1.9% to 51.5%, while electricity usage increased by 1.9% to 45.8%. Heating oil remained at 2.7%. Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba, and Ontario had higher-than-average energy consumption, while other provinces were below the national average.

Facts

  • Average household energy consumption
    • -5.6% (90.5 to 85.4 gigajoules)
  • Natural gas
    • -1.9% (from 53.4% to 51.5%)
  • Electricity
    • +1.9% (from 43.9% to 45.8%)
  • Heating oil
    • 0% (remained at 2.7%)
  • Provinces above national average
    • Alberta (121.8 gigajoules)
    • Saskatchewan (101.3 gigajoules)
    • Manitoba (91.9 gigajoules)
    • Ontario (89.3 gigajoules)
```
quotes: ["'Canadian households consumed 1.3 million terajoules of energy in their homes in 2021", 'On average, the amount of energy consumed per household was 85.4 gigajoules in 2021, down from 90.5 gigajoules in 2019', 'Of the total energy consumed in Canadian homes in 2021, natural gas accounted for 51.5%, down 1.9% from 2019; electricity for 45.8%, up 1.9% from 2019; and heating oil for 2.7%, the same as in 2019', "Households in Alberta (121.8 gigajoules), Saskatchewan (101.3 gigajoules), Manitoba (91.9 gigajoules) and Ontario (89.3 gigajoules) reported higher-than-average energy consumption per household compared to the national average'"]

title: Job vacancies, fourth quarter 2023
summary:
```html

Summary

Job vacancies in Canada decreased by 25,400 (-3.6%) to 678,500 in Q4 2023, continuing a downward trend from Q2 2022's high of 983,600. Payroll employment increased slightly by 37,700 (+0.2%). The job vacancy rate fell to 3.8%, the lowest since Q1 2021. Sales and service occupations saw the largest year-over-year decline in vacancies (-93,800; -31.5%). Health occupations vacancies decreased by 3,400 (-3.6%) year-over-year. The average offered hourly wage for vacant positions rose by 6.4% to $26.50. Job vacancies requiring a high school diploma or less experienced the largest decline (-31.1%; -154,600).

Facts

title: Consumer Price Index, February 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

The CPI increased by 2.8% year-over-year in February, a slight decrease from January's 2.9%. Cellular services and Internet access saw significant price drops, while gasoline prices rose by 0.8% after a previous decline. Excluding gasoline, CPI growth slowed to 2.9%. Monthly, the CPI rose by 0.3%, with travel tours and gasoline as main contributors. Grocery price inflation eased with a 2.4% rise, notably slower than the previous month. Regionally, prices rose more slowly in seven provinces, with Alberta experiencing an increase due to higher natural gas prices.

Facts

Consumer Price Index (CPI) - 2.8% (Year-over-year change for February) - 2.9% (Year-over-year change for January) - 0.3% (Monthly change for February) - 0.0% (Monthly change for January) - 0.1% (Seasonally adjusted monthly change for February) Cellular services - -26.5% (Year-over-year change for February) - -16.4% (Year-over-year change for January) Internet access services - -13.2% (Year-over-year change for February) - -9.4% (Monthly change for February) Food purchased from stores - +2.4% (Year-over-year change for February) - +3.4% (Year-over-year change for January) - +21.6% (Change from February 2021 to February 2024) Gasoline prices - +0.8% (Year-over-year change for February) - -4.0% (Year-over-year change for January) - +4.0% (Monthly change for February) Travel tours - +4.8% (Year-over-year change for February) - +3.3% (Year-over-year change for January) Regional CPI changes - Alberta: +15.1% (Natural gas prices year-over-year change for February) - Alberta: -18.7% (Natural gas prices year-over-year change for January) ```
quotes: ["'Canadians pay less for cellular services and Internet access services", 'Grocery inflation continues to ease', 'Prices for gasoline increase', 'Consumers pay more for travel tours in February', "Regional highlights'"]

title: Product of U.S. meat label could disrupt cross-border trade
summary:
```html

Summary

The U.S. Department of Agriculture's new voluntary labeling rules for "Product of USA" or "Made in the USA" are set to disrupt the integrated meat and livestock supply chains between Canada and the U.S. These labels will only apply to products from animals born, raised, slaughtered, and processed in the U.S. starting in 2026. Canadian officials express concern over potential trade disruptions and are reviewing the rule's compliance with international trade obligations. The Canadian meat industry, which has traded over $11.3 billion in exports to and imported nearly $4.9 billion from the U.S. since 2022, advocates for reduced trade barriers.

Facts

  • Labeling Rule Implementation Year
    • 2026
  • Canadian Exports to the U.S. (since 2022)
    • $11.3 billion
  • Canadian Imports from the U.S. (since 2022)
    • $4.9 billion
```
quotes: "Canada remains concerned about any measures that may cause disruptions to the highly integrated North American meat and livestock supply chains."

title: Newfoundland, eager to shed dependency on expensive travel nurses, launches program for rural communities
summary:
```html

Summary

Mark Aylward, a nurse practitioner from Newfoundland and Labrador, participated in a pilot project aimed at reducing reliance on costly out-of-province travel nurses. The government spent $35.6 million on for-profit agency nurses in five months, a significant increase from the pre-pandemic $1 million annual average. The new program offers unionized nurses higher wages to work in rural areas, saving money compared to agency rates. Over 100 nurses have joined since September 2022, with the project extended to January 2025. Alberta has a similar program, paying an extra $25 per hour to fill staffing gaps.

Facts

  • Government spending on travel nurses
    • 3,460% ($34.6 million from $1 million)
  • Hourly rate for agency nurses (Canadian Health Labs)
    • $312
  • Hourly rate for unionized hospital registered nurses
    • $37.86 to $47.16
  • Hourly rate for nurses under the pilot project
    • $25 extra
  • Other staffing agency rates
    • $120 to $159.50
  • CHL's continued rate for supplying nurses
    • $172.22
  • Payment to nurses working for CHL
    • $85 to $100
  • Duration of the pilot project
    • Extended to January 2025
  • Number of nurses participating in the pilot project
    • Over 100
```
quotes: "The government of Newfoundland and Labrador spent $35.6-million on nurses from for-profit agencies in just five months last year, up from an average of about $1-million a year before the pandemic" - "he Globe reported last month that health authorities in one region of Newfoundland were paying a Toronto-based company, Canadian Health Labs, as much as $312 an hour for each nurse. "

title: Port Metro Vancouver and Ottawa assessing whether Chinese-built port cranes pose security risk: B.C. Premier
summary:
```html

Summary

B.C. Premier David Eby has expressed concern over potential national security risks posed by cargo cranes in Canadian ports, following a U.S. investigation into Shanghai Zhenhua Heavy Industries Co. Ltd. (ZPMC). The U.S. found hidden modems in cranes that could be exploited by China. ZPMC cranes, which constitute about 80% of those in American ports, are under scrutiny. Canadian agencies have been contacted for comment, but no official probe has been confirmed. ZPMC denies cybersecurity risks, while Canadian companies using ZPMC cranes assert their own security measures.

Facts

  • Canadian ports with ZPMC cranes
    • Vancouver
    • Prince Rupert
    • Halifax
    • Montreal
  • Canadian agencies contacted
    • Public Safety Canada
    • Canadian Security Intelligence Service
    • Canadian Border Services Agency
    • Transport Canada (oversees ports)
  • ZPMC's response to allegations
    • Denies cybersecurity risks
    • Claims adherence to laws and regulations
  • Canadian companies' security measures
    • GCT uses ZPMC cranes without ZPMC's software
    • Opt for Swedish and North American technology providers
```
quotes: "Shanghai Zhenhua Heavy Industries Co. Ltd. (ZPMC), which made about 80 per cent of the ship-to-shore cranes operating across American ports, had installed the communications devices that “do not contribute to the operation” of the cranes." - "Hicham Ayoun, senior spokesperson for Transport Canada, declined to say whether the country has launched its own probe into potential risks posed by these cranes." - "Christian Leuprecht, a political science professor at the Royal Military College and Queen’s University, said the federal government once again appears to be reactive rather than proactive on a matter of potential national security" - "“This is the same problem as with the Huawei routers: They may not pose a risk today – everybody says, ‘We haven’t found any malware’ – the problem is you can install that malware overnight,” Dr. Leuprecht said"

title: Ottawa’s EV mandate unrealistically requires the equivalent of 10 new mega hydro dams or 13 large natural gas plants nationwide within 11 years
summary:
```html

Summary

Canadian EV sales grew from less than 1% in 2017 to 9.1% in Q4 2022, with higher rates in British Columbia (18%) and Quebec (14%). EV adoption could increase Canada's electricity load by 7.5% to 15.3%, requiring significant new generating capacity. Projections suggest the need for up to 13 new 500-MW gas plants or 10 new 1,000-MW hydroelectric facilities. Alternatively, nearly 5,000 wind turbines could be built, but would require backup from gas plants, hydropower, or batteries, potentially necessitating subsidies. Immediate development of infrastructure is crucial to meet EV demand.

Facts

  • EV market share
    • 2017: <1%
    • 2022 Q4: 9.1%
  • Regional EV market share (2022 Q4)
    • British Columbia: 18%
    • Quebec: 14%
  • Projected electricity load increase
    • Minimum: 7.5%
    • Maximum: 15.3%
  • Provincial load increase
    • Quebec: 4.6%
    • Ontario: 26.2%
  • Annual load increase (TWh)
    • Canada: 46.8 - 95.1 TWh
    • British Columbia: 4.4 - 9.3 TWh
    • Ontario: 19.0 - 38.2 TWh
    • Quebec: 10 - 21.7 TWh
  • New generating capacity requirements
    • Gas plants (500-MW): up to 13
    • Hydroelectric facilities (1,000-MW): up to 10
    • Wind turbines (3.5 MW): nearly 5,000
  • Backup capacity
    • Requirement: Subsidized backup from gas, hydro, or batteries
```
quotes: "Our results indicate that EVs couldpose a significant burden on Canadian electricity grids, with systemdemand (also known as load)increasing by as little as 7.5% to asmuch as 15.3%" - "We project that as manyas 13 new gas plants of 500-MW capacity might be required in Canada" - "Unless society begins almost immediately to develop the required generating infrastructure, it will not be possible to meet the expected demand that EVs might pose for electricity grids in Canada."

The rise was largely due to a 5.2% increase in energy and petroleum products, influenced by higher conventional crude oil prices and reduced refinery output. Meanwhile, the Raw Materials Price Index (RMPI) went up by 2.1% from the previous month, led by a 5.7% rise in crude energy products, but fell 4.7% compared to the previous year, with significant declines in nickel ores and concentrates and canola.

Summary

In 2020, Canadian plastic production for consumption slightly increased by 0.8% to 7,121 kilotonnes, with packaging and construction materials leading the rise. However, plastic waste disposal decreased by 2.7% to 4,928 kilotonnes, and material recovery dropped by 8.8%. Domestically produced plastic grew by 5.9%, while net trade decreased by 6.9%. title: Industrial Water Survey, 2021
summary:
```html

Summary

Canada's industrial water intake was 27.4 billion cubic metres in 2021, a slight increase of 0.42% from 2020. Thermal-electric power producers were the largest users, accounting for 83.7% of intake and 84.7% of discharge. Manufacturing followed with 14.8% of intake and 13.2% of discharge, while mining contributed to 1.5% and 2.1% respectively. The majority of water, 83.7%, was sourced from self-supplied surface water. Water recirculation decreased by 15.9% to 13.3 billion cubic metres. No significant changes in intake, recirculation, or discharge volumes were observed in manufacturing and thermal-electric power industries over the past decade, but mining has seen a gradual decrease since 2017.

Facts

    • 0.42% (27.4 billion cubic metres)

    • 83.7%
  • Manufacturing industries' share of water intake
    • 14.8%

    • 1.5%

    • 83.7%

In 2023, five years post-legalization, 38.4% of Canadians aged 18-24 and 34.5% aged 25-44 used cannabis, compared to 15.5% over 45. summary:
```html

Summary

The Federal Reserve is expected to maintain the current federal funds rate, with markets predicting a 75 basis point cut to 4.5-4.75% this year. Inflation remains above target, with recent data showing unexpected increases. The Fed's projections on rate cuts, GDP growth, unemployment, and inflation will be scrutinized. Canadian inflation is also in focus, with February's CPI anticipated at 3.1% year-over-year. Retail sales in Canada are predicted to decline by 0.4% in January. Various reports from RBC Economics discuss the economic outlook, housing market, inflation, and consumer spending.

Facts

  • Federal Reserve interest rate cuts
    • -75 basis points (from 125 bps expected)
    • to 4.5-4.75%
  • U.S. inflation
    • Two months of upside surprises
  • Canada inflation (February)
    • 3.1% year-over-year
    • Up from 2.9% in January
  • Canada gasoline prices
    • +4% in February (from the previous month)
  • Retail sales in Canada (January)
    • -0.4%
    • Volume -0.3%
```
quotes: ["'Markets continue to expect the first interest rate cut in June in line with our expectations", 'But we now anticipate the Fed will be moving at a slower pace and cut rates by 75 basis points (instead of the 125 bps previously expected) this year to 4.5-4.75%', 'Recent comments from Fed officials have suggested they’re still committed to moving rates lower this year despite the setback in inflation', 'Both headline and core (ex-food and energy) inflation are expected to come in at 3.1% year-over-year with headline up from 2.9% in January on higher energy inflation', 'Gasoline prices rose by nearly 4% in February from a month ago', "Still, a very soft economic backdrop means that price pressures in Canada are more likely to keep easing and narrowing, allowing for a first rate cut from the BoC to also come in June'"]

Summary

Foreign investment in Canadian securities was $8.9 billion in January, with a focus on government debt securities, which saw an inflow of $21.3 billion. Conversely, Canadian investors divested $7.6 billion in foreign securities, with a notable $14.8 billion sell-off in foreign equities. title: Tracking Canada's evolving supply chain links and their effects: Knowns and unknowns
summary:
```html

Summary

Canada's integration into global supply chains has led to 10% higher labour productivity and 6% higher wages in manufacturing firms involved in global value chains. However, 25% of Canada's economic output faces risks from external demand and supply shocks. Import prices contributed to half of the consumer inflation in the latter three quarters of 2022. Canada's imports from the US decreased from 62% to 49% between 2002 and 2022, while imports from China increased from 5% to 14%. Input requirements from abroad increased from 19% in 2007 to 23% in 2019.

Facts

  • Labor Productivity
    • +10% (higher in manufacturing firms in global value chains)
  • Wages
    • +6% (higher in manufacturing firms in global value chains)
  • Economic Output at Risk
    • 25% (exposed to external shocks)
  • Consumer Inflation from Imports
    • 50% (contribution to inflation in last three quarters of 2022)
  • Imports from the United States
    • -13% (from 62% to 49% between 2002 and 2022)
  • Imports from China
    • +9% (from 5% to 14% between 2002 and 2022)
  • Input Requirements Sourced from Abroad
    • +4% (from 19% in 2007 to 23% in 2019)
```
quotes: ["'Research to Insights: Tracking Canada's Evolving Supply Chain Links and their Effects", 'Manufacturing firms that participate in global value chains have, on average, 10% higher labour productivity and 6% higher wages than those that do not', "Canadian industries accounting for 25% of the country's economic output are exposed to potential external demand and supply shocks", 'Rising import prices accounted for about half of consumer inflation at its peak in the last three quarters of 2022', "From 2002 to 2022, Canada's imports shifted away from the United States, whose import share declined from 62% to 49%", "China's import share rose from 5% to 14% over the same period", 'The share of input requirements sourced from abroad rose from 19% in 2007 to 23% in 2019', "These smaller firms, which have less capacity to absorb import supply chain shocks, had on average fewer than two suppliers for each imported intermediate product'"]

title: Monthly Survey of Manufacturing, January 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

Manufacturing sales increased slightly by 0.2% to $71.1 billion in January, with transportation equipment and chemical subsectors leading the growth. Motor vehicle sales surged by 19.6% to $5.3 billion, marking a recovery after a period of retooling. Chemical product sales also rose by 3.5% to $5.6 billion. However, aerospace products saw a significant decline of 16.7% to $2.1 billion. Ontario's sales grew by 3.8%, while Quebec experienced a 4.2% decrease. Inventories fell by 0.2% to $122.1 billion, and unfilled orders decreased by 1.3% to $104.2 billion. The capacity utilization rate improved to 77.1%.

title: Fewer charitable donors, less money donated in 2022
summary:
```html

Summary

In 2022, 17.1% of Canadian tax filers reported charitable donations, a slight decrease from the previous year, with total donations falling by 3.1% to $11.4 billion. Median donations increased by 5.6% to $380. Donations of $100,000 or more saw a 12.4% decline in the number of donors and a 13.4% decrease in total amount donated. Higher-income filers contributed 59.1% of total donations, with those earning $1 million or more reporting the highest median donation at $5,150. Seniors were the most charitable, with those aged 65 or older contributing $48 for every $100 donated. Men were more likely to donate than women, contributing 63.4% of total donations. British Columbia and Ontario led the decrease in donations, while Manitoba remained the most charitable province.

Facts

  • Number of tax filers declaring charitable donations
    • -0.3% (decrease from previous year)
  • Total amount donated
    • -3.1% ($11.4 billion)
  • Median donation
    • +5.6% ($380)
  • Donations of $100,000 or more
    • -12.4% (number of donors)
    • -13.4% (total amount donated)
  • Share of total donations from high-income filers
    • +0.9 percentage points (59.1% of total donations)
  • Median income of charitable donors
    • $71,240
  • Median donation by income
    • $1 million or more: -5.2% ($5,150)
    • $500,000 to $999,999: +1.0% ($1,930)
  • Charitable donations by age
    • 65 or older: 23.9% (of tax filers)
    • Median donation by seniors: $590
  • Charitable donations by gender
    • Men: 18.1% (of tax filers)
    • Women: 16.2% (of tax filers)
    • Men's median donation: +2.5% ($410)
    • Women's median donation: +6.1% ($350)
  • Charitable donations by province
    • British Columbia: -11.8%
    • Ontario: -6.0%
    • Newfoundland and Labrador: -13.2%
    • Manitoba: 19.3% (of tax filers)
    • Manitoba's median donation: +7.3% ($590)
    • Nunavut's median donation: $900
  • Charitable donations by urban centre

```

In 2023, Canada saw a 12.7% increase in new motor vehicle sales, totaling 1,755,741 units. This rise is attributed to the recovery from the global semiconductor shortage. Despite this growth, sales were still 11.3% lower than pre-pandemic levels in 2019. Passenger car sales fell by 7.0%, while sales of heavy trucks, buses, and light trucks increased by 12.4%, 16.1%, and 17.0% respectively. title: Participation in regular French programs in Canada outside Quebec, 2021: Maps, key facts and data table
summary:
```html

Summary

In 2021, 64.7% of eligible children aged 5 to 17 outside Quebec participated in regular French programs. This varied by region, age, education level, and eligibility under section 23 of the Charter. At least one municipality per province and the Northwest Territories had over 80% of eligible children attending French-language schools. However, only 35.5% of eligible youth aged 12 to 17 attended French-language secondary schools. Additionally, 60.4% of children with a French-speaking parent attended French-language schools, versus 40.9% with parents who did not have French as a mother tongue but attended French-language schools themselves.

Facts

  • Overall participation in French programs
    • 64.7% (452,000 children)
  • Participation by municipality
    • ≥80% (at least one municipality per province/territory)
    • <50% (at least one municipality per province/territory, except Nunavut)
  • French-language elementary school attendance (youth aged 12 to 17)
    • 65.3%
  • French-language secondary school attendance (youth aged 12 to 17)
    • 35.5%
  • French-language school attendance (children aged 5 to 11)
    • 62.7%
  • Attendance with French-speaking parent
    • 60.4%
  • Attendance with parent who attended French-language school
    • 40.9%
```
quotes: ['"Maps and key facts on participation in regular French programs in Canada outside Quebec, 2021," \'In at least one municipality in each province in Canada outside Quebec, four in five eligible children have attended a French-language school', 'In Canada outside Quebec, just over one-third of youth aged 12 to 17 years who are eligible for instruction in French have attended a French-language secondary school', "In Canada outside Quebec, three in five school-aged children with at least one parent whose mother tongue is French have attended a French-language school'"]

title: Police-reported hate crime, 2022
summary:
```html

Summary

Hate crimes in Canada increased by 7% in 2022, with a cumulative rise of 83% since 2019. The majority of the increase was due to crimes targeting race or ethnicity (+12%) and sexual orientation (+12%). Violent hate crimes rose by 12%, while non-violent crimes increased by 3%. Hate crimes against religion decreased by 15%, yet remained above the numbers from 2018 to 2020. Ontario, Nova Scotia, and British Columbia had the highest rates of hate crime. Victims were predominantly men and boys, except in crimes targeting sex or gender. Less than one-third of hate crimes were cleared in 2022.

Facts

  • Hate crimes reported
    • +7% (from 3,355 to 3,576 incidents)
  • Cumulative increase from 2019 to 2022
    • +83%
  • Crimes targeting race or ethnicity
    • +12% (to 1,950 incidents)
  • Crimes targeting sexual orientation
    • +12% (to 491 incidents)
  • Crimes targeting religion
    • -15% (from 886 to 750 incidents)
  • Rate of police-reported hate crime per 100,000 population
    • +5% (to 9.2 incidents)
  • Overall crime rate change in 2022
    • +5%
  • Highest hate crime rates by province (per 100,000)
    • Ontario: 12.7
    • Nova Scotia: 11.1
    • British Columbia: 10.2
  • Violent hate crimes increase
    • +12%
  • Non-violent hate crimes increase
    • +3%
  • Hate-related homicide increase
    • +53% (from 15 to 23 victims)
  • Clearance rate for hate crimes
    • 29%

    • 34%
  • Cyber hate crimes increase from 2018 to 2022
    • +138% (from 92 to 219 incidents)
```

title: Crushing statistics of major oilseeds, Canada and United States, 2023
summary:
```html

Summary

Canadian oilseed processors crushed a record 10,522,947 tonnes of canola in 2023, a 20.0% increase from 2022. Soybean crushing, however, decreased by 5.7%. Canola oil production was 4,422,368 tonnes and soybean oil was 329,856 tonnes. Canola meal production reached 6,200,229 tonnes and soybean meal was 1,371,250 tonnes. High canola prices and exports, which rose by 20.3% to 3,149,904 tonnes, drove the increase in canola crushing. Canola production was up by 31.2% from the previous year. In the US, soybean and canola crushing increased by 2.6% and 19.2%, respectively.

Facts

  • Canadian canola crushing
    • +20.0% (10,522,947 tonnes)
  • Canadian soybean crushing
    • -5.7% (1,762,693 tonnes)
  • Canadian canola oil production
    • 4,422,368 tonnes
  • Canadian soybean oil production
    • 329,856 tonnes
  • Canadian canola meal production
    • 6,200,229 tonnes

title: Canada's international investment position, fourth quarter 2023
summary:
Summary

Canada's net foreign asset position reached a new high of $1,677.3 billion at the end of 2023, with a $288.2 billion increase in the fourth quarter alone. This growth was driven by global equity market strength, with a $317.1 billion increase due to market prices. The Canadian dollar's fluctuations against other major currencies had a moderating effect. International financial assets rose by $613.1 billion to $9,037.6 billion, while international liabilities increased by $324.9 billion to $7,360.3 billion. Canada's gross external debt also grew, reaching $4,150.3 billion, or 140.6% of GDP. Throughout 2023, the net foreign asset position grew by $584.2 billion.

Facts

  • Net foreign asset position
    • +20.7% ($288.2 billion)
  • International assets
    • +7.3% ($613.1 billion)
  • International liabilities
    • +4.6% ($324.9 billion)
  • Gross external debt
    • +5.4% ($212.9 billion)
  • US stock market growth
    • +11.2%
  • European stock market growth
    • +8.3%
  • Canadian stock market growth
    • +7.3%
  • Canadian dollar against US dollar
    • +2.2%
  • Canadian dollar against euro
    • -2.2%
  • Canadian dollar against British pound
    • -1.9%
  • Canadian dollar against yen
    • -3.2%
  • Net foreign asset position with the United States
    • +15.2% ($172.7 billion)
  • Net foreign asset position with the rest of the world
    • +45.1% ($115.5 billion)
  • Annual increase in net foreign asset position (2023)
    • +20.8% ($584.2 billion)
  • GDP percentage of net foreign asset position (end of 2023)
    • 56.8%
quotes: ["'Canada's net foreign asset position reached $1,677.3 billion at the end of 2023", 'The growth in the fourth quarter was fuelled by the strength of global equity markets', "Canada's international financial assets were up by $613.1 billion (+7.3%) to $9,037.6 billion at the end of the fourth quarter, the highest quarterly increase on record", "Canada's international liabilities were up $324.9 billion to $7,360.3 billion at the end of the fourth quarter, also the largest quarterly increase on record", "Canada's gross external debt increased by $212.9 billion (+5.4%) to reach $4,150.3 billion at the end of the fourth quarter", "Canada's net foreign asset position increased by $584.2 billion in 2023'"]

title: Police-reported online child sexual exploitation in Canada, 2022
summary:
```html

Summary

From 2014 to 2022, Canada saw a significant rise in police-reported online sexual offences against children and online child pornography, with the rate of online child pornography nearly quadrupling. The majority of accused were male, and non-consensual distribution of intimate images often involved youth victims victimized by peers. Police solved 41% of online sexual offences against children, and one-third of charges in adult criminal court resulted in a guilty finding, with 78% of those receiving a custodial sentence.

Facts

  • Overall rate of police-reported online child sexual exploitation
    • 2014: 50 incidents per 100,000 children and youth
    • 2022: 160 incidents per 100,000 children and youth
  • Rate of online child pornography reported to police
    • 2014: 32 incidents per 100,000 children and youth
    • 2022: 125 incidents per 100,000 children and youth
  • Percentage of online child pornography offences
    • 75% of all online child sexual exploitation offences
  • Percentage of making or distributing child pornography offences
    • 72% of child pornography incidents from 2014 to 2022
  • Percentage of male accused in online sexual offences against children
    • Invitation to sexual touching: 97%
    • Luring a child: 96%
    • Possessing or accessing child pornography: 90%
  • Percentage of youth victims in non-consensual distribution of intimate images
    • 97% aged 12 to 17 years
  • Percentage of girls as victims in non-consensual distribution of intimate images
    • 86%
  • Percentage of accused-victim relationship in non-consensual distribution of intimate images
    • Casual acquaintances: 33%
    • Current or former dating partners: 28%
    • Friends: 21%
    • Strangers: 14%
  • Percentage of incidents of police-reported online sexual offences against children cleared
    • 41%
  • Percentage of cleared incidents resulting in a charge
    • 74%
  • Clearance rates for online sexual offences against children vs. child pornography offences
    • Online sexual offences against children: 37%
    • Child pornography offences: 22%
  • Percentage of charges in adult criminal court resulting in a guilty finding
    • 34%
  • Percentage of guilty cases in adult court leading to a custodial sentence
    • 78%
  • Percentage of charges in youth court leading to a guilty finding
    • 44%
  • Percentage of youth sentenced to probation
    • 62%
```
quotes: ["'The overall rate of police-reported online child sexual exploitation incidents—which includes both online sexual offences against children and online child pornography—has risen since 2014", 'boys and men accounted for the vast majority of accused persons in incidents of online sexual offences against children from 2014 to 2022', 'Youth aged 12 to 17 years accounted for almost all (97%) victims', 'from 2014 to 2022, 41% of incidents of police-reported online sexual offences against children were cleared (that is, solved) by police', "around one-third (34%) of charges laid for sexual offences against children likely committed online resulted in a guilty finding'"]

title: New motor vehicle registrations, fourth quarter 2023
summary:
```html

Summary

In 2023, Canada saw a 13.4% increase in new motor vehicle registrations, totaling 1,714,356. Ontario, Quebec, and British Columbia led the count. Multipurpose vehicles dominated with a 20.8% increase, comprising 59.7% of registrations. Pickup trucks followed with a 6.5% rise. Vans rebounded with a 28.1% increase, while passenger cars declined by 3.8%. ZEVs hit a milestone, making up 10.8% of registrations, a 49.4% jump from 2022. Gasoline-powered vehicles decreased to 77.0% of registrations, while hybrids rose to 7.9%.

title: Engineering services industry, 2022
summary:
```html

Summary

Engineering services industry operating revenue grew by 12.1% to $39.5 billion in 2022, with investment in oil and gas extraction up by 41.9%. Operating expenses rose by 14.0% to $37.0 billion, reducing the operating profit margin to 6.4%. Salaries and benefits accounted for 45.7% of expenses. Sales related to petroleum and petrochemical projects increased to 16.7% of total sales. Business sector clients constituted 61.6% of sales, while public institutions made up 22.6%. Foreign sales accounted for 8.8%, with the majority in the United States (51.3%).

Facts

  • Operating expenses

    • 45.7% ($16.9 billion)

    • 21.2% (of total expenses)
  • Sales from petroleum/petrochemical projects
    • +0.8% (16.7% up from 15.9%)

    • 61.6% (of sales)
  • Sales to governments and public institutions

      • 51.3% (of foreign sales)
    • Other countries

title: Research and development personnel, 2021
summary:
```html

Summary

In 2021, Canada's full-time equivalent (FTE) R&D personnel increased by 5.8% to 298,850 FTEs, marking the fifth consecutive year of growth. This aligns with a 9.3% increase in gross domestic R&D spending, reaching $46.9 billion. The business enterprise and higher education sectors contributed 95.4% of the personnel growth. Researchers accounted for 69.4% of R&D personnel and saw a 5.8% increase in positions. Ontario and Quebec drove 80% of the FTE increase. Despite growth, Canada's R&D personnel per thousand employment ratio dropped to 15.7, still above the OECD average.

Facts

title: Principal field crop areas, 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

Canadian farmers are projected to plant more wheat, corn for grain, oats, lentils, and dry peas in 2024, while seeding less canola, soybeans, and barley. Wheat acreage is expected to edge up slightly by 0.1% to 27.0 million acres, with an increase in durum wheat but decreases in spring and winter wheat. Canola is set to decrease by 3.1% to 21.4 million acres. Soybean acreage will drop by 0.9% to 5.6 million acres. Barley will decline by 2.5% to 7.1 million acres, while oats will surge by 21.6% to 3.1 million acres. Corn for grain is expected to rise by 1.6% to 3.9 million acres. Lentils will increase by 4.4% to 3.8 million acres, and dry peas will go up by 2.4% to 3.1 million acres.

Facts

  • Wheat
    • +0.1% (27.0 million acres)
    • Spring wheat: -1.2% (19.2 million acres)
    • Winter wheat: -3.6% (1.5 million acres)
    • Durum wheat: +5.1% (6.3 million acres)
  • Canola
    • -3.1% (21.4 million acres)
  • Soybeans
    • -0.9% (5.6 million acres)
  • Barley
    • -2.5% (7.1 million acres)
  • Oats
    • +21.6% (3.1 million acres)
  • Corn for grain
    • +1.6% (3.9 million acres)

    • +4.4% (3.8 million acres)
  • Dry peas
    • +2.4% (3.1 million acres)
```

title: Leading indicator of international arrivals to Canada, February 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

In February 2024, international arrivals to Canada increased by 18.6% from the previous year. Non-resident air arrivals rose by 23.0%, surpassing pre-pandemic levels for the first time since COVID-19 began. Canadian residents returning from abroad by air increased by 15.8%, while US residents traveling to Canada by automobile went up by 18.8%. Canadian-resident return trips by automobile also saw a 20.7% rise. The busiest days coincided with US Presidents' Day and Canadian Family Day holidays.

Facts

  • International arrivals to Canada
    • 18.6% (Increase from February 2023)
  • Non-resident arrivals by air
    • 23.0% (519,500 total)
    • US residents: 84.3% (14,300 on Presidents' Day holiday)
    • Other countries: 2.9% (Higher than pre-pandemic level)
  • Canadian-resident return trips by air
    • 15.8% (1.8 million total)
    • 20.2% (Higher in the second half of February)
    • 5.2% (Higher than pre-pandemic level excluding Toronto Pearson International Airport Terminal 1)
  • US-resident trips to Canada by automobile
    • 18.8% (735,100 total)
    • 92.8% (Of February 2020 level)
  • Canadian-resident return trips by automobile
    • 20.7% (1.5 million total)
    • 138.0% (Higher on Family Day)
    • 89.9% (Of February 2020 level)
```
quotes: ['"In February, the preliminary number of international arrivals to Canada by air and automobile increased 18.6% from February 2023" - "In February, for the first time since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, the number of non-resident arrivals by air surpassed the pre-pandemic level, in February 2020" - "By automobile, US residents took 735,100 trips to Canada in February 2024, up 18.8% from the same month in 2023" - "When data from Toronto Pearson International Airport Terminal 1 are excluded from the total arrivals, non-resident arrivals in February were higher (+2.9%) than the pre-pandemic level observed in February 2020, a first since the start of the pandemic" - "When arrivals at Toronto Pearson International Airport Terminal 1 are excluded from the total arrivals, the number of return trips in February was 5.2% higher than the pre-pandemic level observed in February 2020" - "February 19, Family Day in most provinces, marked the peak of arrivals (118,500), exceeding the daily average of the remainder of the month (49,800) by 138.0%"']

title: Study: The duration of first unions: A comparative analysis between landed immigrants and Canadian-born individuals
summary:
```html

Summary

A study based on the 2017 General Social Survey – Family reveals that landed immigrant women in Canada have a lower risk of first union dissolution compared to Canadian-born women. The analysis considers sociodemographic factors affecting union stability, including type of union, presence of children, age at union start, and education level. While some factors like union type and children have a consistent impact across groups, others such as age and education level show varying effects based on sex and immigration status.

Facts

  • Landed Immigrant Status
    • Lower risk of first union dissolution for immigrant women compared to Canadian-born
  • Type of Union
    • Consistent impact on first union dissolution risk across groups
  • Presence of Children
    • Consistent impact on first union dissolution risk across groups
  • Age at Start of Union
    • Varying impact on first union dissolution risk based on sex and immigration status
  • Highest Level of Education Attained
    • Varying impact on first union dissolution risk based on sex and immigration status
```
quotes: ['"The family institution has undergone important transformations in recent decades" - "landed immigrant women were less likely than Canadian-born women to experience the dissolution of their first union" - "the effect of other sociodemographic characteristics, such as age at the start of the union and the highest level of education attained, varies by sex and landed immigrant status"']

Summary

Employment in Canada increased by 41,000 (+0.2%) in February, with gains in full-time work (+71,000; +0.4%) and among core-aged women (+45,000; +0.7%) and men (+23,000; +0.3%). However, population growth outpaced employment growth, leading to a 0.1 percentage point drop in the employment rate to 61.5%. The unemployment rate rose slightly to 5.8%. Service industries saw employment growth, particularly in accommodation and food services (+26,000; +2.4%) and professional, scientific, and technical services (+18,000; +0.9%). Average hourly wages increased by 5.0% year-over-year to $34.82.

title: Industrial capacity utilization rates, fourth quarter 2023
summary:
```html

Summary

Canadian industries' capacity utilization slightly decreased to 78.7% in Q4 from 78.8% in Q3. Manufacturing saw a 0.7 percentage point drop, led by declines in petroleum, coal, and chemical manufacturing. Mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction rose by 1.3 percentage points, driven by oil sands extraction. Construction decreased by 0.7 percentage points due to reduced engineering activity despite growth in building construction.

Facts

  • Overall capacity utilization
    • -0.1% (78.8% to 78.7%)
  • Manufacturing sector capacity utilization
    • -0.7% (76.9% from previous)
  • Petroleum and coal product manufacturing
    • -4.7%
  • Chemical manufacturing
    • -2.6%
  • Mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction sector
    • +1.3% (76.3% from previous)
  • Construction sector capacity utilization
    • -0.7% (82.7% from previous)
```
quotes: ["'Canadian industries operated at 78.7% of their production capacity in the fourth quarter, down slightly from 78.8% in the third quarter.", 'The capacity utilization rate in the manufacturing sector fell 0.7 percentage points to 76.9% in the fourth quarter.', 'This decline was mainly due to a slowdown in petroleum and coal product manufacturing (-4.7 percentage points) and chemical manufacturing (-2.6 percentage points).', 'Capacity utilization in the mining, quarrying and oil and gas extraction sector continued its upward trend, with the rate rising 1.3 percentage points to 76.3% in the fourth quarter.', 'This increase coincided with a rebound in oil sands extraction.', 'Conversely, the capacity utilization rate in construction fell 0.7 percentage points to 82.7% in the fourth quarter.', "Lower activity in engineering more than offset the increase in residential and non-residential building construction.'"]

title: Federal members of Parliament and federal members of Cabinet across Canada
summary:
```html

Summary

In 2023, women constituted 30.6% of MPs in the House of Commons, a rise from 20.6% in 1997. Cabinet achieved gender parity with women representing 48.7%, a significant increase from 24.3% in 2002. These statistics are part of Canada's efforts to track and promote gender equality in federal leadership, as outlined in the Gender Results Framework introduced in 2018.

Facts

  • Gender representation among MPs in 1997
    • 79.4% (Men)
    • 20.6% (Women)
  • Gender representation among MPs in 2023
    • 69.4% (Men)
    • 30.6% (Women)
  • Gender representation in Cabinet in 2002
    • 75.7% (Men)
    • 24.3% (Women)
  • Gender representation in Cabinet in 2023
    • 51.3% (Men)
    • 48.7% (Women)
```
quotes: ['\'In recognition of International Women\'s Day, the CGDIS has also released an infographic titled "Gender representation among Canadian members of Parliament and Cabinet," which provides a brief overview of gender representation in Canada\'s House of Commons and Cabinet.', 'A balanced distribution of women and men throughout all levels of decision-making in Canada leads to better decisions and is essential to a fair and democratic society.', 'In 2023, 69.4% of MPs were men and 30.6% were women.', "In 2023, men made up 51.3% of Cabinet, while women made up 48.7%.'"]

title: Farm product prices, January 2024
summary:
```html

Summary

January 2024 saw a decline in monthly prices for wheat (excluding durum) in the Prairie provinces, with Manitoba experiencing the largest year-over-year drop at -24.1%. Canola prices also fell across all provinces, with Quebec leading the decline at -11.2%. Conversely, dry peas prices increased in the Prairie provinces, with Saskatchewan seeing the highest rise at +6.6%. Slaughter cattle prices varied, with year-over-year gains in each province of at least +16.3%. Feeder cattle prices increased in Western provinces, with Alberta up by +3.3%, and saw year-over-year gains across all provinces, with Alberta having the highest at +39.1%. Hog prices had mixed movements, with Ontario leading monthly gains at +2.8%.

Facts

  • Wheat (excluding durum) January price changes
    • -4.8% (Manitoba)
    • -24.1% (Manitoba year-over-year)
    • -22.8% (Saskatchewan year-over-year)
    • -22.1% (Alberta year-over-year)
  • Canola January price changes
    • -11.2% (Quebec)
  • Soybean January price changes
    • -2.0% (Manitoba)
    • -3.4% (Quebec)
    • -3.5% (Ontario)
  • Dry peas January price changes
    • +6.6% (Saskatchewan)
    • +6.1% (Alberta)
    • +4.7% (Manitoba)
  • Slaughter cattle January price changes
    • -0.4% to -8.1% (Range across provinces)
    • +16.3% (Minimum year-over-year growth across provinces)
  • Feeder cattle January price changes
    • +3.3% (Alberta)
    • -0.5% to -8.3% (Range of decreases across provinces)
    • +8.4% to +39.1% (Year-over-year range across provinces)
  • Hog January price changes
    • +2.8% (Ontario)
    • -6.2% (Nova Scotia)
```
quotes: ["'Manitoba (-24.1%) posted the most notable year-over-year drop", 'Quebec posting the largest decline, down 11.2%', 'Saskatchewan leading the increase (+6.6%)', 'shrinking cattle herd supported year-over-year price gains in slaughter cattle, with each province posting growth of at least 16.3%', 'feeder cattle prices increased across all provinces year over year, with gains ranging from 8.4% in Prince Edward Island to 39.1% in Alberta', 'Ontario (+2.8%)', "Nova Scotia (-6.2%) led the decreases in hog prices'"]

In January, Canada's merchandise imports decreased by 3.8% to $61.8 billion, and exports fell by 1.7%. The trade balance shifted from a $863 million deficit in December to a $496 million surplus in January. Imports of consumer goods and motor vehicles and parts saw significant declines, while exports of metal products and aircraft also decreased. title: Securities statistics, fourth quarter 2023

Summary

Canadian entities increased their net borrowing in debt securities to $71.7 billion in Q4, with government sector leading at $50.9 billion. Total outstanding debt securities reached $5,721.5 billion, up by $58.4 billion. Net retirements of equity securities continued, totaling $5.5 billion in Q4. Annually, net debt security issuances were $206.3 billion in 2023, down from $253.9 billion in 2022. The government sector's net issuances were $88.8 billion, while financial sector borrowings slowed to $87.6 billion. Equity retirements exceeded issuances by $32.4 billion, and the market value of equity securities rose by $279.5 billion in 2023.

title: Control and sale of alcoholic beverages and cannabis, April 1, 2022, to March 31, 2023
summary:
```html

Summary

Federal and provincial governments collected $15.5 billion from alcohol and cannabis sales, marking a 2.5% increase from the previous fiscal year. Alcohol sales rose by 2.8% to $26.3 billion, driven by a 5.9% price increase, despite a 1.1% drop in volume. Beer per capita sales hit a record low, while wine volume sales fell by 3.0%. Ciders and coolers saw a modest volume increase of 0.6%. Spirit sales grew by 3.0%, but volume slightly decreased. Recreational cannabis sales surged by 15.8% to $4.7 billion, with inhaled extracts contributing significantly to this growth.

title: Labour productivity, hourly compensation and unit labour cost, fourth quarter 2023
summary:
```html

Summary

Canadian businesses experienced a 0.4% rise in labour productivity in Q4, marking the first increase since Q1 of 2022. Hours worked remained stable, with slight changes in employment and average hours worked. Productivity improved in both goods-producing (+0.1%) and service-producing (+0.4%) sectors. Unit labour costs decreased by 0.1%, the first drop after 12 quarters of increases. Annually, labour productivity fell by 1.8% in 2023, with goods-producing sectors down 3.4% and service sectors down 0.8%, reflecting a 0.6% rise in real GDP and a 2.5% increase in hours worked.

Facts

  • Labour Productivity Q4
    • +0.4% (first gain since Q1 2022)
  • Real GDP of Businesses Q4
    • +0.4% (after -0.4% in the previous quarter)
  • Hours Worked Q4
    • 0.0% (stable)
  • Number of Jobs Q4
    • -0.1%
  • Average Hours Worked Q4
    • +0.1%
  • Goods-Producing Businesses Productivity Q4
    • +0.1% (after four quarters of decline)
  • Service-Producing Businesses Productivity Q4
    • +0.4% (first increase in six quarters)
  • Unit Labour Costs Q4
    • -0.1% (first decline in 13 quarters)
  • Annual Labour Productivity 2023
    • -1.8% (third consecutive annual decline)
  • Real GDP of Businesses 2023
    • +0.6%
  • Hours Worked 2023
    • +2.5%
  • Goods-Producing Businesses Productivity 2023

  • Service-Producing Businesses Productivity 2023
    • -0.8% (following zero growth in the previous year)
```

title: Immigrant-owned businesses on average received a higher dollar value of government support programs than Canadian-born owned businesses during the COVID-19 pandemic
summary:
```html

Summary

Immigrant-owned businesses in Canada were more affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, leading to higher usage of government support programs compared to those owned by Canadian-born individuals. They received 33% of CEBA loans, 37% of CECE aid, but only 14% of CEWS subsidies. When adjusting for business characteristics, immigrant-majority-owned businesses were more likely to receive CEBA and CECE support but less likely to benefit from CEWS. The total support value for these businesses was 6% higher on average than for Canadian-born owned businesses.

Facts

  • Ownership by immigrants
    • 25% (One in four businesses)
  • CEBA loans
    • 33% (One-third of total loan)
  • CECE aid
    • 37%
  • CEWS subsidies
    • 14% (Over one-tenth)
  • Total support value
    • 6% higher for immigrant-majority-owned businesses
```
quotes: ['"Use of Government COVID-19 Liquidity Support Programs by Immigrant-owned Businesses and Those Owned by Canadian-born Individuals"']

title: Advertising and related services, 2022
summary:
Summary

The Canadian advertising and related services industry saw a 15.4% increase in operating revenues in 2022, reaching $13.3 billion. Growth was observed across most regions, with the Northwest Territories, Ontario, Alberta, and Nova Scotia leading. Operating profit margins decreased slightly to 15.3%. Operating expenses rose by 18.6%, with salaries and wages comprising 44.4% of these expenses. Subcontracting expenses also grew. Sales to businesses outside Canada increased by 1.4 percentage points to 15.1%. The industry is expected to continue growing in 2023, albeit at a slower rate due to economic factors.

Facts

title: Screened passenger traffic at Canadian airports, January 2024
summary:
Summary

In January 2024, 4.3 million passengers were screened at Canada's eight largest airports, up 10.2% from January 2023 but 2.6% below January 2020. International traffic outside the US rose by 17.0% year-over-year, with 1.4 million passengers, 4.7% above January 2020. Transborder traffic to the US increased by 14.1%, yet remained below pre-pandemic levels. Domestic traffic was up 2.8% from 2023 but 6.1% below January 2020. Six airports saw over 9.0% growth, with Calgary, Montréal-Trudeau, and Halifax exceeding January 2020 volumes.

title: Annual Head Office Survey, 2022
summary:
Summary

In 2022, Canada had 2,654 head offices, a 1.1% decrease from 2021, with head office employment also down by 0.9% to 209,029. Ontario, Quebec, and Alberta were the top provinces for head office employment, concentrated in Toronto, Montréal, Vancouver, and Calgary. Toronto led with 692 head offices and 67,503 employees. Economic challenges persisted in 2023, but job creation was positive and business numbers grew. Detailed 2023 head office data will be released in 2024.
