title: Gross domestic product, income and expenditure, fourth quarter 2023
summary: In Q4 2023, Canada's real GDP grew by 0.2%, driven by increased exports (up 1.4%) and decreased imports (down 0.4%), despite a 0.2% decline in final domestic demand. Exports were boosted by crude oil and travel services, while imports fell due to lower demand for intermediate metal products and vehicles. Household spending rose slightly by 0.2%, with growth in vehicle purchases but a decline in spending abroad. Housing investment dropped by 0.4%, with a slowdown in the resale market. Business investment also declined, with a 3.0% decrease in non-residential structures. Inventory investment slowed, with a $30.4 billion increase. The terms of trade fell by 0.5% in Q4 and 5.9% over the year. Employee compensation grew by 0.8%, the slowest since Q2 2020. The household saving rate remained stable at 6.2%, and corporate incomes rose by 2.9%, with non-financial corporations growing by 3.3% and financial corporations declining by 1.8%.
quotes: ["'Exports of goods and services rose 1.4% in the fourth quarter", 'Household spending increased 0.2% in the fourth quarter', 'Housing investment was down 0.4% in the fourth quarter', 'Real business investment declined for the sixth time over the last seven quarters', 'Businesses continued to add to their inventories in the fourth quarter (+$30.4 billion)', 'The ratio of the price of exports to the price of imports—the terms of trade—fell 0.5% in the fourth quarter', 'Compensation of employees rose 0.8% in the fourth quarter of 2023, the slowest growth rate since the second quarter of 2020', 'The household saving rate was little changed in the fourth quarter, at 6.2%', "Corporate incomes increased 2.9%, after rising 3.4% in the third quarter'"]

title: Gross domestic product by industry, December 2023
summary: In December, Canada's real GDP remained flat, with a 0.2% contraction in goods-producing industries and unchanged services-producing industries. A public sector strike in Quebec led to a 1.0% decline in public sector output, with educational services dropping 3.8%. Utilities shrank by 3.6%, influenced by warmer weather and drought conditions. Construction fell 0.6%, and manufacturing declined 0.4%, with transportation equipment manufacturing down 3.1%. Mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction grew by 1.5%, driven by record crude oil production. The finance and insurance sector expanded by 0.8%, retail trade grew for the fourth month by 0.7%, and wholesale trade increased by 0.5%. An early estimate suggests a 0.4% GDP increase in January 2024. The fourth quarter of 2023 saw a 0.2% GDP rise, with mining and retail trade contributing positively, while public sector and construction declined. Overall, 2023 GDP growth slowed to 1.2%, with the public sector and client-facing industries as main growth drivers, while goods-producing industries, especially construction, tempered growth.

title: Farm cash receipts, January to December 2023
summary: In 2023, Canadian farm cash receipts increased by 3.6% to $98.6 billion, with livestock receipts up 9.8% to $37.3 billion, largely due to a $2.7 billion rise in cattle receipts. Crop receipts grew 2.0% to $54.9 billion, with significant gains in wheat and potatoes, but declines in corn and soybeans. Supply managed receipts, including dairy and chicken, also rose. All provinces except Ontario saw increases. Direct payments to farmers decreased by 13.4% to $6.4 billion, with a notable drop in crop insurance payments from the previous year's high, but still above the five-year average.
quotes: ["'Farm cash receipts totalled $98.6 billion in 2023, up 3.6% (+$3.4 billion) compared with 2022", 'Livestock receipts rose 9.8% to $37.3 billion in 2023 because of increases in the cattle and supply managed sectors', 'Total crop receipts in 2023 were up 2.0% to $54.9 billion, compared with 2022', "Total direct payments dropped by $983.0 million (-13.4%) to $6.4 billion in 2023, compared with 2022'"]

title: Aircraft movement statistics: Major and select small airports, December 2023
summary: In 2023, Canada's major and select small airports saw a 13.1% increase in aircraft movements from December 2022, totaling 352,280. Itinerant movements rose by 8.8% to 260,236, while local movements surged by 27.7% to 92,044. The year ended with 5.5 million movements, 5.5% higher than in 2022 and 90% of 2019's volume. International movements excluding the US grew by 18.1%, while US-related traffic increased by 9.7%. Domestic movements within Canada went up by 7.9%. Most provinces saw traffic increases, with Ontario leading. Wildfires in 2023 led to heightened activity from smaller carriers. Despite recovery, many airports still lagged behind pre-pandemic levels.

summary: The latest Canadian Community Health Survey has released new data on smoking behaviors, focusing on the stages of change in smoking habits and the use of tobacco alternatives. This rapid response component provides insights into how individuals are approaching smoking cessation and the adoption of different products that may impact public health. The data is crucial for developing targeted interventions and policies to reduce smoking rates and promote healthier choices among Canadians.

title: Weak productivity is threatening Canada’s post-pandemic wage growth
summary: Canadian wage growth has been high but not sufficient to keep pace with inflation, especially considering the tight labor market earlier in the pandemic recovery. Real wages fell by 1% in 2021 and 2.5% in 2022, with only a slight recovery in 2023. Canada's productivity growth is lagging, ranking 5th among G7 countries since 2019, with output per hour worked falling below 2019 levels. This underperformance is increasing unit labor costs and reducing competitiveness relative to the U.S. The labor market is softening, with unemployment rising and job openings decreasing, which may slow wage growth further. Long-term wage increases depend on productivity growth, which is hindered by low business investment and ineffective utilization of immigrant skills. Without improvements in productivity, living standards may stagnate.
quotes: ['"Wage growth lagged, cutting into household purchasing power." \' "Real" (after adjusted for inflation) wages declined by about 1% in 2021 and 2.5% in 2022 before picking up in 2023.', 'Over the last 30 years, real worker pay per hour has moved largely in lockstep with productivity growth.', 'Productivity underperformance versus the U.S. has increased relative unit labour costs in Canada by about 5%.', "Sustained growth in worker pay significantly above the rate of inflation over the longer run—which is critical to ensuring living standards continue to improve—will also depend on ensuring that the weak productivity performance does not persist.'"]

title: Canada's balance of international payments, fourth quarter 2023
summary: Canada's current account deficit decreased to $1.6 billion in Q4, with a stronger goods surplus. Exports rose by $2.9 billion, led by energy products, while imports increased marginally. The services deficit narrowed, and the financial account saw Canadian investors acquire $33.5 billion in foreign securities. For 2023, the current account deficit grew to $17.8 billion, with a significant drop in energy exports. Services exports increased, driven by travel and commercial services. Direct and portfolio investments resulted in a net outflow, with Canadians investing heavily in foreign securities, particularly in US bonds and shares. Foreign investment in Canadian securities continued, albeit at a reduced pace.

title: Economic and Social Reports, February 2024
summary: Women inventors in Canada are increasing at a faster rate than men, with a higher proportion being younger, immigrants, and working in large businesses. Black and Latin American youth in British Columbia have lower high school graduation and postsecondary enrollment rates than White youth, largely due to lower academic performance in key subjects. Canadian citizenship acquisition among recent immigrants has declined from 75% in 1996 to 46% in 2021, with the pandemic contributing to recent drops. Recent immigrants have seen faster employment rate growth and narrowing earnings gaps compared to Canadian-born workers, likely due to changes in immigration selection and economic conditions.

title: Disparities in wealth and debt among Canadian households
summary: Canadian households face increasing financial pressures with the highest debt to disposable income ratios in the G7. The "Research to Insights" presentation reveals that post-pandemic net financial gains are concentrated among the wealthiest, while lower- and middle-income families see a decline in net saving. Younger households are increasingly burdened by debt service costs and are retreating from the housing market, threatening socioeconomic mobility as homeownership becomes less attainable. Real estate remains central to wealth accumulation, with 55% of an average household's wealth tied to property, but the distribution of wealth is skewed towards older Canadians, posing risks for future intergenerational mobility.
quotes: ["'Net saving deteriorates for lower- and middle-income households as renters and lower-income families are spending more than they make", 'Prospective young homeowners turn away from the housing market, while homeowners pay off debt or look for affordable housing', "Real estate continues to be central to wealth accumulation across the life cycle'"]

title: Monthly civil aviation statistics, December 2023
summary: In December 2023, Canadian airlines carried 6.8 million passengers, a 10.7% increase from 2022 but 5.8% below December 2019 levels. The passenger load factor was 82.8%, with 18.1 billion passenger-kilometres flown. Throughout 2023, 79.6 million passengers were transported, marking a 27% increase from 2022, yet 6.8% less than in 2019. The year saw a gradual recovery from the pandemic, with passenger numbers and load factors nearing pre-pandemic levels, particularly in October and November. Operating revenue for December reached $2.5 billion, 14.3% higher than in 2019, with the annual total at $28.3 billion, up 11.8% from 2019.

title: 2021 Census of Population: Analytical product on participation in French immersion
summary: The "Participation in French immersion, bilingualism and the use of French in adulthood, 2021" report reveals that in Canada outside Quebec, 16.9% of children aged 5 to 17 with a non-French mother tongue were in French immersion. These individuals were 12 times more likely to converse in French (50.2%) compared to those not in immersion (4.1%). The study, based on 2021 Census data, examines factors influencing French immersion program participation and its impact on bilingualism and French usage in personal and professional settings.

title: Payroll employment, earnings and hours, and job vacancies, December 2023
summary: In December 2023, Canadian payroll employment rose by 31,600 (+0.2%), totaling a year-over-year increase of 223,500 (+1.3%). The education sector saw a significant rebound with 56,800 new jobs (+7.2%) after a temporary dip due to the Quebec public sector strike. Excluding education, payroll employment fell by 25,200 (-0.1%). Job vacancies remained stable at 637,400, a significant drop from the previous year (-24.7%) and from the May 2022 peak (-36.5%). Health care and social assistance, public administration, and construction sectors experienced employment growth, while retail trade saw a decline. Average weekly earnings decreased by 1.1% to $1,212 in December, but year-over-year earnings grew by 3.8%. Job vacancies decreased in retail trade but increased in education and utilities, with retail trade vacancies at their lowest since November 2019. Job vacancies also fell in Ontario and Quebec, while they rose in Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island.

title: Canada's fertility rate reaches an all-time low in 2022
summary: In 2022, Canada's total fertility rate (TFR) fell to a historic low of 1.33 children per woman, marking the largest decline (-7.4%) since 1971-1972. This drop, which accelerated during the COVID-19 pandemic, was observed in most provinces and territories, particularly among women aged 20 to 39. Canada's TFR now ranks in the middle among selected high-income countries, with South Korea at the lowest (0.78) and France at the highest (1.80). The decline in Canada's fertility rate is the third steepest after the Netherlands and Germany, indicating a potential pandemic-related disruption in fertility behaviors.

title: Firearms and violent crime in Canada, 2022
summary: In 2022, Canada saw a 36.7 per 100,000 population rate of firearm-related violent crimes, an 8.9% increase from 2021, marking the highest rate since 2009. Ontario, particularly Toronto, drove this rise, with a 24% increase in Ontario alone. British Columbia and Alberta also saw significant increases, with urban centers contributing most to the rise. Since 2013, firearm-related violent crime has risen by 55%, with rural and northern regions showing the largest increases. Discharging a firearm with intent saw a 244% increase since 2013. Handgun-related crimes rose by 50%, and the firearm-related homicide rate in 2022 was the highest since 1991.

title: Monthly civil aviation statistics, November 2023
summary: In November 2023, Canadian Level I air carriers transported 6.0 million passengers, an 8.6% increase from 2022 but 2.2% below November 2019 levels. Passenger-kilometres reached 15.5 billion, surpassing pre-pandemic figures by 1.4%, with available seat-kilometres at 19.0 billion matching pre-pandemic capacity. The load factor was 81.9%, slightly higher than the 80.8% in November 2019. Passengers traveled an average of 2,584 kilometres, a 3.6% increase from 2019. Flying hours were down by 5.3% compared to pre-pandemic levels. Operating revenue for air carriers hit $2.0 billion, marking a 14.6% rise from November 2019 and the 12th month of revenue exceeding pre-pandemic levels.

summary: In November 2023, Canada's major and select small airports saw a 9.1% increase in aircraft movements compared to November 2022, totaling 447,863. International movements excluding the US rose by 16.2%, while US-related traffic increased by 7.3%. Domestic movements within Canada grew by 5.8%. title: Repair and maintenance services subsector, 2022
summary: In 2022, the repair and maintenance services subsector saw a 7.9% increase in operating revenues, reaching $36.9 billion, with a slight dip in profit margin to 9.1%. The automotive repair and maintenance industry group contributed 62.5% of this revenue, growing by 7.5% to $23.1 billion, despite a marginal decrease in profit margin to 8.7%. Non-automotive repair and maintenance generated $13.8 billion, maintaining a stable profit margin of 9.8%. Increased demand in 2023 is driven by supply chain issues affecting new vehicle availability, leading to more repairs and maintenance of existing vehicles and machinery.

title: Production and disposition of tobacco products, December 2023
summary: In December 2023, Canadian cigarette production decreased by 8.7% from the previous month to 1.2 billion but was 52.6% higher than December 2022. Cigarette sales fell by 14.0% to 1.1 billion compared to November 2023 and were 16.7% lower than sales in December 2022.

title: Real estate agents and brokers, 2022
summary: In 2022, the Canadian real estate agents and brokers industry saw a 21.8% decrease in operating revenue, dropping from $26.7 billion in 2021 to $20.9 billion. This decline was influenced by the Bank of Canada's interest rate hikes, which rose from 0.25% to 4.25%. Despite the downturn, revenues remained 34.5% higher than pre-pandemic levels in 2019. Ontario experienced a 25.9% revenue drop, while Alberta saw a 5.0% increase. Operating expenses fell by 15.4%, with subcontract expenses being the largest cost. The operating profit margin decreased from 36.5% to 31.3%. Challenges are expected to persist in 2023, with further declines anticipated due to ongoing weakness in home sales and rising borrowing costs.
quotes: ["'Operating revenue in the Canadian real estate agents and brokers industry fell by over one-fifth (-21.8%)", 'Higher borrowing costs dampened existing home sales through 2022', 'Ontario, which accounted for the largest share of operating revenue nationally (55.0%), fell 25.9% to $11.5 billion in 2022', 'Alberta was the only province to post an increase in operating revenue, growing 5.0% from 2021 to 2022', 'The operating profit margin decreased from 36.5% in 2021 to 31.3% in 2022', "Operating revenue in the real estate agents and brokers industry is expected to continue to decline in 2023'"]

title: Screened passenger traffic at Canadian airports, December 2023
summary: In December 2023, Canada's eight largest airports saw 4.5 million passengers, an 8.9% increase from December 2022 but 3.5% below December 2019. Domestic traffic declined by 1.0% year-over-year and was 8.5% lower than in 2019. Transborder traffic to the U.S. rose by 15.0%, yet remained below pre-pandemic levels. Other international traffic grew by 18.5% from 2022 and was 6.8% higher than in 2019. Six airports reported increases, with Montréal-Trudeau International exceeding December 2019 volumes by 4.6%, marking its ninth consecutive month of growth. Edmonton and Halifax saw declines compared to December 2022.
quotes: ["'In December, 4.5 million passengers passed through pre-board security screening at checkpoints operated at Canada's eight largest airports, an increase of 8.9% compared with the number of passengers during the challenging holiday travel period of December 2022", 'December 2023 traffic was 3.5% below the same month in 2019, ending a five-month run in which total passengers had surpassed pre-COVID-19 pandemic volumes', 'Domestic passenger traffic in December (-1.0%) was down compared with December 2022, marking the first year-over-year monthly decline for this sector in 2023', 'Transborder traffic to the United States (+15.0%) was up sharply from December 2022', 'Other international traffic (outside the United States) increased by 18.5% compared with the same month in 2022', 'The 1.5 million passengers screened for international flights in December 2023 was also higher (+6.8%) than the volume reported in December 2019, making it the only sector to surpass pre-pandemic volumes', "Six of Canada's eight largest airports reported increases in year-over-year screened passenger traffic, with Ottawa Macdonald Cartier International, Montréal-Trudeau International, and Toronto Pearson International reporting double-digit increases", "Only Montréal-Trudeau International reported a December 2023 passenger volume higher than that of December 2019 (+4.6%)'"]

title: Labour Force Survey: Revisions, 2021 to 2023
summary: The Labour Force Survey's seasonal adjustment revision, accounting for COVID-19 impacts, shows that recent labour market patterns are realigning with pre-pandemic trends. The revisions had minimal effect on employment estimates and unemployment rates in Canada, with changes in the unemployment rate not exceeding 0.1 percentage points. The national unemployment rate for December 2023 remained at 5.8% after the revision.
quotes: ["'Labour Force Survey seasonal adjustment revision has minimal impact on labour market trends'"]

title: Total income of farm families, 2021
summary: In 2021, Canadian farm families' average total income rose by 19.1% to $214,089, with net operating income up 41.5% to $99,786, largely due to increased AgriRecovery funding. Off-farm income, which constitutes 53.4% of total income, increased by 4.7% to $114,303. Incorporated farm families saw a 28.9% income increase to $365,484, outpacing the unincorporated sector's 7.9% rise to $143,368. Crop farming families experienced a 21.9% income growth, with potato farms having the highest average income at $436,475. Regionally, Saskatchewan farm families had the highest average income at $271,945, while British Columbia families had the highest off-farm income at $136,761.

title: Census of Environment: A snapshot of Canada's growing coastal communities and their natural environment
summary: In 2021, 5.5 million Canadians lived within 10 km of the coast, with the Pacific Coast seeing the most growth. Coastal population increased by 5.3% since 2016, with significant growth in British Columbia and the Maritime provinces. Conversely, the Newfoundland ecoprovince experienced a population decline. Over 460,000 Canadians live less than five meters above sea level, posing risks due to rising sea levels. Enhanced mapping has identified 1,651 km² of seagrass and 3,602 km² of salt marshes, vital for coastline protection and carbon storage. As of 2022, 14.6% of Canada's marine areas are protected, with a goal to reach 25% by 2025 and 30% by 2030.
quotes: ["'Canada's coastal population grew by 5.3% from 2016 to 5.5 million people in 2021", 'An additional 207,820 people lived in the southern coastal area of British Columbia in 2021 compared with five years earlier, the largest increase nationally', 'Over twice as many people were living within less than five metres above sea level on the Pacific Coast (318,225 people) compared with the Atlantic Coast (142,492)', 'In 2023, known areas of seagrass meadows extended across 1,651 km2 of coastal oceans, while salt marshes covered 3,602 km2 of coastal area', "In 2022, 14.6% of Canada's ocean and coastal areas were protected or conserved", 'The conserved area increased by nearly 44,000 km2 from 2021 to 844,059 km2, mainly because of the addition of the Eastern Canyons Conservation Area in the Scotian Shelf bioregion in the Atlantic Ocean', "In 2022, 37% of the mapped area of these ecosystems was conserved or protected'"]

title: Payroll employment, earnings and hours, and job vacancies, November 2023
summary: In November, Canadian payroll employment fell by 88,300 (-0.5%), largely due to a strike in Quebec's education sector. Excluding this, the decline was 25,300 (-0.1%). Retail trade employment continued to drop for the third month, with a cumulative loss of 12,500 (-0.6%) since September. Wholesale trade also declined by 5,000 (-0.6%), and accommodation and food services decreased by 5,600 (-0.4%). However, health care and social assistance grew by 6,700 (+0.3%), and public administration increased by 3,900 (+0.3%). Average weekly earnings rose by 0.6% to $1,228. Job vacancies edged up to 653,000, with notable increases in accommodation and food services, retail trade, and manufacturing. Ontario saw a significant rise in job vacancies, up by 21,200 (+9.8%).

title: Socioeconomic profile of the 2SLGBTQ+ population aged 15 years and older, 2019 to 2021
summary: Statistics Canada's data from the 2019-2021 Canadian Community Health Survey reveals that 4.4% of Canadians aged 15 and older identify as 2SLGBTQ+. Youth aged 15-24 are the most likely to identify as such, with 10.5% reporting they belong to this group. Despite higher educational attainment, 2SLGBTQ+ individuals have lower incomes, with 18.4% in the bottom income quintile. Mental health disparities are significant, with 29.7% of 2SLGBTQ+ people rating their mental health as fair or poor, compared to 9.1% of non-2SLGBTQ+ individuals. Transgender or non-binary individuals report even higher rates of fair or poor mental health at 54.7%.

title: Tourism Investment Module, 2022
summary: In 2022, Canadian tourism industries invested $25.4 billion in non-residential capital assets, comprising 6.2% of the country's total non-residential investment, a decrease from 6.6% in 2021. Investment declines were notable in urban transit systems and passenger car rentals. The private sector's share of tourism investment increased for the first time since 2016, accounting for 46.2% of the total, led by Ontario with $4.9 billion. Public sector investment was dominated by provincial, territorial, and Indigenous general governments, with Ontario contributing 58.3% to the sector's investment in the province. Overall, capital investment by tourism industries fell by 2.7% in real terms in 2022.

title: Economic and Social Reports, January 2024
summary: The shift to remote work has led to a significant decline in public transit use in Canada, with urban commuters dropping from 14.8% in 2016 to 11.8% in 2023. Canadian corporate debt has risen to 160% of GDP, posing risks of insolvency and economic slowdown. Blended Visa Office-Referred refugees show better early employment outcomes than government-assisted refugees but lag behind privately sponsored ones. Two-step economic immigrants earn more than one-step immigrants from arrival, suggesting better skill-market fit. Low-skilled foreign workers in accommodation, food services, and food manufacturing are less likely to obtain permanent residency compared to high-skilled workers.

title: Transition to permanent residency and retention of temporary foreign workers in accommodation and food services and food manufacturing
summary: In Canada, TFWs with lower-skill occupations in the accommodation and food services industry have a lower rate of transition to permanent residency (29%) compared to those with higher-skill occupations (45%) and study permit holders (49%). Despite this, they represent a larger number of immigrants due to their greater numbers. Post-immigration, 40% of these TFWs remain in the industry after five years, less than higher-skill TFWs (52%) but more than study permit holders (16%). In the food manufacturing industry, TFWs with lower-skill occupations show a declining retention rate, dropping from 73% to 36% over five years post-immigration. Each new cohort of TFWs sees a lower percentage remaining in the industry one year after becoming permanent residents, from 69% for the 2006-2010 cohort to 57% for the 2016-2019 cohort.

title: New historical data tables on immigration and official languages
summary: In 2021, immigrants made up 23% of Canada's population, with 93.6% able to converse in English or French, continuing a historical trend. In Quebec, 80.5% of immigrants could speak French, a significant increase from 38.4% in 1951. Conversely, English-only speaking immigrants in Quebec declined from 56.8% in 1951 to 15.4% in 2021. In the rest of Canada, 5.5% of immigrants spoke French in 2021, a slight decrease from 2001. Over half of Quebec's immigrants in 2021 had French as their first official language, a reversal from 1971. Outside Quebec, French-speaking immigrants surpassed 100,000 in 2021, with a growing proportion of recent immigrants speaking French.
quotes: ['"In Quebec, the proportion of immigrants who can conduct a conversation in French only or along with English more than doubled, from 38.4% in 1951 to 80.5% in 2021." \' "In Canada outside Quebec, just over 1 in 20 immigrants (5.5%) could have a conversation in French only or along with English in 2021, down slightly from 2001 (6.6%)." \' "In Quebec, 54.3% of immigrants had French as their first official language spoken in 2021, while one-quarter (25.2%) had English." \' "In 2021, 102,000 immigrants had French as their first official language spoken in Canada outside Quebec, the majority of whom lived in Ontario (66,000), Alberta (13,000) and British Columbia (12,000)." \' "The proportion of French-speaking immigrants to Canada who settled outside Quebec increased; among recent immigrants, it rose from 11.0% in 2006 to 17.9% in 2021."']

title: Distributions of household economic accounts for income, consumption, saving and wealth of Canadian households, third quarter 2023
summary: In the third quarter of 2023, income and wealth inequality in Canada widened. The disposable income gap between the highest and lowest income quintiles increased to 44.9%, with the lowest earners seeing a 1.2% drop in disposable income due to higher interest rates and reduced net investment income. The highest earners experienced a 3.2% increase in disposable income, driven by wage and investment income gains. Net saving for the lowest earners fell by 9.8% due to cost-of-living increases, while the highest earners saw a 4.6% increase. Wealth disparity also grew, with the top 20% holding 67.4% of net worth, averaging $3.3 million, and the bottom 40% holding just 2.8%, averaging $67,738. The least wealthy saw only a 0.9% increase in net worth due to mortgage debt offsetting real estate gains. Younger households reduced mortgage debt by 5%, facing affordability challenges, and their debt-to-income ratio decreased, but their debt service ratio increased due to higher interest rates. Overall, household debt continued to grow, with a slowdown in mortgage borrowing.
quotes: ['"The income and wealth gaps increased in the third quarter of 2023 relative to the same period a year earlier as higher interest rates had a negative impact on the income and net worth of the lowest income and least wealthy households." \' "Income inequality increased in the third quarter as the gap in the share of disposable income between households in the two highest income quintiles and two lowest income quintiles reached 44.9%, up 0.5 percentage points from the third quarter of 2022." \' "The lowest income households—those in the bottom 20% of the income distribution—were the only income group to reduce their average disposable income in the third quarter of 2023 relative to the same quarter of 2022 (-1.2%)." \' "Higher interest rates weighed on average disposable income for the lowest income households in the third quarter." \' "Average disposable income for the highest income households (top 20% of the income distribution) (+3.2%) increased at the fastest pace of any income group in the third quarter of 2023 relative to a year earlier, due entirely to gains in wages (+5.7%) and net investment income (+9.9%)." \' "In contrast with a 4.6% gain in net saving for the highest income households, net saving for the lowest income households decreased by 9.8% in the third quarter of 2023 relative to a year earlier." \' "The wealthiest (top 20% of the wealth distribution) accounted for more than two-thirds (67.4%) of net worth in the third quarter of 2023, averaging $3.3 million, while the least wealthy (bottom 40% of the wealth distribution) accounted for 2.8%, averaging $67,738." \' "The gap in wealth between the top 20% and the bottom 40% increased by 0.2 percentage points from the third quarter of 2022 to reach 64.6% in the third quarter of 2023." \' "The average value of real estate for the wealthiest increased by 0.7% over the same period, the same rate observed for the average household." \' "Along with rapid interest rate increases from the third quarter of 2022 to the third quarter of 2023, the youngest households were the only age group that reduced their average mortgage debt (-5.0% vs. +1.3% for all households)." \' "Debt-to-income ratios were the highest for core working-age households (aged 35 to 64) in the third quarter of 2023, ranging from 164.2% to 255.9%, and they also increased relative to a year earlier." \' "Persistently high interest rates and inflation are likely to continue to strain households\' ability to make ends meet without going further into debt, especially vulnerable groups, such as those with the lowest income, the least wealth and in the younger age groups."']

title: The continued impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic: Variations in the economic integration of new immigrants
summary: In 2020, Canada admitted 184,575 immigrants, a 45.9% decrease from 2019 due to COVID-19 restrictions. The 2020 cohort, with a majority having pre-admission experience, filed the fewest taxes in a decade. Their median entry wage in 2021 rebounded to $37,700, surpassing pre-pandemic levels. Women's median entry wage increased by 27.1% to $30,500, while men's reached $44,100. Immigrants with pre-admission work experience earned the highest median entry wages, with those holding both work and study permits earning $48,600. Economic principal applicants had the highest median entry wage at $51,200, while refugees had the lowest. The 2011 cohort's median wage increased by 9.6% to $41,100 in 2021, indicating the importance of pre-admission experience for economic integration.

title: Performing arts, 2022
summary: In 2022, the performing arts industry saw a recovery from the pandemic with operating revenues rising to $2.8 billion and profit margins reaching 12.4%. Non-profit companies experienced growth, heavily reliant on grants and subsidies, which made up 63.7% of their revenue. Federal grants increased significantly, while private funding also saw a rise. Sales revenues were still below pre-pandemic levels, with single ticket sales up but subscriptions and touring income down. For-profit companies rebounded with increases in revenues, expenses, and wages. The industry's recovery may be challenged by inflation and the financial strain on households affecting attendance and donations.

title: Natural resource indicators, third quarter 2023
summary: In the third quarter, the natural resources sector's real GDP fell by 0.6%, with declines in energy, minerals and mining, and hunting, fishing, and water subsectors. Export volumes dropped by 3.6%, with significant decreases in energy and minerals and mining exports. Natural resource prices rose by 4.1%, driven by increases in energy and forestry prices, despite a fall in minerals and mining prices. Jobs in the sector slightly decreased by 0.1%. Downstream activities' nominal GDP decreased by 3.5%. Annually, the sector's real GDP grew by 3.1% in 2022, with a 27.2% increase in the price index and a gain of 14,100 jobs.

title: Working from home in Canada
summary: The percentage of Canadians working from home rose to 40% in April 2020 but decreased to 20% by November 2023, compared to 7% in May 2016. Employee preferences for telework vary, with some desiring more remote work and others less, posing challenges for employers. The shift to remote work has significantly reduced public transit use, with passenger trips dropping from 163.9 million to 25.7 million, and has likely decreased greenhouse gas emissions from transportation. If all eligible Canadians worked from home, emissions could have been reduced by 9.5 megatons annually, or 12% of household transportation emissions in 2015.
quotes: ['"After rising to about 40% in April 2020, the percentage of Canadians working most of their hours from home in a given week fell to about 20% in November 2023" \' "Of all employees usually working from home, almost one in four would ideally work a greater proportion of their hours from home than they did in the reference week of August 2023" \' "The increase in work from home triggered by the pandemic directly decreased public transit use by reducing the number of passenger trips taken by former public transit commuters who started working partly or exclusively from home" \' "A recent Statistics Canada study estimates that if all Canadians whose job could be done from home in 2015 and who worked onsite that year had started working exclusively from home, greenhouse gas emissions due to transportation could have fallen by 9.5 megatons of carbon dioxide equivalent on an annual basis"']

title: Accommodation services, 2022
summary: In 2022, the accommodation services subsector's operating revenue reached a record $29.6 billion, surpassing pre-COVID-19 levels by 9.6%. Inflation contributed to a 29.3% increase in traveller accommodation prices. Ontario led in revenue share at 29.5%. Operating expenses were $24.4 billion, with salaries and wages being the largest expense. The profit margin improved to 17.5%, exceeding the 2019 figure of 14.2%. Hotels, motor hotels, and motels saw a 61.7% revenue increase to $24 billion, with a significant portion from room sales. Other accommodation industries, led by Alberta, increased revenue by 20.7% to $5.6 billion, though their profit margin decreased to 11.9% in 2022.

title: Human Resources Module of the Canadian economy, 2021
summary: The Human Resources Module (HRM) provides annual data on Canadian jobs, hours, and wages by employee characteristics (age, gender, education, immigration status). It aligns with National Accounts standards and covers various sectors, including tourism, non-profits, and natural resources. This release offers the first economy-wide HRM estimates, serving as a benchmark for sector-specific analyses. For up-to-date trends, the Labour Force Survey's monthly employment statistics are recommended.
quotes: ["'Human Resources Module (HRM) of the Canadian Economy is a new product that depicts annual estimates of jobs, hours worked, and wages and salaries consistent with the System of National Accounts concepts'"]

title: Consumer Price Index: Annual review, 2023
summary: In 2023, the Consumer Price Index (CPI) increased by 3.9%, with energy prices leading the deceleration, falling 4.2% due to lower gasoline and natural gas prices. Food prices from stores rose by 7.8%, with significant increases in edible fats and oils, and bakery products, although the rate of increase was slower than in 2022. Shelter prices also grew more slowly at 5.6%, with homeowners' replacement costs and owned accommodation expenses decelerating, while mortgage interest cost surged by 28.5%, contributing significantly to the CPI rise. Rent increased by 6.5%. All provinces saw price rises, albeit at a reduced rate compared to the previous year.
quotes: ["'Excluding energy, the annual average CPI rose 4.5% in 2023 compared with 5.7% in 2022", 'The slowdown in energy prices was led by gasoline prices, which fell 7.6% in 2023 after a 28.5% increase in 2022', 'Grocery price inflation remained broad-based in 2023 with a number of contributing factors', "The mortgage interest cost index rose 28.5% in 2023, the largest increase on record'"]

title: Small and medium-sized businesses in rural and small town Canada, 2021
summary: In 2021, small businesses in rural and small town (RST) Canada represented 15.3% of the country's total, with a 5.2% increase from 2020. Medium-sized RST businesses made up 15.6%, growing by 15.9%. RST small businesses outperformed urban ones in average annual revenue ($484,327 vs. $408,800) and revenue growth (4.8% vs. 2.3%). The total revenue of small businesses in Canada increased by 9.3% to $866.0 billion, with RST areas contributing 17.6% ($152.7 billion). Net profits for small RST businesses grew by 43.6%, with incorporated entities seeing a 66.0% increase. Medium-sized RST businesses also experienced a net profit increase of 37.4%.

title: National culture indicators, third quarter 2023
summary: Canada's culture and sport sectors saw a 1.3% drop in real GDP in Q3 2023, marking the first decline since Q2 2020. The nominal GDP also fell by 0.6%. Employment in these sectors decreased by 1.1%, totaling 812,512 jobs. The culture sector experienced a 0.8% nominal GDP decline, with the audio-visual and interactive media domain falling by 2.8%, significantly impacted by strikes in the American film industry. Some culture domains, however, did grow, such as governance, funding, and professional support (+2.5%). The sport sector's GDP grew by 1.3%, with jobs increasing to 109,670. Culture sector jobs fell by 1.5% to 702,842, heavily influenced by a 12,077 job decrease in the film and video subdomain due to the spillover effect of American labor strikes.
quotes: ["'Culture and sport gross domestic product heading in opposite directions during third quarter", "Recent labour action causing volatility in culture jobs'"]

title: Architectural services, 2022
summary: In 2022, the operating revenue of the architectural and landscape architectural services industries grew by 8.7% to $6.8 billion, despite a slowdown in housing starts due to higher financing costs. Non-residential investment, particularly in industrial and commercial sectors, increased, with public investment also growing but at a slower rate. Operating expenses rose by 11.1% to $5.7 billion, reducing the profit margin to 16.8%. Non-residential projects accounted for over half of the sales, while Ontario led in revenue generation. In 2023, investment growth stalled, and the demand for architectural services decreased due to rising mortgage rates.

title: Study: Gaps in prescription insurance coverage
summary: In Canada, 79% of the population has some form of prescription drug insurance, with employer-sponsored plans being the most common at 55%. However, disparities exist, with immigrants and racialized groups like Chinese Canadians having lower access to employer-sponsored coverage. Seniors, individuals with chronic conditions, and low-income earners are more likely to rely on government-sponsored plans. For example, over 50% of seniors and nearly half of those with multiple chronic conditions have government-sponsored insurance, compared to just over 10% of the highest income earners and those without chronic conditions. Cost-related non-adherence to medication is highest among those without insurance or with government plans.
quotes: ["'cost-related non-adherence to prescription medication was highest among those with either no insurance plan or a government-sponsored plan", 'not all Canadians had equal access to employer-sponsored drug insurance plans', 'Chinese women (45%) and men (44%) had the lowest rates of employer-sponsored drug insurance coverage', 'seniors, people with chronic conditions, people with lower incomes, part-time workers, those not employed and the self-employed', 'government-sponsored plans were the most common type of plan among senior women (54%) and senior men (51%)', 'For individuals with five or more chronic conditions, almost half had a government-sponsored plan', "For those in the lowest income quintile, approximately 4 in 10 had government-sponsored drug insurance coverage'"]

title: Environmental and Clean Technology Products Economic Account, 2022
summary: The environmental and clean technology products sector in Canada grew by 1.2% in 2022, with over half of the GDP from environmental goods and services, particularly clean electricity. Ontario and Quebec combined contributed nearly two-thirds of the sector's GDP, with Ontario focusing on clean technology services and Quebec on clean electricity. Exports of these products fell by 2.3%, while imports rose by 7.9%, with manufactured goods dominating both trade flows. Employment in the sector grew by 1.3%, lagging behind the overall job growth rate, but wages increased by 5.3%, outpacing the average. In 2020, the sector saw a decrease in energy use and greenhouse gas emissions, reflecting the overall economic impact of the pandemic.
quotes: ["'Ontario (34.3%) accounted for over one-third of the national economic activity in the environmental and clean technology products sector in 2022", 'Manufactured goods (37.9%) accounted for more than one-third of all exports', 'The national average annual compensation per environmental and clean technology job, including benefits, increased 5.3% from 2021 to $101,595 in 2022', "The 3.4% decrease in national GDP in the environmental and clean technology products sector in 2020 coincided with both a 2.4% decrease in direct energy use and a 6.2% decrease in greenhouse gas (GHG) directly emitted during production'"]

title: Government finance statistics, third quarter 2023
summary: The Canadian general government surplus decreased by $3.4 billion to $3.6 billion in Q3 due to expenses rising faster than revenues. The federal government deficit decreased to $5.3 billion, while provincial-territorial governments posted a $0.8 billion deficit. Social security funds had an $8.6 billion surplus. Interest expenses increased by 20.7%, with the federal government spending 10.1% of its revenue on interest. Canadian general government net debt fell by $107.5 billion to $500.4 billion, with net debt-to-GDP ratio declining to 17.5%. Federal government net debt decreased by 7.1%, while provincial-territorial net debt increased slightly by 1.7%.
quotes: ["'Higher compensation of employees and interest charges were the main contributors to the increase in expenses.", "With the federal government's revenue increasing 7.0% year over year, the ratio of interest expense to revenue rose significantly to 10.1% in the third quarter, compared with 7.9% a year earlier.", "Canadian general government net debt as a percentage of GDP continued its downward trend, reaching 17.5% at the end of the third.'"]

title: National tourism indicators, third quarter 2023
summary: In Canada's third quarter, tourism spending modestly grew by 0.5%, with a notable 2.3% increase from foreign tourists but a 0.2% decline in domestic tourism demand. Air transport spending was the largest contributor to this growth. Despite this, tourism GDP slightly decreased by 0.1%, with accommodation services seeing the most significant decline. The overall economy's GDP fell by 0.3%, but tourism's share of GDP remained stable at 1.67%. Employment in tourism sectors marginally rose by 0.1%, with job gains in non-tourism and transportation industries, while food and beverage, as well as accommodation sectors, experienced job losses. International visitor spending rose, driven by non-tourism products and accommodation, while domestic tourism spending fell, influenced by decreases in food, beverage, and accommodation spending, despite an increase in air transport spending.
quotes: ["'Tourism spending by international visitors increases", "Tourism spending in Canada by Canadians decreases'"]

title: Oil Pipeline Financial Survey, 2022
summary: In 2022, the Canadian energy sector experienced a 20.9% increase in operating revenues, reaching $17.9 billion, driven by heightened global demand and economic recovery post-COVID-19. Operating expenses also rose by 21.5% to $10.2 billion, leading to a net revenue of $7.7 billion, a 20.0% increase. Net income after taxes surged by 58.4% to $5.8 billion. Crude oil prices were up by 49.0%, with Canadian crude oil production and exports increasing by 2.3% and 2.2%, respectively. Total assets for pipeline companies grew by 1.3% to $74.8 billion, with a slight rise in net fixed assets and a 13.9% increase in current assets. Total investment decreased by 1.2%, while long-term debt rose by 1.8%. Total liabilities, capital stock, and surplus also increased by 1.3%.

title: Survey Methodology, December 2023
summary: The December 2023 issue of Survey Methodology includes 18 papers, featuring the Waksberg invited paper series on the missing information principle for messy survey data. It also honors Professor Jean-Claude Deville with special papers and comments on his significant contributions to survey theory and official statistics. Topics at the 2021 Colloque francophone sur les sondages include statistical methods for cross-classified populations, burden control in surveys, data integration, and determinantal sampling designs. Regular papers cover a range of subjects such as design-based prediction, multimode survey designs, undercoverage in non-probability samples, Bayesian small area models, and strategies for dealing with classification errors and stratification in payment population investigations.

title: Gross domestic expenditures on research and development, 2021 (final), 2022 (preliminary) and 2023 (intentions)
summary: In 2021, Canada's R&D expenditures surged by 9.3% to $46.9 billion, with Ontario, Quebec, British Columbia, and Alberta leading the growth. The business enterprise sector drove this increase, particularly in software R&D, rising by $2.6 billion to $21.8 billion. Despite a decline in federal government spending, the business and higher education sectors performed 93.6% of all R&D. Natural sciences and engineering R&D jumped by $3.9 billion, while social sciences, humanities, and arts rose by $92.0 million. However, Canada's R&D intensity fell to 1.86% of GDP, ranking it 19th in the OECD and below the G7 average. Early estimates suggest a continued rise in R&D spending to $49.1 billion in 2023.

title: Annual Wholesale Trade - Commodities, 2022
summary: In 2022, the top five commodity subclasses represented 51.8% of total wholesale sales in Canada, an increase from 47.5% in 2021. The largest subclass was petroleum and petroleum products, accounting for 31.4% of sales, marking a significant rise of 48.0% from the previous year. The Annual Wholesale Trade Survey categorizes sales using the North American Product Classification System, encompassing a diverse range of goods from both durable and non-durable sectors.

title: Economic outlook among businesses majority-owned by racialized individuals from the Canadian Survey on Business Conditions, fourth quarter 2023
summary: The "Canadian Survey on Businesses Conditions" reveals that in Q4 2023, businesses majority-owned by racialized individuals faced more challenges than the broader private sector, particularly in loan repayment, debt, and profitability, with 48.4% expecting decreased profitability vs. 37.7% of all businesses. Despite this, both groups similarly anticipated rising interest rates and debt costs as obstacles. Racialized majority-owned businesses were less likely to encounter labor-related issues. Majority-ownership is self-reported and pertains to private sector businesses with 51% or more ownership.
quotes: ["'just under half (48.4%) of businesses majority-owned by racialized individuals expected a decrease in profitability over the next three months, compared with 37.7% of all private sector businesses'"]

title: Concerns with misinformation online, 2023
summary: In 2023, 59% of Canadians expressed high concern about online misinformation, with concern rising with age, education, and income. Women and men showed equal levels of concern, but those aged 15-19 were the least worried. Difficulty in distinguishing true from false information has increased for 43% of Canadians, with 96% having fact-checked at some point. Regular fact-checking is more common among those who find it harder to discern the truth. Older adults, despite being more concerned, are less likely to fact-check, potentially due to a preference for traditional news sources. Half of Canadians don't fact-check due to disinterest or lack of time, and 8% don't know how to do it. Mistrust in media correlates with higher fact-checking rates, and feelings of hopelessness are linked to more frequent verification of information.
quotes: ['"In 2023, 59% of Canadians said they were very or extremely concerned about any type of misinformation online" \' "43% felt it was getting harder to decipher online truth from fiction compared with three years earlier" \' "66% of Canadians with a college diploma or higher expressed concern" \' "67% for Canadians who earned more than $60,000 a year" \' "43% of Canadians said it was becoming more difficult than it was three years earlier to distinguish between true and false information" \' "Nearly all Canadians (96%) have verified information they encountered" \' "59% regularly fact checked" \' "8% saying they did not know how to fact-check information" \' "55% of Canadians with low levels of trust in media always or often verified information" \' "59% who felt feelings of hopelessness regularly verified news and information"']

title: Canadian System of Environmental–Economic Accounts: Energy use and greenhouse gas emissions, 2021
summary: From 2009 to 2021, Canada's GDP grew by 2.0% annually, while industrial GHG emissions decreased by 0.2% per year. The economy expanded by 26.8% from 2009 to 2019, with industrial energy use and GHG emissions increasing by 9.9% and 4.8%, respectively. The COVID-19 pandemic led to an 8.4% reduction in industrial energy use and a 9.3% drop in GHG emissions in 2020, followed by a slight rebound in 2021. The oil and gas extraction industry remained the top energy user and GHG emitter, accounting for 18.6% of energy use and 23.2% of GHG emissions in 2021. Households consumed 22.0% of total energy and were responsible for 16.1% of GHG emissions, with per capita household emissions decreasing to 3.0 tonnes. GHG emission sources varied by province, with oil and gas extraction being the largest in Alberta (51.2% of emissions) and households being the primary emitters in several provinces.

title: Annual Survey of Manufacturing Industries, 2022
summary: In 2022, Canadian manufacturing revenue grew by 17.4% to $922.4 billion, with goods manufactured contributing $866.7 billion. Most subsectors saw increases, led by petroleum, coal, transportation equipment, food, fabricated metal, and chemicals. Ontario, Quebec, and Alberta dominated, contributing 85% of the revenue increase. Expenses rose faster than revenue, leading to a slight profitability decline, with costs of materials and supplies up by 21.4%. Petroleum and coal product manufacturing saw the largest growth at 55.3%, reaching $114.4 billion. Transportation equipment manufacturing rebounded by 24.7% to $124.2 billion. Food manufacturing led for the third year, with an 11.9% increase to $147.7 billion. Fabricated metal and chemical manufacturing also saw significant revenue growth due to higher prices.

title: Logging, 2022
summary: In 2022, the Canadian logging industry's revenue rose by 4.6% to $12.4 billion, with a 5.8% increase in revenue from logging activities to $11.4 billion, driven by a 24.1% average price increase for forestry products. Expenses outpaced revenue growth at 6.8%, reaching $11.9 billion, with materials and supplies costs up 8.0% to $5.7 billion and energy-related costs up 25.0%. Salaries and wages slightly increased by 1.9% to $1.8 billion. Quebec led provincial revenue growth at 10.9%, with the top five provinces accounting for 96.5% of national revenue. Expenses represented 96% of total revenue, up from 94% in 2021.
quotes: ["'Total revenue in the logging industry increased 4.6% (+$547.0 million) to $12.4 billion in 2022 compared with 2021", 'Revenue from logging activities—which excludes revenue from other sources, such as secondary business activities—was up 5.8% (+$628.8 million) from 2021', 'The cost of materials and supplies grew 8.0% (+$419.1 million), to reach $5.7 billion, for all logging activities', 'Total salaries and wages for the logging industry increased 1.9% (+$34.2 million) to $1.8 billion in 2022', 'Quebec (+$250.4 million; +10.9%) saw the largest increase', "Manitoba saw the fastest growth of all the provinces (+$23.5 million; +51.5%)'"]

title: Canada's population estimates, third quarter 2023
summary: Canada's population reached 40.5 million on October 1, 2023, marking a record quarterly growth rate since 1957, primarily driven by international migration. In the third quarter, 96% of the growth was due to immigration, with 107,972 new immigrants. Alberta led interprovincial migration gains, while British Columbia faced losses. The total population increase for the first nine months of 2023 surpassed any full-year growth since 1867. The number of non-permanent residents rose by 312,758, the largest quarterly increase since 1971. Immigration is expected to continue as the main growth factor due to aging demographics and lower birth rates.
quotes: ["'Canada's population was estimated at 40,528,396 on October 1, 2023, an increase of 430,635 people (+1.1%) from July 1.", 'This was the highest population growth rate in any quarter since the second quarter of 1957 (+1.2%).', "Canada's total population growth for the first nine months of 2023 (+1,030,378 people) had already exceeded the total growth for any other full-year period since Confederation in 1867.", 'In the third quarter of 2023, the vast majority (96.0%) of the population growth was due to international migration.', 'Canada welcomed 107,972 immigrants in the third quarter.', "From January to September 2023, immigration reached 79.8% (371,299) of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada's target of 465,000 immigrants for the year.", 'The total non-permanent resident population increased from 2,198,679 to 2,511,437.', 'This represents a net increase of 312,758 non-permanent residents in the third quarter, which is the greatest quarterly increase going back to 1971.', "Alberta has registered interprovincial migration gains of 10,000 or more for five consecutive quarters for the first time since comparable data were made available (1971).'"]

title: Job vacancies, third quarter 2023
summary: Job vacancies in Canada decreased by 9.0% to 706,100 in Q3 2023, continuing a downward trend for the fifth consecutive quarter, while payroll employment rose by 0.7%. The unemployment-to-job vacancy ratio increased to 1.7, indicating a less tight labor market. The average offered hourly wage grew by 5.8% year-over-year to $25.60, with variations across occupations. Sales and service occupations saw the largest decline in vacancies, down 32.6% year-over-year. Vacancies also decreased across other broad occupational groups, with health occupations experiencing their first annual decline since 2015. The largest decline in vacancies was for positions requiring a high school diploma or less. Regionally, job vacancies decreased in 26 of 69 economic regions, with Ontario, Quebec, and British Columbia seeing the largest drops.

title: College finances in the second year of the pandemic, 2021/2022
summary: In 2021/2022, colleges in Canada reported a $158.8 million surplus, lower than the previous year's $336.1 million. Revenues increased to $14.0 billion, with fee revenues, ancillary revenues, and donations driving this growth. Expenditures rose to $13.8 billion, primarily due to spending on fees, contracted services, building projects, and salaries. Enrolment increases, especially from international students, contributed to higher fee revenues. Product and service-based revenues nearly returned to pre-pandemic levels, and donations hit a record $195.6 million. Federal and provincial funding decreased slightly, with public funding remaining the primary revenue source except in Ontario, where fees, particularly from international students, dominated.
quotes: ["'In 2021/2022, despite the ongoing challenges caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, colleges collectively reported a $158.8 million budget surplus.", 'The increase of $551.2 million in revenues was driven by an increase in college fee revenues (+$285.1 million), ancillary revenues (+$153.4 million) and donations (+$85.2 million), which collectively made up 95.0% of the total increase.', 'Increased enrolments of international college students (+1.0%), whose fees can be as much as four times those of Canadian students, contributed to the 2021/2022 growth in college fee revenue.', 'In 2021/2022, product and service-based revenues increased by 46.2% to reach $4.9 billion, after having dropped almost 50% during the first year of the pandemic.', 'In 2021/2022, donations grew by 77.3%, reaching a record high of $195.6 million.', 'In 2021/2022, Newfoundland and Labrador reported the largest increase in federal funding (+139.4%), attributable to a $1.8 million federal grant allocated over the next five years to establish Technology Access Centres.', 'Public funding made up more than half of all revenues in all provinces and territories, except for Ontario in 2021/2022.', "The Ontario auditor General 2021 public colleges oversight report revealed that nearly 7 in 10 dollars of Ontario's college fees came from foreign students.'"]

title: Earnings and mobility indicators for newly certified journeypersons in Canada, 2021
summary: In 2021, newly certified journeypersons had a median income of $56,160, a 12.2% increase from 2020, marking the highest median income and growth since 2008. This rise occurred alongside a strong demand for skilled tradespeople and tight labor market conditions. Median earnings increased in 22 of the 25 largest Red Seal trades, with significant gains in construction-related trades correlating with increased construction investment and employment, and record-high job vacancies. However, hairstylists, auto body repairers, and early childhood educators had incomes below pre-pandemic levels. Interprovincial mobility remained at its 2020 low of 5.2%, with the majority of migrations to Ontario, British Columbia, and Alberta. Alberta experienced a net out-migration for the fifth consecutive year.

title: National balance sheet and financial flow accounts, third quarter 2023
summary: Household net worth in Canada decreased by $301.2 billion (-1.8%) to $16,168.3 billion in Q3 due to weaker financial and housing markets. Real estate value and equity markets declined, with the S&P 500 Index falling 3.6%. Financial assets dropped by $196.3 billion, non-financial assets by $74.5 billion, and financial liabilities increased by $30.5 billion. The saving rate rose to 5.1%, but currency and deposit growth slowed, and mutual funds saw net redemptions of $2.7 billion. Residential real estate prices dipped by 1.0%, yet housing investment increased due to a 6.5% rise in new construction. Household borrowing rose with mortgage loans jumping to $19.4 billion. The debt service ratio increased to 15.22% as debt payments grew faster than disposable income. Federal government borrowing slowed to $9.5 billion, with a shift towards short-term instruments. Private non-financial corporations' demand for funds rose to $18.5 billion, mainly in bonds. National net worth remained nearly unchanged at $18,352.6 billion, with a slight decrease in national wealth and a marginal increase in net foreign assets.
quotes: ["'Households were less wealthy in the third quarter as their net worth—the value of all assets minus all liabilities—shrank $301.2 billion (-1.8%) to $16,168.3 billion", 'the value of real estate declined after two quarters of recovery', "the Standard and Poor's (S&P) 500 Index falling 3.6% and the S&P/TSX Composite Index declining 3.0%", 'the household saving rate rose to 5.1% on a seasonally adjusted basis in the third quarter', 'households recorded net redemptions in mutual funds of $2.7 billion in the third quarter', 'The value of household residential real estate declined 1.0% (-$85.1 billion) during the third quarter', 'The average resale price of residential homes sold fell 8.3% from the second quarter', 'the pace of seasonally adjusted household credit market borrowing rose as households demanded $24.5 billion in funds', 'the household debt service ratio, measured as total obligated payments of principal and interest on credit market debt as a proportion of household disposable income, rose to 15.22% in the third quarter', 'the federal government borrowed $9.5 billion in bonds and treasury bills, a notable shift from the $28.2 billion recorded in the second quarter', 'The Bank of Canada continued its quantitative tightening program in the third quarter', 'The ratio of federal government net financial liabilities to gross domestic product decreased from 32.7% in the second quarter to 32.3% in the third quarter', 'The demand for funds by private non-financial corporations increased to $18.5 billion in the third quarter from $8.7 billion in the second quarter', 'The demand for funds in Canada was $96.6 billion in the third quarter, a drop from $183.9 billion in the previous quarter', "National net worth, the sum of national wealth and Canada's net foreign asset position, remained nearly unchanged, at $18,352.6 billion (-$7.7 billion) in the third quarter'"]

title: Census of Environment: Resource-based communities, 2016 and 2021
summary: In 2021, approximately 1% of Canadians lived in resource-based communities, relying heavily on local ecosystems for their livelihoods. Economic dependence on resources was highest in agriculture-based communities (37.8%), followed by forestry (29.9%) and fishing (29.7%), with all sectors seeing a decline since 2016. Residents of these communities often have lower educational attainment and a higher proportion of seniors compared to provincial averages. Additionally, linguistic differences are notable, with higher percentages of minority official language speakers in resource-based communities than in the broader provincial population, indicating potential vulnerability to ecosystem changes.

title: Environmental taxes in Canada, 2020
summary: In Canada, environmental taxes reached $26 billion in 2020, a 7.2% decrease from 2019, largely due to the COVID-19 economic slowdown. Energy taxes comprised 76.8% of this revenue, with the carbon tax share growing to 27.6% following the Greenhouse Gas Pollution Pricing Act. Transportation taxes accounted for 19.9%, while natural resources and pollution taxes were minor contributors. The industry sector was the largest payer at 53.4%, with households contributing 46.2%. Ontario (34.3%), Quebec (19.2%), British Columbia (15.9%), and Alberta (14.3%) were the top provincial contributors to environmental taxes.
quotes: ["'The energy tax category represents three-quarters of environmental tax revenue", 'The majority of environmental tax revenue comes from the industry sector', "Ontario accounts for the largest share of environmental taxes'"]

title: Employer pension plans (trusteed pension funds), second quarter 2023
summary: In Q2, Canadian trusteed pension funds' assets remained near $2.2 trillion, slightly down by 0.2% from the previous quarter but up 5.1% year over year. Equities and infrastructure assets grew, while real estate declined. Net income was positive at $22.9 billion, a significant increase from the previous year's loss. Domestic assets decreased by $9.6 billion, whereas foreign assets increased by $6.7 billion quarterly and $96.8 billion annually. Public sector assets dropped by $6.8 billion, while private sector assets grew by $2.0 billion. Public sector funds represent 79.3% of total assets, a slight decrease from the previous year.

title: Canada's international investment position, third quarter 2023
summary: Canada's net foreign asset position slightly increased by $5.5 billion to $1,382.4 billion in the third quarter, despite market price declines. Exchange rate fluctuations led to a $48.8 billion increase in asset values, while market price changes resulted in a $52.6 billion decrease. Canadian assets abroad were 53.9% more valuable than foreign investments in Canada, with international assets growing by 0.7% to $8,424.1 billion. International liabilities also rose by 0.7% to $7,041.6 billion. Canada's gross external debt increased by 2.1% to $3,942.3 billion, mainly due to the financial sector's activities, with the government sector's debt decreasing. Gross external debt as a percentage of GDP edged up to 135.8%.

title: Specialized design services, 2022
summary: In 2022, specialized design services in the housing sector saw an 11.9% increase in operating revenue, reaching $4.3 billion. Interior design services led the industry with 47.1% of sales, while graphic design services contributed 26.8%. The share of sales to individuals rose to 38.5%, while sales to businesses fell to 44.9%. Operating expenses climbed by 14.9% to $3.4 billion, with salaries and benefits reaching $1.0 billion. Profit margins decreased from 24.2% to 22.1%. However, 2023 is expected to see a slowdown due to economic constraints and higher interest rates, potentially dampening the momentum of interior design services.

title: Survey on COVID-19 and Mental Health, February to May 2023
summary: The Survey on COVID-19 and Mental Health (SCMH) indicates mental health improvements in Canada post-pandemic, with increases in adults reporting excellent or very good mental health (57%), strong community belonging (62%), and high life satisfaction (54%) compared to 2021. However, rates of moderate to severe depression, anxiety, and PTSD symptoms remain unchanged at about one in four adults. Young adults, Indigenous people, and 2SLGBTQ+ individuals report higher prevalence of these symptoms, with young adults showing 33% for depression, 25% for anxiety, and 15% for PTSD; 2SLGBTQ+ adults at 45% for depression, 35% for anxiety, and 19% for PTSD; and Indigenous people at 29% for depression, 24% for anxiety, and 16% for PTSD.
quotes: ["'Perceived mental health, sense of belonging and life satisfaction all show significant improvements, compared with two years earlier", 'Symptoms of depression, anxiety and posttraumatic stress disorder remain high', "High prevalence of depression, anxiety and posttraumatic stress disorder among young adults, Indigenous people and 2SLGBTQ+ individuals'"]

title: Maple products, 2023
summary: In 2023, Canadian maple syrup production plummeted by 40.1% to 10.4 million gallons, with all maple-producing provinces affected, especially Quebec, which saw a 41.3% drop to 9.4 million gallons. This decline was attributed to adverse weather conditions, including severe storms and temperature fluctuations. Ontario's production decreased by 14.9% to 502,000 gallons due to a delayed season in the north, despite an extended season in the south. New Brunswick also experienced a 35.0% reduction. Exports fell by 8.7% to 7.7 million gallons in the first three quarters of 2023 compared to the previous year.

title: Annual wholesale trade, 2022
summary: In 2022, Canadian wholesalers saw a 21.2% increase in operating revenue to $1.6 trillion, largely driven by a 47.3% rise in the petroleum subsector. Gross margins decreased from 16.9% to 15.8%, with operating profits slightly down to 5.4%. The machinery subsector also saw a significant revenue increase of 12.7%. Gross margins varied, with the highest in machinery (26.5%) and household goods (25.0%). All provinces reported revenue growth, with Ontario and Alberta contributing most to the $278.3 billion national increase. Alberta's growth was predominantly due to a 40.6% rise in petroleum revenue.

title: Changes in language behaviour at home according to the Canadian Social Survey
summary: In Canada, 15.5% of individuals who spoke a non-official language at home have shifted to speaking an official language (English or French) within five years, with immigrants accounting for a significant portion of this change. Immigrants make up 12% of the population but represent 31% of the linguistic shifts at home. Recent immigrants are more likely to adopt an official language, with 23% of those who were abroad five years ago now using one. Language changes are more common among those who initially spoke a minority official language at home, with 13% of such French speakers outside Quebec and 6.7% of English speakers in Quebec adopting the majority language. Younger Canadians (15-34 years old) are more likely to change their home language, with around 8% doing so, compared to 2.3% of those 55 and older.
quotes: ["'Close to one in six Canadians who only spoke a non-official language most often at home five years prior to the survey have since begun using an official language", 'Roughly 13% of immigrants who spoke only a non-official language most often at home began using an official language five years preceding the survey', 'Approximately 23% of immigrants who spoke only a non-official language most often at home and were living in another country five years prior to the survey have since made a change to their language behaviour', 'In Canada, one-third of the changes to language behaviours at home involved adding a language spoken equally to the one already spoken most often at home five years prior to the survey', "People aged 15 to 34 are more likely to have changed the language or languages they spoke most often at home'"]

title: New motor vehicle registrations, third quarter 2023
summary: In Q3 2023, Canadian new vehicle registrations rose by 16.1% year-over-year to 457,836, with vans (+65.7%), multi-purpose vehicles (+26.7%), and pickup trucks (+5.7%) leading the growth, while passenger cars declined by 8.3%. Zero-emission vehicle (ZEV) registrations hit 12.1% of total new vehicles, a significant increase from 8.7% in Q3 2022. Plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs) surged by 170.1%, and battery electric vehicles (BEVs) by 43.9%. Quebec, Ontario, and British Columbia led in ZEV registrations, with over one in five new vehicles in Quebec being a ZEV. All provinces saw an increase in new ZEV registrations, with Prince Edward Island (+115.1%) and New Brunswick (+109.5%) experiencing the highest growth.
quotes: ["'New zero-emission vehicle registrations surpass 10% of new motor vehicle registrations", "Over one in five new vehicles registered in Quebec is a zero-emission vehicle'"]

title: Experiences of Canadians with long-term symptoms following COVID-19
summary: The study on long-term COVID-19 symptoms in Canada reveals that 64.4% of adults have had at least one infection by June 2023, with 11.7% experiencing long-term symptoms. Over half of those with long-term symptoms still suffer from them, with 79.3% enduring symptoms for six months or more. Daily life is often or always limited for 21.7% of those affected. Alarmingly, 66.4% of adults seeking healthcare for long-term symptoms report inadequate care. This data underscores the pandemic's enduring impact on public health and healthcare systems.
quotes: ["'Nearly one in five Canadian adults have had more than one known or suspected COVID-19 infection", 'About one in nine of all Canadian adults have experienced long-term symptoms from a COVID-19 infection', 'Over half (58.2%) of Canadian adults who ever had long-term symptoms continued to experience these symptoms up to June 2023', 'About 7 in 10 Canadian adults with long-term symptoms experienced them on a daily or nearly daily basis', "Two-thirds of Canadian adults who sought healthcare services for their long-term symptoms reported not receiving adequate care for any of their symptoms'"]

title: Canadian Housing Statistics Program: First-time homebuyers, 2020
summary: In 2020, there was a significant increase in first-time homebuyers across various regions, with British Columbia seeing a 28% rise. These buyers are often more vulnerable to affordability issues, especially with potential mortgage rate increases upon renewal. While the median family income of first-time buyers generally rose slower than the median sale prices, British Columbia and Manitoba were exceptions. First-time buyers in British Columbia paid $100,000 less than repeat buyers, largely due to the types of properties purchased, with a higher share opting for condominiums and row houses, whereas in Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Manitoba, they paid more, often buying single-detached houses in urban areas.
quotes: ['"In British Columbia, the number of first-time homebuyers reached 25,315, which represented a 28.0% increase from 2019" \' "First-time homebuyers who opened five-year mortgages at fixed rates of around 2% in 2020 could be renewing at a much higher rate in 2025" \' "In Nova Scotia, the number of first-time homebuyers rose to 5,830 in 2020, up 21.0% from 2019" \' "In Manitoba, there were 9,180 first-time homebuyers, a 24.1% increase" \' "In Nova Scotia, the median family income of first-time homebuyers increased by 10.5% from 2019 to 2020, while the median price of the properties they purchased increased by 13.0%" \' "In British Columbia, the two indicators experienced a similar evolution, each increasing by 9.1% from 2019 to 2020" \' "In British Columbia, first-time homebuyers paid a median price of $530,000, which was $100,000 less than that paid by repeat buyers" \' "In Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Manitoba, the majority of first-time homebuyers bought single-detached houses" \' "In British Columbia, a higher share (62.5%) of first-time homebuyers bought condominium apartments and row houses"']

title: Industrial capacity utilization rates, third quarter 2023
summary: In the third quarter, Canadian industries operated at 79.7% capacity, a slight increase from 79.6% in the previous quarter. Manufacturing saw a minor rise in capacity utilization to 78.3%, driven by gains in primary metal manufacturing (+2.2 percentage points) and metal product manufacturing (+1.3 percentage points). The mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction sector also increased to 76.7%, with oil and gas extraction up by 2.1% after a natural gas extraction slowdown due to forest fires. However, the electric power generation, transmission, and distribution industry fell by 1.9 percentage points to 79.3%, with a significant 11.6% year-over-year drop in electricity generation in August due to drier conditions.
quotes: ["'Canadian industries operated at 79.7% of their production capacity in the third quarter, up slightly from 79.6% in the second quarter.", 'The capacity utilization rate in the manufacturing sector edged up 0.3 percentage points to 78.3% in the third quarter.', 'Capacity utilization in the mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction sector increased 0.9 percentage points to 76.7% in the third quarter.', "According to Energy statistics, total electricity generation in Canada fell 11.6% year over year in August, attributable to drier conditions or droughts across a large area of the country.'"]

title: Activities of multinational enterprises in Canada and abroad, 2021 (actual) and 2022 (preliminary)
summary: In 2022, multinational enterprises (MNEs) in Canada saw capital investment rise to $197.1 billion, employment increase to nearly 5 million, and merchandise trade exceed $1 trillion. Canadian MNEs outpaced foreign MNEs in capital investment, particularly in non-residential construction in Alberta and British Columbia. Employment at MNEs surpassed pre-pandemic levels, with notable growth in the professional, scientific, technical, and manufacturing sectors. Merchandise trade by MNEs surged, with significant imports by foreign MNEs from related parties and substantial exports from Alberta's energy sector. Sales by Canadian MNEs abroad reached over $1 trillion, with faster growth domestically, driven by the energy and manufacturing sectors.

title: Securities statistics, third quarter 2023
summary: In Q3 2023, Canadian borrowing via debt securities slowed to $30.0 billion, down from $82.0 billion in Q2. Gross issuances hit a high since Q2 2020, offset by record retirements. Total debt securities outstanding rose to $5,656.5 billion, due to net borrowings and Canadian dollar depreciation. 18.8% of debt was US dollar-denominated. Despite a book value increase, market value fell by $50.6 billion due to rising interest rates. Government debt issuances dropped to $12.4 billion, with financial corporations borrowing $9.0 billion and non-financial corporations $8.6 billion. Equity security retirements outpaced issuances by $2.9 billion, marking the seventh consecutive quarter of net retirements, with market value falling by $123.4 billion.

title: Labour productivity, hourly compensation and unit labour cost, third quarter 2023
summary: Canadian labour productivity fell by 0.8% in the third quarter, marking the sixth consecutive quarterly decline, with a 0.7% contraction in business output and a slight increase in hours worked. Hours worked edged up by 0.1%, the lowest growth in 13 quarters, with no change in the number of jobs. Productivity decreased in both goods-producing (-0.9%) and services-producing (-0.4%) sectors, with declines in 10 of the 16 main industry sectors. Unit labour costs rose by 1.6%, due to slower growth in compensation and the more pronounced productivity decline. Wildfires in July 2023 slightly impacted hours worked.
quotes: ["'Labour productivity of Canadian businesses decreased 0.8% in the third quarter", 'This was the lowest quarterly growth rate in 13 quarters', 'Productivity falls in both goods-producing and services-producing businesses', "Unit labour costs increased 1.6% in the third quarter'"]
