title: Child care arrangements, 2023
summary: In 2023, 56% of Canadian children aged 0-5 were in child care, below the pre-pandemic level of 60%. Centre-based care attendance increased to 34%, surpassing 2019 rates, while home-based care usage remained lower at 9%. Most provinces and territories returned to pre-pandemic child care participation rates, except Ontario. Parents reporting difficulty finding child care rose from 36% in 2019 to 49% in 2023, with availability being the top challenge. Twenty-six percent of children not in child care were on waitlists. The main reason for not using child care was parental preference to stay home (35%). Average monthly child care expenses decreased to $544 in 2023 from $649 in 2022, with variations based on age, type of care, and location.

title: Sexual misconduct in the Canadian Armed Forces, 2022
summary: In 2022, 3.5% of Canadian Armed Forces Regular Force members reported sexual assault, a rise from 1.6% in 2018. Women experienced higher rates (7.5%) than men (2.8%). Most victims (64%) didn't report the assault, with 41% believing it wouldn't make a difference. Experiences of sexualized or discriminatory behaviors increased to 19%, with women more affected. Bystander intervention improved, with over half intervening in 2022. Despite positive perceptions of unit responses to sexual misconduct, only 66% felt the CAF holds perpetrators accountable, and 61% saw sexual misconduct as a problem within the CAF.

title: Registered apprenticeship training programs, 2022
summary: In 2022, Canadian apprenticeship registrations rose by 11.6% to 81,141, the highest since 2014, while certifications slightly declined by 0.8% to 46,777. New registrations for trades like carpenters, heavy-duty equipment mechanics, and electricians exceeded pre-pandemic levels, while community service workers and food service trades lagged. Alberta saw a 51% increase in new registrations, with Quebec reaching a record high of 24,723. Despite this, certifications remained below pre-pandemic levels, particularly in service sector trades affected by COVID-19. However, Ontario saw an increase in certifications, driven by electricians and millwrights, surpassing its 2019 numbers.

title: Scotiabank, BMO brace for higher impaired loans as interest rates weigh on consumers
summary: Scotiabank and Bank of Montreal reported higher provisions for credit losses than expected due to economic challenges, with Scotiabank setting aside $962 million and BMO $627 million. Both banks anticipate interest rate cuts later this year, which could provide relief. Scotiabank's impaired loan provisions were mainly for personal loans, while BMO saw higher delinquencies in credit cards and personal loans. Economic growth expectations in Canada and the U.S. differ, with Scotiabank focusing on Latin America for growth. Scotiabank beat earnings expectations, while BMO missed them due to a slump in capital markets profit. Both banks are undergoing strategic changes, with Scotiabank aiming to increase its deposit base and BMO integrating Bank of the West to expand its U.S. presence.
quotes: "As consumers and businesses grapple with higher interest rates and inflation, the risk of loan losses has risen across the banks, prompting the lenders to hike provisions which crimp profit growth."

title: Ottawa will shut down shady post-secondary institutions if provinces don’t, Miller says
summary: Immigration Minister Marc Miller has warned that the federal government may intervene to close problematic private colleges exploiting the international student program if provincial action is insufficient. With over 900,000 foreign students in Canada, a threefold increase from a decade ago, the government is scrutinizing the program and has capped new study permits. Concerns have been raised about institutions using the program as a shortcut to permanent residency. The government plans to distinguish reputable institutions and may shut down those failing to meet standards. Notably, asylum claims by international students at certain colleges have surged, which Miller deems "alarming" and "totally unacceptable."
quotes: "More than 900,000 foreign students had visas to study in Canada last year, which is more than three times the number a decade ago"

title: National Travel Survey, third quarter 2023
summary: In Q3 2023, Canadian residents took 99.7 million trips, a 3.0 million increase from Q3 2022, with 91.1% being domestic. Domestic travel spending was $27.5 billion, slightly up from 2022 and a 27.1% increase from pre-pandemic 2019. Trips to the US rose by 24.9% to 6.9 million, with expenditures reaching $6.1 billion, surpassing 2022 and 2019 figures. Overseas trips were 2.0 million, with a 37.3% spending increase from 2022. The UK, Italy, and France were top destinations. Cruise spending grew to $121.0 million, 21.6% above pre-pandemic levels.

title: Visitor Travel Survey, third quarter 2023
summary: In the third quarter of 2023, Canada saw 10.5 million visitors, 83.9% of 2019's Q3 figures, with 77.8% from the US. Tourist spending reached $10.1 billion, a 6.7% increase from 2019, largely due to a 17.8% rise in US visitor spending. US residents made 8.1 million trips, 85.9% of 2019's Q3 levels, spending $5.4 billion, with Ontario being the top destination. Overseas visitors accounted for 2.3 million trips, spending $4.7 billion. British Columbia garnered the highest share of overseas spending at 34.1%. Accommodation and food were the main expenses for both US and overseas visitors.

title: Non-residential capital and repair expenditures, 2022 (revised), 2023 (preliminary) and 2024 (intentions)
summary: Capital expenditures on non-residential tangible capital assets are projected to rise by 4.5% to $353.9 billion in 2024, marking a fourth consecutive annual increase. The mining, quarrying, and oil and gas extraction sector is expected to grow by 4.8% to $61.0 billion, despite a 2.7% decrease in mines and quarries. Saskatchewan is leading growth with a $1.7 billion increase. Manufacturing sector investments are set to surge by 31.0% to $36.2 billion, driven by government-supported projects in decarbonization and clean energy. Public sector investments are anticipated to reach $131.8 billion, with significant contributions from public administration and utilities. Capital spending on Canadian infrastructure rose by 13.4% to $122.6 billion in 2022, with significant growth in transport and electricity functions.

title: Online hate and aggression among young people in Canada
summary: In Canada, 84% of young people aged 15 to 24 encountered online misinformation in 2022, with 71% seeing content that could incite hate or violence, higher than the national average. Young Canadians with disabilities are 2.5 times more likely to encounter daily hate content. Cyber-related hate crimes reported to police increased from 92 in 2018 to 219 in 2022, with 82% being violent. Victims of cyber-related hate crimes are often youth aged 12 to 17, with teenage boys six times more likely to be charged. Young women are particularly targeted by online harassment, with 11% pressured into sharing explicit content and 25% receiving unsolicited explicit messages. Cyberaggression is linked to other victimizations and can impact mental health and community cohesion.

title: Wholesale trade: Early indicator, January 2024
summary: January 2024 advance estimates indicate a 0.6% decrease in Canadian wholesale sales, excluding certain energy and agricultural products. The decline was particularly significant in the building materials and supplies subsector. The preliminary figures are based on a 55.5% response rate, lower than the 75.8% average of the past year, which may lead to higher revisions. Notable changes in subsectors include a 6.2% drop in farm products, a 3.9% decrease in building materials, and a 3.1% increase in machinery and equipment supplies.

title: International trade in environmental and clean technology products by origin and destination, 2022
summary: In 2022, Canada's exports of environmental and clean technology (ECT) products were valued at $20.9 billion, 2.2% of total exports, with a trade deficit of $4.2 billion. The U.S. was the primary export destination, receiving 77.7% of these exports, mainly environmental products and clean technology goods. Europe and Asia followed, with significant exports to the UK, the Netherlands, Norway, and China. Canada imported $25.1 billion worth of ECT products, 2.6% of total imports, predominantly from the U.S. (73.5%), with major imports being clean technology goods and biofuels. Asia and Europe were other key import sources, with China, Japan, South Korea, Germany, and the UK as notable partners.

title: Canadian Survey on Business Conditions, first quarter 2024
summary: In November 2023, Canada's real GDP grew by 0.2%, with inflation at 2.9% year over year in January 2024, and unemployment dropping to 5.7%. The Canadian Survey on Business Conditions indicates that 73.6% of businesses expect cost-related obstacles, with rising inflation (55.4%) and input costs (43.7%) as primary concerns. Interest rates impact 72.1% of businesses, with 26.5% reporting a high impact. Labour-related obstacles are expected by 39.4% of businesses, with skilled employee recruitment (29.5%) being the top challenge. Only 13.9% of businesses are using or plan to use generative AI. Business outlook remains optimistic, with 68.4% feeling positive about the next 12 months. Supply chain challenges are expected by 16.1% of businesses, with 37.3% reporting higher revenues in 2023 than in 2022. Finally, 71.6% of businesses do not plan to seek debt financing, with 50.2% citing unfavorable interest rates as a deterrent.

title: Half of adults sentenced to provincial correctional programs were reconvicted within three years, mostly for non-violent offences
summary: In 2015/2016, half of the adults released from custody or starting community supervision across five Canadian provinces were reconvicted within three years. The reconviction rate was higher for those with custodial sentences (66%) compared to community supervision (40%). The study found that reconvictions were mostly for non-violent offenses, with administration of justice offenses being the most common. Young men aged 18 to 34 had the highest reconviction rates. Indigenous individuals were more likely to be reconvicted than non-Indigenous, with a 30% higher likelihood on average. The study also found that Black individuals had a similar reconviction rate to White individuals, with an 8% lower risk when adjusted for various factors. Factors contributing to over-representation in the criminal justice system, such as historical and systemic issues, were not analyzed in this study.
quotes: 'Half of adults sentenced to custody or community supervision were reconvicted within three years' 'The risk of reconviction was highest in the first three months' 'Young men had the highest incidence of reconviction' 'Most of those in the cohort with 10 or more prior convictions were reconvicted within three years' 'Indigenous people in the cohort were more likely to be reconvicted than non-Indigenous people' 'Breaking the cycle of administration of justice convictions could help reduce the gap in reconvictions between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people' 'Nearly the same proportion of Black people were reconvicted as White people'

title: Travel between Canada and other countries, December 2023
summary: In December 2023, non-resident visits to Canada reached 91% of pre-pandemic levels, with Canadian residents' returns at 87.7%. Overseas trips to Canada were at 95% of December 2019 levels, with European visitors nearly fully recovered. US residents took 1.5 million trips to Canada, 89.8% of December 2019 figures. Canadian residents made 2.8 million trips to the US, 84.2% of 2019 levels, and returned from 989,700 overseas trips, nearly matching pre-pandemic numbers. Overall, 2023 saw a significant recovery in travel, with 74.5 million international arrivals to Canada, 84.1% of 2019's total, and the cruise industry showing strong resilience.

title: Livestock estimates, January 1, 2024
summary: Canadian livestock inventories as of January 1, 2024, show declines across cattle, hogs, and sheep compared to the previous year. The cattle herd is at its lowest since 1989, down 2.1% to 11.1 million, despite increased carcass weights since 1999. Breeding stock and calves also decreased. Hog inventories fell by 1.0% to 13.8 million, with notable reductions in Quebec. Sows, gilts, and boars declined, while hog slaughter and exports rose. Sheep and lamb inventories decreased by 2.2% to 828,300, with reductions in the breeding herd and market lambs. Sheep and lamb slaughter and exports also dropped.

title: Spectator sports, event promoters, artists and related industries, 2022
summary: In 2022, the spectator sports, event promoters, artists, and related industries subsector saw a 51.6% increase in operating revenue to $11.1 billion, surpassing pre-pandemic levels by 5.5%. title: Quarterly financial statistics for enterprises, fourth quarter 2023
summary: Canadian corporations saw a 2.7% increase in net income before taxes (NIBT) in Q4, reaching $165.4 billion, with the financial sector's 6.8% rise outpacing the non-financial sector's 1.2% growth. Non-financial industries' NIBT rose by $1.4 billion to $118.0 billion, led by gains in the wholesalers, telecommunications, and wood and paper manufacturing industries. However, declines were noted in motor vehicle and trailer manufacturing due to production slowdowns and strikes, as well as in petroleum and coal products manufacturing due to lower energy prices and refinery maintenance. The financial sector's NIBT increased by $3.0 billion, with significant growth in securities, commodity exchanges, and credit unions, but a decrease in banking due to higher credit loss provisions.

title: Retail trade, December 2023
summary: In December, Canadian retail sales rose by 0.9% to $67.3 billion, with motor vehicle and parts dealers leading the increase (+1.9%). Core retail sales, excluding gasoline stations and motor vehicle and parts dealers, also increased by 0.5%. The fourth quarter saw a 1.0% rise in retail sales, contributing to a 2.2% annual increase for 2023, primarily driven by motor vehicle and parts dealers. Retail sales increased in eight provinces, with Ontario and British Columbia showing significant gains. E-commerce sales fell by 3.6% in December. The advance estimate for January 2024 indicates a potential 0.4% decrease in retail sales.
quotes: 'Sales were up in five of nine subsectors and were led by increases at motor vehicle and parts dealers (+1.9%)' 'Core retail sales—which exclude gasoline stations and fuel vendors and motor vehicle and parts dealers—were up 0.5% in December' 'Retail sales were up 1.0% in the fourth quarter of 2023, marking a second consecutive quarterly increase' 'In 2023, retail sales increased 2.2%, led by gains at motor vehicle and parts dealers' 'The largest increase in retail sales in December was observed at motor vehicle and parts dealers (+1.9%), up for a fourth consecutive month' 'The gain in December was led by higher sales at new car dealers (+2.4%)' 'Core retail sales increased 0.5% in December, led by higher sales at general merchandise retailers (+2.8%) and food and beverage retailers (+1.5%)' 'Retail sales increased in eight provinces in December, led by higher sales in Ontario (+1.3%) and, to a lesser extent, British Columbia (+1.5%)' 'On a seasonally adjusted basis, retail e-commerce sales were down 3.6% to $3.7 billion in December' 'Canadian retailers finished 2023 with $794.4 billion in sales, up 2.2% from 2022' 'Leading the gain in retail sales in 2023 were higher sales at motor vehicle and parts dealers (+7.0%)' 'Core retail sales increased 2.4% in 2023, led by higher sales at food and beverage retailers (+3.7%) and health and personal care retailers (+8.6%)' 'Statistics Canada is providing an advance estimate of retail sales, which suggests that sales decreased 0.4% in January 2024'

title: Employment Insurance, December 2023
summary: In December, the number of Canadians receiving Employment Insurance (EI) benefits rose by 1.4% to 464,000, a 14.8% increase from the previous year. The unemployment rate remained steady at 5.8%. Core-aged men and women saw increases in EI beneficiaries, with a 20.2% year-over-year rise for core-aged men and a 15.5% increase for core-aged women. Ontario and Alberta led the increase in EI recipients among provinces, with Ontario experiencing a 32.0% year-over-year increase. Windsor, Ontario had the largest local increase. British Columbia was the only province with a notable decrease in EI recipients in December.
quotes: 'The number of regular Employment Insurance beneficiaries rose in four provinces in December, led by Ontario and Alberta' - 'Ontario posted the largest proportional increase, followed by Alberta, Manitoba and New Brunswick' - 'The number of regular EI recipients increased by 34,000 (+32.0%) in Ontario, the largest proportional increase among the provinces' - 'In Alberta, the number of regular EI beneficiaries rose by 1,500 (+3.1%) in December, marking the third consecutive monthly increase'
file_1: Employment, Future Workforce Development and Disability Inclusion

title: Railway carloadings, December 2023
summary:
In December, Canadian railways saw an 11.2% increase in freight transport compared to the previous year, carrying 31.7 million tonnes. Non-intermodal freight rose by 10.2%, with significant shipments of potash, iron ores, and energy products. Intermodal freight grew by 9.4% to 2.8 million tonnes, marking the first increase since November 2022. American railway loadings also rose by 21.0% to 3.5 million tonnes.

For 2023, Canadian rail freight totaled 375.1 million tonnes, a 2.4% increase from 2022. Early growth was driven by agricultural shipments, particularly grains. Disruptions and lower yields later in the year were offset by a strong finish, with non-intermodal loadings up 4.4% and intermodal down 7.6%. Freight from the US decreased by 2.2%.

Key commodity shifts included record wheat loadings, up 30.2%, and increases in canola and potash. However, fuel oils and crude petroleum loadings continued to decline, dropping by 13.4%.
quotes: 'Canadian railways transported 31.7 million tonnes of freight in December, up 11.2% from December 2022' 'This was the second straight month of year-over-year growth and the largest increase in tonnage since January 2023' 'Higher shipments of potash, iron ores and some energy products more than offset a continued decline in some agricultural and food products, notably grain' 'Intermodal freight loadings in Canada (mainly containers) increased 9.4% year over year to 2.8 million tonnes in December' 'Loadings from American railways have increased year over year for five straight months, up 21.0% to 3.5 million tonnes in December' 'The total annual rail freight carried in Canada during 2023 was 375.1 million tonnes, up 2.4% from 2022 levels' 'During the first few months of 2023, rail freight volumes were consistently above 2022 totals with growth driven by considerable increases in carloadings of agricultural and food products, notably grains' 'From May 2023 onward, total freight carried by Canadian railways began to lag 2022 levels' 'Despite these disruptions and lower crop yields on the Prairies during 2023, freight traffic was higher in the last two months of the year' 'Compared with 2022, non-intermodal freight loadings in Canada increased 4.4% to 296.0 million tonnes in 2023, while intermodal freight traffic was down 7.6% to 34.0 million tonnes' 'Freight traffic coming from the US rail connections saw an annual decline for the first time since 2020, dipping 2.2% from 2022 to 45.0 million tonnes in 2023' 'Leading the way was wheat, with loadings of 26.5 million tonnes, up 30.2% (or +6.1 million tonnes) from 2022 levels—the largest annual increase ever recorded' 'Similarly, loadings of canola increased 22.1%, from 6.7 million tonnes in 2022 to 8.2 million tonnes in 2023, while potash was up 5.5%, reaching 24.3 million tonnes' 'Other large increases were reported for coal, with loadings up 6.2% from 2022 to 39.7 million tonnes in 2023' 'Loadings of fuel oils and crude petroleum decreased for the fourth consecutive year, down sharply (-13.4%) to 10.5 million tonnes in 2023'

title: What contributed to the slowdown of investment in Canada after the mid-2000s?
summary: Canadian firms saw a 20% drop in investment per worker from 2006 to 2021, with large- and medium-sized firms, especially foreign-controlled ones, accounting for the majority of this decline. Investment shifted towards intangible assets, which grew from 8% to 17% of firms' total fixed assets. Concurrently, the entry rate of new firms decreased from 12% in 2006 to 7% in 2021, reducing competition and contributing to lower investment levels. This decline in firm entry and competitive intensity from 2006 to 2019 explains 30% of the investment per worker reduction.
quotes: 'Investment per worker among Canadian firms declined by 20% from 2006 to 2021' 'Large- and medium-sized firms accounted for 90% of the overall decline in investment per worker from 2006 to 2021, much larger than their share of investment' 'Foreign-controlled firms contributed 30% of the decline in investment per worker from 2006 to 2021' 'The share of intangible assets as a portion of total fixed assets on firms' balance sheets increased from 8% in 2006 to 17% in 2021' 'The entry rate—or the percentage of new firms in a year—declined from 12% in 2006 to 7% in 2021' 'The decline in both the rate of firm entry and competitive intensity in the pre-pandemic period from 2006 to 2019 accounted for 30% of the decline in investment per worker during that period'

title: Gender Results Framework: Data table update on federally appointed judges, 2023
summary: The number of women appointed as federal judges in Canada has risen from 526 in 2021 to 548 in 2023, now making up 46.7% of all federally appointed judges, an increase of 2.9 percentage points since 2021. The number of men appointed has declined to 625 in 2023. Most provinces have seen an increase in the proportion of women judges, with significant fluctuations in the territories due to their smaller numbers of judges. The CGDIS provides detailed data on gender representation through the Sex, Gender and Sexual Orientation Statistics Hub, supporting Canada's Disaggregated Data Action Plan.
quotes: 'The total number of women appointed as federal judges has increased from 2021 to 2023' 'Almost half of federally appointed judges in Canada are women' 'The proportion of federal judges who are women has increased in most provinces since 2021' 'The Sex, Gender and Sexual Orientation Statistics Hub features disaggregated data about gender'
file_1: Justice and Attorney General of Canada

title: Millennials now outnumber baby boomers in Canada
summary: Canada's population aging was tempered by increased immigration in 2022 and 2023, leading to a slight decrease in the average age for the first time since 1958. Millennials now outnumber baby boomers, who have been the largest generation for 65 years, with Generation Z also surpassing Generation X. A record number of immigrants, mainly younger adults, has slowed demographic aging, with the average and median ages of the population falling for the first time in 65 years. The working-age population (15 to 64 years) increased slightly, potentially easing labor shortages but also pressuring services and infrastructure. Population aging continues, with those aged 65 and older now outnumbering those under 18. Regional differences persist, with older populations in the Atlantic provinces and younger demographics in the Prairies and territories. The gender balance is nearly even, with a slight recent increase in the male population due to the nature of work permit holders' jobs.
quotes: 'For the first time, the millennial generation (born between 1981 and 1996) comprised a greater number of people in the population than the baby boomer generation (born between 1946 and 1965).' 'From July 1, 2022, to July 1, 2023, the millennial population increased by 457,354, exclusively due to the arrival of permanent and temporary immigrants.' 'This is the first time in 65 years that the mean and median ages of the population have both fallen in the same year.' 'The proportion of the population aged 15 to 64 years increased from July 1, 2022, to July 1, 2023, an uncommon event in recent years.' 'On July 1, 2023, for the first time in Canadian history, there were more people aged 65 years and older (7,568,308) than younger than 18 years (7,497,048).' 'Newfoundland and Labrador continued to be the province with the highest average age (45.7 years) and the highest proportion of people aged 65 years and older (24.4%).' 'Alberta was the first province where millennials outnumbered baby boomers, in 2014.' 'Among NPRs, there were 128.9 men+ for every 100 women+ on July 1, 2023.'

title: Annual retail trade, 2022
summary: In 2022, Canadian retail sales reached $815.5 billion, with $63.7 billion from e-commerce. The main contributors were motor vehicle and parts dealers (25.7%), food and beverage retailers (18.6%), general merchandise retailers (12.2%), and gasoline stations (11.3%). Retail prices rose significantly, with gasoline up 28.5%, store food 9.8%, and passenger vehicles 7.2%. Inflation hit 6.8%, influenced by various factors including geopolitical unrest and supply chain issues. The classification system for retail trade was updated to better reflect the digital economy. Gasoline stations had a net profit margin of 7.7%, while motor vehicle and parts dealers had a margin of 4.7%. Food price inflation led to a shift towards general merchandise retailers, which saw a profit margin of 6.1%. The largest provinces generated 86.5% of the total operating revenue.
quotes: 'Customers spent $815.5 billion at Canadian retailers in 2022, of which $63.7 billion was e-commerce revenue' 'Headline inflation rose to 6.8% in 2022, the fastest growth since 1982' 'Operating revenue of gasoline stations and fuel vendors reached $91.9 billion' 'Sales in the largest subsector—motor vehicle and parts dealers—amounted to $209.4 billion' 'New zero-emission vehicle registrations increased in popularity in 2022, representing an 8.2% share of total new motor vehicle registrations' 'Food price increases accelerated in 2022, and the share of retail food sales at food and beverage retailers began to decline' 'The four largest provinces—Ontario, Quebec, British Columbia and Alberta—accounted for the largest share of operating revenue, representing a combined $705.6 billion (86.5%) of the national total'

title: New Housing Price Index, January 2024
summary: In January, Canadian new home prices dipped by 0.1% with declines or no change in 21 out of 27 surveyed CMAs. Ottawa saw the most significant monthly decrease at 0.4%, marking its 13th consecutive drop. Decreases were also noted in Vancouver, Montréal, and Calgary. Conversely, Edmonton and Trois-Rivières experienced price increases due to higher construction costs and better market conditions. Year-over-year, national new home prices fell by 0.7%, the 10th straight annual decline and the longest streak since 2009. Ottawa had the steepest annual drop at 5.0%, while Québec and Calgary recorded increases of 3.3% and 2.5%, respectively.
quotes: "The largest month-over-month decrease in January was recorded in Ottawa (-0.4%)" - "This marked the 10th consecutive annual decrease recorded and the longest period of consecutive declines since 2009." - "Ottawa (-5.0%) reported the largest year-over-year decline in January" - "The largest annual increases in January were reported in Québec (+3.3%) and Calgary (+2.5%)."

title: Health Reports, February 2024
summary: Health care workers in Canada's long-term care and seniors' homes faced precarious working conditions during the COVID-19 pandemic, with 6.5% experiencing income loss, unpaid leave, or reduced hours. Precarious work was linked to increased stress and poor health, especially among immigrant workers, with immigrant nurses being nearly four times more likely to report stress compared to non-immigrants. The pandemic also affected Canadians' oral health care, with nearly 6% not receiving needed care. About 45% needed routine dental care, but one in five had appointments disrupted. Income disparities were evident in access to dental care, and 23% experienced mouth or teeth pain, with one-third avoiding treatment due to fear of COVID-19.
quotes: 'Work precarity, employment characteristics and health among Canada's long-term care and seniors' home workers during the COVID-19 pandemic' 'Reported need for and access to oral health care services during the COVID-19 pandemic in Canada'

title: Study: Early career quality of employment of Indigenous graduates with a bachelor's degree, 2010 to 2018 cohorts
summary: The Statistics Canada research paper examines the employment quality for Indigenous graduates with a bachelor's degree from 2010 to 2018. It compares First Nations and Métis graduates' employment income, unionization, and pension plan coverage with those of non-Indigenous, non-racialized, Canadian-born counterparts two years post-graduation. The study utilizes data from the Postsecondary Student Information System, 2016 and 2021 Censuses, and the T1 Family File.

title: Consumer Price Index, January 2024
summary: The January CPI rose 2.9% year over year, a deceleration from December's 3.4%, with gasoline prices down 4.0% contributing to the slowdown. Excluding gasoline, the CPI increase was 3.2%. Food price growth from stores also slowed to 3.4% from 4.7%. Airfare prices dropped significantly by 14.3% year over year. Cellular service prices fell 16.4% year over year but rose 6.7% from December. Regionally, Alberta saw faster price growth due to electricity prices, while Saskatchewan experienced a decline in natural gas prices due to the cessation of the carbon levy. Overall, the CPI was unchanged from the previous month and seasonally adjusted it fell by 0.1%.
quotes: 'Year over year, gasoline prices fell 4.0% in January' 'While grocery prices remained elevated, their growth slowed year over year in January (+3.4%) compared with December (+4.7%)' 'Prices for airfares declined in January (-14.3%) compared with December (-9.7%)' 'On a year-over-year basis, prices for cellular services fell 16.4% in January' 'Alberta was the only province with faster price growth, partly due to higher electricity prices in January (+119.9%) compared with December (+22.9%)'

title: Survey of Innovation and Business Strategy, 2020-2022
summary: The innovation rate in Canada declined from 79.8% in 2017-2019 to 71.9% during the pandemic years 2020-2022, with both product and process innovation rates decreasing. Large businesses and those in Ontario remained the most innovative. Innovations with environmental benefits also dropped to 46.5%. COVID-19, lack of skills, and uncertainty were the top obstacles to innovation. Over 40% of businesses reported savings from process innovations, and nearly 40% of product innovators protected their intellectual property. Collaboration for innovation was more common with other businesses than with academic or research institutions. Government support programs increased innovation rates, with 34.1% of businesses using such programs, and tax incentives were considered the most critical.
quotes: 'For product innovators, 5.1% brought new or improved products to market exclusively in response to the pandemic' '46.5% of businesses introduced an innovation with at least one environmental benefit, down from 56.9% in the 2017-to-2019 period' 'COVID-19 (29.4%) was listed as one of the major obstacles to innovation' 'over two in five (41.1%) businesses reported realizing savings in 2022 related to the overall cost of production' 'nearly two in five (38.4%) of these businesses filed or registered the product innovations they developed in Canada to protect their intellectual property' '14.0% of businesses reported cooperating with partners for innovation activities' '34.1% reported using at least one government support program for innovation-related activities, up from 30.5% during the 2017-to-2019 period' 'businesses that leveraged government support for innovation-related activities (83.3%) had a higher innovation rate than those that did not depend on such support (66.0%)'

title: Public and private spending on elementary and secondary schools, 2021/2022
summary: In 2021/2022, Canadian education spending declined by 1.9% in real terms to $89.7 billion due to inflation. Public education expenditures fell by 2.8% to $73.7 billion, with all regions except Prince Edward Island experiencing decreases. The decline followed the end of special federal funding, with spending still 2.1% above 2019/2020 levels. Local revenue from education property tax continued to drop for the fifth year. Quebec set a record with $2.9 billion in capital spending, 49.4% above its five-year average, following a significant infrastructure plan. Ontario also increased capital funding and anticipates further increases in 2022/2023.
quotes: 'In 2021/2022, Canadian elementary and secondary schools encountered a challenging period following the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic' 'Total expenditures for public elementary and secondary education in Canada decreased by 2.8% from the previous year to $73.7 billion in 2021/2022' 'Prince Edward Island was the only province that incurred an increase in public school expenditures in 2021/2022' 'Local taxation has continued to represent a smaller proportion of the total funding for education, marking its fifth consecutive annual decline in 2021/2022' 'In 2021/2022, Quebec reached a record high in capital spending, encompassing expenditures in areas such as new school construction, major renovations, site improvements and equipment purchases' 'Continued increases in capital spending in Ontario are also expected in 2022/2023, as announced in "2023 Ontario Economic Outlook and Fiscal Review: Building a Strong Ontario Together."'

title: Urban public transit, December 2023
summary: In December 2023, Canadian urban transit ridership reached 123.4 million trips, showing significant recovery at 80% of December 2019 levels. Throughout 2023, there were 1.5 billion passenger trips, marking an increase from 1.2 billion in 2022 but still only 77.4% of the 2019 total. Operating revenue in December 2023 was up 25.5% from 2022, yet still below December 2019 by $23.4 million. The pandemic caused ridership to drop below half of 2019 levels in 2020 and 2021. Recovery has been ongoing since late 2021, but despite population growth, largely from international migration, and the resumption of pre-pandemic activities, transit ridership lags behind due to changes in commuting behavior, including the adoption of hybrid work arrangements.
quotes: 'In December 2023, urban transit ridership in Canada reached 123.4 million trips, recovering more than 80% of its December 2019 level, pre-COVID-19 pandemic.' 'In 2023, there were roughly 1.5 billion total passenger trips taken, up from the 1.2 billion trips recorded in 2022 but representing 77.4% of the 2019 total.' 'Canada's transit agencies provided 123.4 million passenger trips in December 2023, up 17.1% (+18.0 million trips) compared with the same month in 2022.' 'In December 2023, transit agency operating revenue (excluding subsidies) was up 25.5% (+$64.1 million) from the same month in 2022 but was $23.4 million below the December 2019 revenue.' 'Before the pandemic, annual ridership approached 1.9 billion trips in 2019.' 'With the public health measures implemented to combat the contagion, ridership fell to 849.1 million in 2020 and then to 778.4 million in 2021, less than half (45.0% and 41.2% respectively) of the 2019 total.' 'Growth continued into 2023, with the monthly rate of recovery compared with the same month in 2019 increasing from 70.6% in January to 80.5% in December.' 'Canada's population surpassed 40 million people as of July 1, 2023—an increase of almost 1.2 million from July 1, 2022, and marking the highest population growth since 1957.' 'Almost 98% of the growth from July 1, 2022, came from net international migration.' 'There were 426.3 million fewer passenger trips in 2023 compared with 2019.' 'Over this same period, Canada's population grew by almost 2.5 million people.' 'The pandemic has altered commuting behaviour.' 'A recent study on working from home and public transit attempted to quantify the impact of working from home on the reduction in transit passenger trips.'

title: Industrial product and raw materials price indexes, January 2024
summary: In January 2024, Canada's Industrial Product Price Index (IPPI) slightly declined by 0.1% from the previous month and fell 2.9% compared to January 2023. Lower prices for meat, fish, dairy, energy, and petroleum products, as well as primary non-ferrous metals, contributed to the decrease. Notably, beef and chicken prices dropped due to weak demand and abundant supply. Energy and petroleum product prices fell despite a rise in crude energy products, influenced by strong refining activity and weaker demand. In contrast, softwood lumber prices increased due to higher housing starts and reduced supply. The Raw Materials Price Index (RMPI) rose by 1.2% month over month, driven by a 3.0% increase in crude energy products, but saw a 6.4% year-over-year decline, with conventional crude oil prices significantly impacting the decrease.
quotes: 'Beef prices primarily fell due to weak seasonal demand.' 'Chicken prices continued to fall in January 2024, mainly because of abundant supply and relatively low seasonal demand.' 'Strength in the US dollar and anticipation of continued high interest rates weighed on silver prices in January.' 'Platinum group metal prices fell recently, partly due to uncertainty about future demand for palladium, as the market shifts towards electric vehicles.' 'The recent increase in Canadian housing starts and reduced domestic supply of lumber in the long term both played a part in the rise of lumber prices.' 'The risk to oil transportation caused by shipping disruptions in the Red Sea had an upward impact on prices.' 'Global corn production is expected to rise for the 2023/2024 crop year, which is likely influencing prices.'

title: Nationally, renters report lower quality of life than homeowners
summary: Canadian Social Survey data reveals disparities in quality of life, with renters, younger Canadians, and residents of Toronto and Vancouver reporting lower satisfaction and well-being. Renters struggle with financial burdens, facing record-low vacancy rates and high rent growth, spending more income on shelter costs. Young Canadians (15-54) report lower life satisfaction and mental health than older groups, with those aged 15-29 feeling less hopeful and more lonely. Homeownership is less common and mortgages less often paid off among the young. Toronto and Vancouver residents feel less community belonging and life satisfaction than their provincial counterparts, with higher shelter costs contributing to financial strain. Overall, 27% of households find it difficult to meet financial needs, with Toronto and Vancouver facing significant unaffordability in housing. Statistics Canada's Quality of Life framework aims to explore these factors further.
quotes: 'people living in rental housing report lower quality of life across several dimensions of well-being compared with those living in a home owned by someone in the household' 'renters were over 15 percentage points more likely to report difficulty meeting financial needs and over 11 percentage points less likely to report high overall life satisfaction' 'Renters across Canada faced record-low vacancy rates (1.5%) and record-high average rent growth (+8.0%) in 2023' 'Canadians aged 15 to 54 reported lower results on several quality of life indicators than those aged 55 or older' 'youth aged 15 to 29, in particular, were less satisfied and less hopeful about the future than in previous years, and they were more likely to feel lonely than older Canadians' 'nearly two-thirds of Canadians aged 15 to 29 rented their home' 'Canadians aged 55 and over (74.2%) were more likely to own their home than those aged 15 to 54 (59.5%)' 'people living in Toronto and Vancouver were less likely to report a strong sense of belonging to their community when compared with those living in the rest of Ontario or British Columbia' 'Residents of Toronto (46.0%) and Vancouver (45.1%) were also less likely to report high life satisfaction than elsewhere in their respective provinces' 'In the second quarter of 2023, almost 27% of households reported that it was difficult or very difficult to meet their financial needs, compared with less than 19% in late 2021' 'In Toronto, 30.3% of households lived in unaffordable housing and 12.6% of households spent over half their income on shelter costs' 'in 2023, the gap in average rents between turnover and non-turnover units was much higher than the national average (13%) in both Vancouver (27%) and Toronto (31%)' 'Statistics Canada will continue to explore the factors that drive quality of life—what matters most to Canadians'

title: Monthly credit aggregates, December 2023
summary: Household borrowing in December saw an increase of $8.1 billion (+0.3%), reaching $2,910.0 billion. Mortgage debt grew by $5.3 billion (+0.2% monthly; +3.0% annually), while non-mortgage loan debt rose $2.9 billion (+0.4%). Home equity lines of credit saw the largest growth since May 2022, up $0.8 billion (+0.5%), and credit card debt increased by $1.1 billion (+1.1%). Private non-financial corporation borrowing decreased by $12.2 billion, with non-mortgage loans from government lenders falling $4.0 billion (-6.9%), reflecting repayments of the Canada Emergency Business Account. Debt security liabilities dropped $9.6 billion due to exchange rate fluctuations.
quotes: 'Household mortgage debt rose $5.3 billion (+0.2% on a monthly basis; +3.0% on an annualized basis) in December' 'outstanding balances on home equity lines of credit increased $0.8 billion (+0.5%), the largest growth since May 2022' 'credit card debt with chartered banks advanced $1.1 billion (+1.1%)' 'Non-mortgage loans from government lenders decreased $4.0 billion (-6.9%), a sharper decline compared with November (-2.4%)' 'The value of debt security liabilities fell $9.6 billion in December, mainly because of exchange rate fluctuations'

title: Quarterly civil aviation statistics, third quarter 2023
summary: In the third quarter of 2023, the 24 largest Canadian air carriers saw operating revenue rise to $9.6 billion, a 21.2% increase from the same period in 2022 and 19.7% higher than pre-pandemic levels in 2019. Passenger revenue at $8.7 billion accounted for 90.2% of total revenue. Cargo revenue was $544.6 million, in line with pre-pandemic contributions. Operating expenses reached $7.9 billion, with the largest shares being other operating expenses (48.8%), turbo fuel (27.7%), and wages (20.0%). Passenger volumes reached 25.0 million, with a load factor of 88.4%, surpassing the 85.7% in 2019.
quotes: 'Operating revenue for the 24 largest Canadian air carriers totalled $9.6 billion in the third quarter' 'Cargo revenue reached $544.6 million in the third quarter of 2023' 'The 24 Canadian air carriers transported 25.0 million passengers in the third quarter'

title: Book publishing industry, 2022
summary: In 2022, the book publishers industry saw an 8.3% increase in operating revenue to $1.6 billion, with expenses rising to $1.5 billion. A resurgence in reading, partly influenced by social media, led to a record high in salaries and benefits at $378.2 million. Sales grew by 8.8%, with exports growing faster than domestic sales. E-book sales rose by 14.6%, while print sales also increased. Canadian book sales rebounded post-pandemic, with a notable rise in print book sales from physical stores. Canadian authors saw a 10.5% increase in sales, outpacing foreign authors and accounting for 52.8% of total sales. Rising production costs and the popularity of e-books may shift the industry's focus towards digital formats.
quotes: "Operating revenue for book publishers rose 8.3% to $1.6 billion from 2020 to 2022, the largest increase since comparable data became available in 2014" - "Salaries, wages and benefits rose 12.6% to a record high of $378.2 million and remained the largest share of operating expenses, at 25.5%" - "With a renewed excitement for reading, total sales rose 8.8% to $1.4 billion in 2022, with growth in exports (+13.9%) outpacing the increase of sales in Canada (+7.0%)" - "Sales of e-books continued to expand, rising 14.6% to $297.5 million from 2020 to 2022" - "Total book sales in Canada grew to $998.3 million in 2022, surpassing the 2018 value of $987.2 million" - "Sales of print books (not on the Internet) in Canada increased 10.5% to $696.4 million in 2022, just shy of the $702.7 million reached in 2018" - "In 2022, book sales by Canadian authors rose 10.5% to $707.6 million, while sales by foreign authors increased 6.7% to $633.0 million" - "The share of sales attributable to Canadian authors edged up from 51.9% in 2020 to 52.8% in 2022, marking the second consecutive period in which the majority of sales came from books by Canadian authors"

title: Canada's international transactions in securities, December 2023
summary: In December 2023, Canadian investors made a record investment of $29.4 billion in foreign securities, primarily in US equities and European shares. This led to a net outflow of $19.0 billion from the Canadian economy. Foreign investors bought $10.4 billion in Canadian securities, focusing on debt instruments, particularly private corporate and government debt securities, while divesting $532 million in Canadian shares. Throughout 2023, Canadian investors acquired $33.4 billion in foreign bonds and $13.1 billion in US shares, with global stock markets generally up. Foreign investment in Canadian bonds was strong at $79.7 billion, but there was a significant divestment in Canadian shares amounting to $48.7 billion.
quotes: 'Canadian investors acquired an unprecedented $29.4 billion of foreign securities in December, led by a record investment in foreign shares' 'Investors increased their exposure to US equity securities by $23.2 billion, the largest investment in three years' 'Canadian acquisitions of non-US foreign shares reached $6.3 billion, largely European shares' 'Foreign acquisitions of Canadian securities totalled $10.4 billion in December, led by investments in debt securities' 'Foreign investors added $11.0 billion of Canadian debt securities to their portfolios in December' 'Non-resident investors acquired $5.3 billion of government debt securities, mainly federal government bonds' 'Canadian investors added $33.4 billion of foreign bonds to their holdings in 2023' 'Canadian investors added $13.1 billion of US shares to their portfolios in 2023' 'Strong foreign investment in Canadian bonds continued, as non-resident investors acquired $79.7 billion worth in 2023' 'Foreign investors reduced their holdings of Canadian shares by $48.7 billion in 2023'

title: Wholesale trade, December 2023
summary: In December 2023, Canadian wholesale sales excluding certain commodities rose 0.3% to $82.9 billion, with a 1.2% annual increase. The personal and household goods subsector led the growth with a 4.1% rise to $12.1 billion, driven by pharmaceuticals. Ontario and Quebec led provincial gains, with Ontario up 1.2% to $42.9 billion. Inventories increased by 1.2% to $129.5 billion, with a slight rise in the inventory-to-sales ratio to 1.56. Quarterly sales in Q4 increased by 0.8% to $247.5 billion. Annual wholesale sales grew 1.5% to $986.9 billion, with the motor vehicle subsector up 11.7% to $164.8 billion. Electric vehicle sales continued to climb, and supply chain issues eased. Year-end inventories rose 2.1%, with the inventory-to-sales ratio increasing to 1.57.
quotes: 'Personal and household goods lead sales increase in December' 'Sales in Ontario lead provincial gains' 'Inventories rise in December' 'Wholesale sales continue to increase in the last quarter of 2023' 'Wholesale sales continue to rise on an annual basis' 'Inventory-to-sales ratio continues to increase in 2023'

title: Non-bank financial intermediation, 2007 to 2022
summary: In 2022, mortgage borrowing in Canada moderated due to higher borrowing costs, with households adding $144.4 billion in mortgage debt, down from 2021's record but still high compared to the 2009-2019 average. Mortgage assets of MICs grew by 11.3% to $36.3 billion, a deceleration from 2021, while MFCs saw their mortgage assets rise by $4.6 billion to $61.2 billion, marking their first increase since 2018. Non-mortgage household borrowing surged by $28.1 billion, the largest increase since 2009, with transportation leasing growing by 5.8% to $73.9 billion, and other leasing and finance sectors also experiencing significant growth in loan assets.
quotes: 'Low interest rates and strong housing demand pushed mortgage borrowing to record-high levels in 2020 and 2021' 'In 2022, households added $144.4 billion in mortgage debt' 'Among the principal NBCI mortgage lending sectors, the mortgage assets of MICs rose 11.3% in 2022 to reach $36.3 billion' 'The mortgage assets of MFCs also rose in 2022, adding $4.6 billion to reach $61.2 billion' 'The pace of household non-mortgage borrowing accelerated in 2022, up by $28.1 billion from the previous year' 'This was the largest dollar value increase since 2009' 'Among non-mortgage NBCI lenders, the transportation leasing sector saw a 5.8% (+$4.1 billion) increase in non-mortgage loan assets in 2022' 'The other leasing sector posted an increase of 19.1% (+$2.4 billion) in non-mortgage loan assets in 2022' 'Similarly, the financing sector recorded a 15.0% (+$2.3 billion) increase in non-mortgage loan assets in 2022'

title: Fruit and vegetable production, 2023
summary: In 2023, Canadian farm-gate sales of fruits and vegetables fell by 1.0% to $2.9 billion, with fruit sales down 4.1% and vegetable sales up 1.8%. The total production decreased by 4.1% to 3.1 billion kilograms, with fruit production dropping significantly by 8.1%. Adverse weather conditions, including dryness in Western Canada and excessive moisture in Quebec and the Atlantic provinces, impacted yields. Notably, Quebec experienced the largest decline in fruit sales, with a significant drop in lowbush blueberries, cranberries, and blackberries. In contrast, Ontario saw a 17.0% increase in fruit sales due to favorable weather and higher farm-gate prices. Vegetable production in Quebec dropped by 9.2% due to a decrease in harvested area and yields.
quotes: 'Fruit and vegetable farm-gate sales fell by 1.0% from 2022 to $2.9 billion in 2023' 'fruit sales fell 4.1% from 2022 to $1.3 billion in 2023' 'lower sales of lowbush blueberries (-32.8%), cranberries (-22.0%) and blackberries (-10.1%)' 'Quebec (-$56.4 million) accounted for the largest decline in fruit sales' 'fruit sales fell 1.9% to $457.0 million in 2023 on account of lower yields' 'Fruit sales rose by 17.0% to $411.3 million in 2023' 'apple production dropped by 3.7% to 368.5 million kilograms in 2023' 'sales rose by 2.9% at the national level to $293.2 million' 'total vegetable production declined by 2.5% to 2.2 billion kilograms compared with 2022' 'Total vegetable production in Quebec fell by 9.2% to 675.3 million kilograms in 2023' 'cranberry production fell by 39.2%, with yields down 35.9% in 2023'

title: Monthly Survey of Manufacturing, December 2023
summary: Manufacturing sales in Canada decreased by 0.7% to $71.2 billion in December, with significant drops in the motor vehicle industry (-13.5%) and chemical products (-3.1%). Aerospace production saw a 10.6% increase. Quarterly sales fell 1.6% in Q4 2023, with transportation equipment and food industries contributing most to the decline. Ontario and Manitoba led provincial sales decreases, while Quebec saw an increase due to aerospace production. Inventory levels dropped by 0.6%, and the capacity utilization rate decreased to 75.3%. In 2023, manufacturing sales grew by 1.1% to $862.8 billion, with transportation equipment sales up 27.0%. Petroleum and coal sales saw the largest decline at 14.3%. Inventory accumulation slowed, with a 1.2% increase to $123.1 billion.
quotes: 'Sales of motor vehicles fell 13.5% to $4.4 billion in December, the fifth consecutive monthly decline and the lowest level since December 2022' 'Production of aerospace products and parts rose 10.6% to $2.5 billion in December, the highest level on record' 'Sales in Ontario declined 2.8% to $31.0 billion in December, mainly on lower sales of motor vehicles (-13.7%)' 'Total inventories fell 0.6% to $123.1 billion in December, on lower goods in process (-3.0%) and finished product (-0.9%) inventories' 'The capacity utilization rate (not seasonally adjusted) for the total manufacturing sector decreased from 79.1% in November to 75.3% in December' 'In current dollars, total manufacturing sales increased 1.1% to $862.8 billion in 2023, following a 17.9% increase in 2021 and an 18.1% gain in 2022' 'Sales in the transportation equipment subsector marked a new record, rising 27.0% to $139.1 billion in 2023' 'Sales of petroleum and coal products fell 14.3% to $101.6 billion in 2023, following two consecutive yearly increases' 'The year-end total inventory levels in current dollars continued to grow, rising 1.2% from 2022 to $123.1 billion in 2023, although at a slower pace compared with 2021 (+17.2%) and 2022 (+20.3%)'

title: Investment in building construction, December 2023
summary: In December, Canadian building construction investment slightly increased by 0.3% to $19.8 billion, with both residential and non-residential sectors growing by 0.3%. Residential investment rose to $13.8 billion, with multi-unit buildings up by 1.6%, despite a 1.0% drop in single-family homes. Non-residential investment also increased to $6.1 billion, with institutional and industrial gains offsetting commercial declines. The fourth quarter saw a 7.8% rise to $59.0 billion, predominantly in residential construction. Annually, 2023 experienced a 6.6% decrease in building construction investment to $229.1 billion, with residential down 16.9% and non-residential slightly up by 0.6%.
quotes: 'Investment in building construction edged up 0.3% month over month to $19.8 billion in December' 'Investment in residential building construction grew 0.3% to $13.8 billion in December' 'Investment in the non-residential sector rose 0.3% to $6.1 billion in December' 'In the fourth quarter of 2023, investment in building construction grew 7.8% to $59.0 billion' 'Year over year, investment in building construction declined 6.6% to $229.1 billion in 2023'

title: Balance sheet of the agricultural sector, December 31, 2022 (revised data)
summary: Canadian farm sector equity surged by 12.9% to $729.9 billion in 2022, marking the largest increase since 1981, with Ontario contributing over a third of this growth. Total asset values rose by 12.0% to $861.5 billion, primarily due to a 12.8% increase in farm real estate values. Crop inventory values also saw a record 43.6% increase, driven by higher prices and yields. Poultry and livestock inventories grew by 17.8% on strong market demand. Liabilities increased by 7.1% to $131.5 billion, with long-term liabilities accounting for most of the rise. The interest coverage ratio improved significantly to 5.305, the highest since 2013, indicating a stronger ability to meet debt obligations despite rising interest rates.
quotes: 'This was the largest percentage increase in farm equity since the beginning of the series in 1981.' 'Farmland values grew despite rising interest rates and were supported by higher commodity prices and a limited supply of farmland for sale.' 'The value of crop inventories was up by $9.3 billion (+43.6%) to $30.7 billion as of December 31, 2022, the largest annual percentage increase recorded since the start of this series in 1981.' 'The interest coverage ratio, which measures the ability of the farm business to meet its interest payments, rose from 2.895 in 2021 to 5.305 in 2022.' 'This was the highest ratio since 2013, when it was 5.825.'

Key metrics include business openings/closures, job vacancies/rates, the Consumer Price Index, and the Industrial Product Price Index, as well as data on exports, imports, retail, and manufacturing sales. For a detailed overview, refer to the "Canadian Economic Tracker" release.

title: Provincial variation in the retention rates of immigrants, 2022
summary: Immigrants admitted to Ontario, British Columbia, and Alberta from 2012 to 2016 had the highest five-year retention rates, with Ontario leading at 93.1% for the 2016 cohort. The Prairie provinces and territories saw significant declines, while Atlantic provinces experienced increases, particularly in New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island. Family-sponsored immigrants and refugees had the highest five-year retention rates, while economic immigrants, especially those through the Provincial Nominee Program, saw declines. The one-year retention rates were more stable in the Prairie provinces but showed a downward trend in Saskatchewan. The Atlantic provinces saw improvements in retaining skilled immigrants, especially post-launch of the Atlantic Immigration Pilot Program, with Nova Scotia showing the most significant increase. Overall, family-sponsored immigrants and refugees had better retention than economic immigrants, and the Atlantic provinces are improving in retaining skilled immigrants.
quotes: 'Among immigrants admitted from 2012 to 2016, those who intended to reside in Ontario, British Columbia or Alberta were the most likely to stay in those provinces five years after their admission.' 'Specifically, among immigrants admitted in 2016, the five-year retention rate was 93.1% in Ontario, 87.3% in British Columbia and 84.5% in Alberta.' 'Alberta experienced a drop of 7.0 percentage points from 91.5% for the 2012 admission cohort.' 'In Saskatchewan, the five-year retention rate was down by 14.3 percentage points from the 2012 admission cohort (72.2%) to that of 2016 (57.9%).' 'In Manitoba, the five-year retention rate fell by 11.0 percentage points, from 75.1% among immigrants admitted in 2012 to 64.1% for those admitted in 2016.' 'In the Atlantic region, both New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island experienced an uptick in the five-year retention rate for immigrants who were admitted in 2016.' 'For the 2016 admission cohort, 91.7% of immigrants sponsored by family and 86.4% of refugees filed taxes in their intended destination province or territory five years after their admission.' 'The five-year retention rate of economic immigrants admitted from 2012 to 2016 trended downward; it dropped 4.2 percentage points, from 82.1% for the 2012 cohort to 77.9% for that of 2016.' 'Among immigrants admitted as caregivers in 2016, 94.9% still filed taxes in their intended destination province or territory five years later, while this was the case for 88.1% of immigrants from the CEC.' 'The one-year retention rate for Alberta fell by 2.3 percentage points from the 2016 admission cohort (88.0%) to that of 2020 (85.7%).' 'In Newfoundland and Labrador, the one-year retention rate grew by 11.4 percentage points, from 55.0% for the 2016 admission cohort to 66.4% for that of 2020.' 'Overall, the one-year retention rate for skilled immigrants in the Atlantic provinces for the 2020 admission cohort was higher than the rate prior to the launch of the AIPP.' 'Nova Scotia experienced the highest increase to the retention rate of skilled immigrants (+42.4 percentage points), up from 21.5% for the 2016 cohort to 63.9% for that of 2020.' 'Newfoundland and Labrador's one-year retention rate increased by 18.7 percentage points, from 31.3% for skilled immigrants admitted in 2016 to 50.0% for those admitted in 2020.' 'With the exception of Prince Edward Island, all of the Atlantic provinces experienced slight declines in retaining skilled immigrants admitted in 2020 compared with the 2019 admission cohort.'

title: Study: The school closest to home: Proximity of French-language elementary schools and enrolment in the Maritime provinces
summary: In the Maritime provinces in 2021, 72% of elementary school-aged children eligible for French instruction attended French-language schools, with higher rates among those with a French-speaking parent (92%) and those living closer to a French-language school (89%). Three-quarters lived within 10 km of a French-language school, and 51% lived closer to a French-language school than an English-language one. Enrolment in French-language schools was 89% when the nearest school was French but dropped to 56% when the nearest was English. Parental language at home was the strongest factor influencing enrolment, with 92% attendance for children with at least one French-speaking parent.
quotes: 'Nearly three-quarters (72%) of elementary school-aged children eligible for instruction in French were attending or had attended French-language elementary school' 'The majority (72%) of children eligible for instruction in French were attending or had attended a French-language school' 'The vast majority (92%) of children eligible for instruction in French had attended a French-language school when at least one parent spoke French most often at home'
